da41a68cd59b.title: Taking Stock: The Value of Pausing to Document and Plan
da41a68cd59b.subtitle: June 6, 2025
da41a68cd59b.content:
Taking Stock: The Value of Pausing to Document andÂ Plan

June 6, 2025

Sometimes the most productive thing you can do is stop being productive.

A week or so into my first attempt at building Piper Morgan, I had that special kind of mess that only happens when youâ€™re building something while figuring out what youâ€™re building. Working code that didnâ€™t quite work. Clear vision that wasnâ€™t quite clear. You know the feeling.

So I did something radical: I stopped coding and started documentint what Iâ€™d actually built versus what I thought Iâ€™d built.

Turns out, those are very different things.

The documentation exercise that became an intervention

The plan was simple, ask for a whole slew of standard technical docs based on our current codebase: Architecture doc, technical spec, requirements, one pager, roadmap, backlog, report to the team, one-pager, presentation. Anything I could think of I asked for.

Sonnet wrote me some enthusiastic first drafts:

â€œPiper Morgan seamlessly integrates organizational knowledge across multiple context levels, enabling sophisticated multi-modal product management workflowsâ€¦â€

I read that three times and still wasnâ€™t sure what it meant. And I built the thing. I was pretty sure it was wrong though.

Donâ€™t believe theÂ hype

I took the whole slew of documents and showed them to Opus. I told it â€œYou are distinguished principal architect and an enthusiastic PM and developer have built a prototype that they are presenting to the team as production ready.â€ I asked it to rewrite the docs to more realistic.

That lens changed everything:

  • â€œWorking systemâ€ â†’ â€œBasic implementation with significant gapsâ€
  • â€œProduction-ready architectureâ€ â†’ â€œServices deployed locally, not production-hardenedâ€
  • â€œAdvanced AI reasoningâ€ â†’ â€œTemplate responses with some LLM callsâ€
  • â€œLearning systemâ€ â†’ â€œStores feedback (learning TBD)â€

Was this depressing? Nah. It was liberating. Finally, I could see what Iâ€™d actually built.

You canâ€™t steer based onÂ hype

The revised documentation definitely backed off on the wild claims:

  • â€œReduces PM work by 50%â€ â†’ â€œPotential 30â€“50% reduction (unproven assumption)â€
  • â€œIntelligent issue creationâ€ â†’ â€œBasic GitHub integration, intelligence variesâ€
  • â€œKnowledge-aware responsesâ€ â†’ â€œSearch works, relevance inconsistentâ€

But hereâ€™s the thing: honest documentation enables honest planning. When you know where you really are, you can figure out where to go next.

The planningÂ paradox

Thereâ€™s always this tension: time spent documenting feels like time not spent coding. Especially when youâ€™re a team of one (plus AI assistants who never sleep but also never quite understand context).

But that June 6th pause taught me something. Comprehensive planning accelerates development by:

  1. Forcing honest assessmentâ€Šâ€”â€ŠCanâ€™t fix what you wonâ€™t acknowledge
  2. Identifying critical blockersâ€Šâ€”â€ŠThat workflow persistence bug Iâ€™d been ignoring? Yeah, that was blocking everything
  3. Setting realistic timelinesâ€Šâ€”â€ŠBased on actual capacity, not caffeinated optimism
  4. Creating accountabilityâ€Šâ€”â€ŠEven if just to future me
  5. Enabling better decisionsâ€Šâ€”â€ŠClear priorities beat fuzzy good intentions

What actually got clarified

AI development has unique challenges: Itâ€™s not just API calls. Itâ€™s prompt engineering, output validation, and handling the fact that LLMs sometimes just make stuff up. The timeline estimates were all over the map. In some ways way conservative because based on language about unaugmented human developers. In other way ambitious because of the hours spent fixing LLM-powered mistakes.

Single developer risk is real: Without documentation, this whole project was just in my head. There was no way to even see the whole shebang, let alone show it to anyone else. Someday Iâ€™d love to have others adding to this codebase, but that wonâ€™t happen if itâ€™s a black box.

Integration complexity compounds: GitHub + Claude + OpenAI + ChromaDB + PostgreSQL = five potential failure points. When I started this project I knew it was ambitious but I had underestimated the level of complexity and the endless combinations of glitch that can bring the whole house down.

Itâ€™s not quite the complex-stakeholder complexity I dealt with at big companies like Yahoo and even bigger enterprises like California and the U.S. Federal government, but it has that same quality of you can get almost everything aligned when suddenly one of your mainstays goes out of true and youâ€™re b0rked again.

The meta-documentation bonus

Writing docs about building an AI system with AI assistance got weird fast. The session log my bot wrote was more optimistic than my mental state. Had to keep editing:

Bot: â€œSuccessfully implemented sophisticated orchestration engine!â€ Me: â€œFixed basic workflow execution. Mostly.â€

Bot: â€œLearning system captures valuable signals!â€ Me: â€œRedis stores some JSON. Learning part TODO.â€

Realistic next steps,Â orâ€¦

Armed with more honest documentation, it seemed the priorities became crystal clear:

  1. Fix workflow persistenceâ€Šâ€”â€ŠCurrently broken, blocking everything
  2. Get ONE integration working end-to-endâ€Šâ€”â€ŠGitHub first, fantasies later
  3. Improve search qualityâ€Šâ€”â€ŠCurrent results areâ€¦ creative
  4. Build basic UIâ€Šâ€”â€ŠAPI-only testing getting old

The documentation exercise also generated two useful scripts: one to populate GitHub with all the docs, another to create issues from the backlog. At least the automation to document my struggles was working!

Over time we outgrew those scripts but the concept of maintaining docs automatically and iterating them over time stays with me.

What I didnâ€™t see yet was that we needed to stop and start over, as recounted in â€œThe Great Rebuild: Starting Over When Starting Over Is the Only Option,â€ so for the moment I just kept plowing ahead thinking my taking-stock pause was enough.

Getting the balanceÂ right

Building complex systems requires alternating between execution and reflection. Pure execution without planning leads to beautiful messes (hi, current state!). Pure planning without execution leads to beautiful fiction (hi, first draft docs!).

The sweet spot? Periodic reality checks like this one. Comprehensive enough to hurt a little, focused enough to actually help. Even as we outgrew the prototype and started on the MVP, I have continued to alternate between periods of developing and periods of taking stock and reviewing where we are.

The actualÂ learning

That day of documentation taught me more about Piper Morgan than the previous week of coding. Not because writing is magic, but because writing honestly about what youâ€™ve built forces you to see it clearly.

With what we learned from generating these docs, reviewing them, and asking for expert advice was that even with some basic capabilities working and the possibility of adding more, we lacked a solid architectural foundation, would likely never be able to build the more sophisticated features Iâ€™d imagined, and that it was time to rethink.

That alone probably saved me weeks of sunk-cost work on a dead-end approach. I didnâ€™t mind learning this! I learned so much in the first nine or ten days and none of it went to waste in the rebuild. Iâ€™m just glad we stopped and checked the map before driving further into the desert.

b5bb0c2c9384.title: Bidirectional Intelligence: Teaching AI to Critique, Not Just Create
b5bb0c2c9384.subtitle: June 8â€“9, 2025
b5bb0c2c9384.content:
Bidirectional Intelligence: Teaching AI to Critique, Not JustÂ Create

June 8â€“9, 2025

Most PM tools are one-way streets. Create a ticket. Push to GitHub. Move on. But what about all those existing issues that read like someone transcribed a fever dream?

Thatâ€™s what PM-008 was about: teaching Piper to analyze and improve existing GitHub issues. Turns out, teaching an AI to give constructive feedback is like teaching your kid to critique your cooking. You want honesty, but you really donâ€™t want any lip.

The architectural choice thatÂ mattered

We could have built issue analysis as a separate system. New classes, new patterns, new everything. Instead, we built on what we already had:

  • GitHubAgent: Already knew how to talk to GitHub
  • IssueContentGenerator: Already knew what good issues looked like
  • Knowledge base: 85 chunks of PM wisdom from my book
  • LLM: Could reason about quality if given the right context

By the way, I see Iâ€™m again slipping into saying â€œwe decidedâ€ when that usually meant Claude (and sometimes my Cursor Agent) proposed something and I said â€œsure, that makes sense.â€ Credit where creditâ€™s due.

The URL parsing adventure

First challenge: GitHub URLs come in many flavors:

  • https://github.com/owner/repo/issues/123
  • github.com/owner/repo/issues/123
  • https://github.com/owner/repo/pull/123 (whoops, that's a PR)
  • owner/repo#123 (GitHub shorthand)

We chose the â€œaccept everything, parse forgivinglyâ€ approach:

pattern = r'github\.com/([^/]+)/([^/]+)/issues/(\d+)'

Because in the real world, people paste URLs however they copied them. Fighting user behavior is like fighting gravityâ€Šâ€”â€Štechnically possible, but why?

The knowledge contextÂ magic

Hereâ€™s where it got interesting. Instead of hardcoding rules about what makes a good issue, we had Piper search the knowledge base for relevant PM practices, then use those as context for analysis.

After testing for a while and finding the results, as expected, about as good as a clever college intern could do with the basics of product management down and access to a library. So I asked one of my UX colleagues if I could let my new little bot read one of her github tickets and offer suggestions.

I have yet to meet a UX strategist or designer who loves filling out issues in Jira or Github or what have you, and she had no objection.

Piper wrote this fairly useful comment, which I posted to the real ticket:
This issue provides a comprehensive description of the task to refine the Veteran journey map for choosing a decision review pathway.

The acceptance criteria are well-defined, and the relevant links and artifacts are included for reference.
One suggestion would be to assign a specific team member to the last acceptance criteria point to ensure accountability for documenting and sharing the final version of the journey map.
Overall, this issue is complete and clear, and the team should be able to proceed with the work as described.

Piper wasnâ€™t applying generic rules. It was referencing specific PM practices from ingested documents. Like having a senior PM review every issue, except the senior PM never gets tired or sarcastic.

The confidence scoreÂ surprise

We added confidence scoring (0.0â€“1.0) expecting, in this case, that it would generally be high. Surprise: Piper knows when it doesnâ€™t know enough.

Testing on another issue, confidence came back at 0.50. Why? The original issue was so sparse that even with PM knowledge, Piper couldnâ€™t be sure about user impact or technical approach.

This is honestly huge. An AI that says â€œIâ€™m not sureâ€ is infinitely more useful than one that confidently hallucinates solutions.

Real-world performance

The full analysis pipeline:

  1. Parse URL (flexible regex)
  2. Fetch issue via GitHub API
  3. Search knowledge base for relevant practices
  4. Generate â€œidealâ€ version for comparison
  5. Produce analysis with specific improvements

For a test issue:

  • âœ… Identified missing problem statement
  • âœ… Noted lack of acceptance criteria
  • âœ… Flagged absent user impact details
  • âœ… Suggested specific improvements
  • âœ… Generated rewrite with proper structure

All in about 23 seconds. Not blazing fast, but faster than waiting for human review.

Vindicating the composition pattern

Remember that architectural choice to compose (make us of) existing services instead of creating something new? It paid off:

  • No new dependenciesâ€Šâ€”â€ŠEverything already installed
  • Familiar patternsâ€Šâ€”â€ŠSame error handling, same logging
  • Knowledge reuseâ€Šâ€”â€ŠPM-007â€™s enhanced search just worked
  • Testing isolationâ€Šâ€”â€ŠCould test each layer independently

This is what good architecture feels like. New capabilities emerge from existing components without fighting the system.

The humblingÂ reality

Of course, it wasnâ€™t all smooth sailing. Testing revealed:

  • Python REPL behaves differently than scripts (environment variables, anyone?)
  • Virtual environments need activation (every. single. time.)
  • .env files need to be in the right directory
  • My ability to type â€œpythonâ€ instead of â€œpython3â€ remains inconsistent and I still find myself â€œfixingâ€ that all the time.

But these are operational grumbles, not architectural flaws. The design held up.

What thisÂ enables

PM-008 (when we refactored the documentation and made a roadmap and backlog, all our pending work got numbered) wasnâ€™t just about reviewing issues.

Itâ€™s proof that Piper 0.1 could:

  • Derive quality standards from organizational knowledge
  • Apply those standards
  • Provide specific, actionable feedback
  • Know when it lacks confidence

By now I was impatient to start seeing Piper as an actual conversational partner. I wanted integration with the chat interface! I should be able to sue natural language like â€œreview this issue: [URL]â€ to trigger the full analysis pipeline.

I also started feeding Piper Morganâ€™s own backlog issues into it for review. Look, Piper! Youâ€™re already helping to build yourself!

The biggerÂ pattern

Weâ€™re building bidirectional intelligence. Not just create, but also review. Not just push, but also pull. Not just execute, but also evaluate.

Itâ€™s like the difference between a junior PM who only creates tickets and a senior PM who improves everyoneâ€™s tickets. Except this senior PM works 24/7 and never gets frustrated by the fifteenth vague bug report of the day.

At this point I still hadnâ€™t reckoned with the fundamental limitations of the prototype. I was still a day or so of manic coding before hitting that wall. At this point I was full of optimism. Four weeks later I would be wondering how this legacy github code with its alternate workflow had made its way into my MVP codebase, forgetting entirely about this brief feeling of a moment of triumph that at least hinted toward the future potential of Piper Morgan.

cc7f4b96b621.title: The RAG Revelation: When Your Proof of Concept Answers Back
cc7f4b96b621.subtitle: May 29, 2025
cc7f4b96b621.content:
The RAG Revelation: When Your Proof of Concept AnswersÂ Back

May 29, 2025

Before the rebuilds, before the domain models, before I knew what a circular dependency even was, there was a moment. That moment when your hacky prototype does exactly what you hoped it would do, and you realize you might be onto something.

Let me rewind to late May, when Piper Morgan was just an idea and some synthetic documents.

The setup: fake it till you makeÂ it

Claude had fabricated some generic â€œproduct documentationâ€â€Šâ€”â€Šreally just some made-up requirements docs, a fictional API spec, and a pretend project roadmap. Total fiction. Like writing a screenplay for a movie about product management (a boring movie).

Still, you donâ€™t need real data to see how your machine handles data, just data. Fake data is till data.

The plan was simple:

  1. Chunk these fake documents
  2. Embed them with OpenAI
  3. Store them in a vector database
  4. See if I could get meaningful answers back

This is called RAGâ€Šâ€”â€ŠRetrieval Augmented Generation. Fancy name for â€œfind relevant stuff, then let the AI use it to answer questions.â€ Not revolutionary (nothing about this project is revolutionary), but potentially useful. (If youâ€™ve got a blog, try to using RAG on your archives!)

The first realÂ test

I fed my fake documents into the system. ChromaDB dutifully stored them. OpenAI created embeddings. Everything looked ready.

Time for the moment of truth. I ran the proof-of-concept python file (pm_agent_poc.py) and it started churning through some canned requests

I need a new feature for the user profile page. Add a dark mode toggle. This is for the Piper Morgan project.

And then Piper responded:

--- Processing request for repo 'mediajunkie/test-piper-morgan' ---
User Request: 'Add a dark mode toggle feature to the user profile page for the Piper Morgan project.'
Searching knowledge base with query: 'Add a dark mode toggle feature to the user profile page for the Piper Morgan project. Piper Morgan project'
Number of requested results 5 is greater than number of elements in index 1, updating n_results = 1
Generating structured issue data with LLM...
Claude structured query successful, JSON parsed.
Claude structured query successful, JSON parsed.
Generated issue data: Title='Add dark mode toggle to user profile page', Labels=['feature', 'enhancement', 'UI/UX']
âœ… Successfully created issue: 'Add dark mode toggle to user profile page'

Holy crap. It worked.

Why thisÂ mattered

Now, I know what youâ€™re thinking. â€œCongrats, you built a toy github machine.â€ And yeah, fair. But hereâ€™s what made this different:

The response wasnâ€™t just regurgitating text. It had:

  • Combined information from multiple document chunks
  • Structured it coherently
  • Added context that made sense
  • Formatted it like an actual PM would

This wasnâ€™t keyword matching. It was understanding. Perhaps a primitive, limited form of understanding, but understanding nonetheless.

What RAG actuallyÂ means

Hereâ€™s the thing about Large Language Models: theyâ€™re brilliant and theyâ€™re liars. Ask GPT about your companyâ€™s API and itâ€™ll confidently make up endpoints that sound plausible but donâ€™t exist.

RAG fixes this by grounding the AI in actual documents instead of vague Internet- (and pirated book-) sourced generalities:

  1. Find relevant chunks from your knowledge base
  2. Pass them as context to the LLM
  3. LLM answers based on that specific context
  4. No hallucination about things not in the documents

Itâ€™s like the difference between asking someone to guess your product requirements versus handing them the spec and asking them to summarize it.

The ahaÂ moment

The real revelation wasnâ€™t that RAG workedâ€Šâ€”â€Šsmarter people than me had already proven that. The revelation was what it meant for Piper Morgan:

  • PMs could upload their actual documents
  • Piper could answer questions about specific projects
  • Knowledge would accumulate over time
  • Context would be real, not imagined

This reinforced the potential of a core element of the vision: a knowledge-aware assistant that actually understood your product context.

Itâ€™s also when I started thinking this thing could really work someday.

The validating power of proving aÂ concept

That evening, with my fake documents and real answers, I knew two things:

  1. The technical approach was sound
  2. I had no idea how to build this properly

The POC was held together with string and good intentions. Directory structure? Whatâ€™s that? Error handling? Thatâ€™s future meâ€™s problem. But it proved the core concept.

Sometimes you need that ugly prototype that barely works just to validate that the idea isnâ€™t crazy. RAG + PM documents = contextual intelligence. Simple equation, powerful result.

What cameÂ next

This successful test is what justified everything that followed:

  • The prototype hack-a-thon I spent the rest of the week on
  • The pause to document and reconsider
  • The decision to do a complete rebuild with proper architecture
  • The domain-driven design approach
  • The learning infrastructure
  • All those hours fighting Python imports

Without this momentâ€Šâ€”â€Šwhen synthetic documents produced real insightsâ€Šâ€”â€Šnone of that would have happened.

The lesson thatÂ sticks

Building AI products is weird because the gap between â€œdoesnâ€™t work at allâ€ and â€œbasically magicâ€ is sometimes just getting your vectors aligned correctly. One day youâ€™re failing to retrieve anything relevant. The next day your prototype is answering questions like it actually understands your fake product.

The RAG revelation taught me: start with the core intelligence. Everything elseâ€Šâ€”â€Šthe architecture, the infrastructure, the fancy featuresâ€Šâ€”â€Šonly matters if the fundamental approach works.

Good thing I tested that first. Even if it was with completely made-up documents.

bb06005611cb.title: From Research Question to Working Prototype: Building an AI PM Assistant from Scratch
bb06005611cb.subtitle: May 29, 2025
bb06005611cb.content:
From Research Question to Working Prototype: Building an AI PM Assistant fromÂ Scratch

May 29, 2025

You know that moment when you realize youâ€™re spending more time managing your work than doing your work? That was me, drowning in GitHub tickets, meeting notes, and legacy documentation that might as well have been written in Linear B.

â€œHow hard could it be to build an AI assistant?â€ I thought, with the dangerous confidence of someone whoâ€™d just discovered LangChain existed.

Narrator: It was harder than he thought.

The delusion that started itÂ all

The initial fantasy was simple: Build a â€œjunior PM internâ€ that could handle the mind-numbing parts of product management. You know, the stuff that makes you question your career choices:

  • Turning rambling Slack messages into properly formatted GitHub tickets
  • Finding that one crucial decision buried in 47 pages of meeting notes
  • Explaining why we canâ€™t just â€œmake it work like Amazonâ€ for the thousandth time

The research question sounded so academic: â€œHow can I develop my own AI agent to handle routine knowledge-management tasks?â€

What I actually meant was: â€œCan I automate myself out of the boring parts of my job without accidentally automating myself out of a job?â€

Platform shopping: the no-codeÂ mirage

I had played around with ChatGPT and the other free bots out there of course, but the problem is they donâ€™t learn and they donâ€™t remember. We donâ€™t even want them to learn because who trusts OpenAI?

But I wanted something that could persist, get better, get to know me and my ideas about how to be a good PM.

The brutal truth: No-code solutions are great if your use case is â€œslightly smarter chatbot.â€ For anything that actually needs to understand your organizationâ€™s context? Time to write some code.

Choosing the stack (or how I learned to stop worrying and love dependencies)

I initially went with Python + LangChain + Chroma + OpenAI because:

  1. Everyone else was using it (peer pressure works)
  2. The documentation existed (mostly)
  3. I could pronounce all the library names (underrated feature)

The real reason? That was the stack recommended to me in my very first chat on the subject (which I just found, so we will include a flashback to that earlier moment at some point!). Also, I needed something I could rip apart and rebuild when it inevitably didnâ€™t work. Vendor lock-in is like a bad relationshipâ€Šâ€”â€Šeasy to get into, painful to leave.

Building the first prototype (a comedy in threeÂ acts)

Act 1: Environment setup Hell

Iâ€™m really not a programmer so my desktop â€œhygeineâ€ is atrocious. The first few sessions of work I had to recreate my environment from scratch each time, endlessly re-installing and upgrading the same packages over and over.

Act 2: The document ingestion dance

Remember when you thought â€œIâ€™ll just load some documentsâ€ would be simple? Me too. Over time I was able to get the prototype to ingest documents, but later when I started working on the real thing and we were inspecting the prototype code, Claude told me the chunks were cutting through sentences. Apparently, this is something of a solved problem but I got the low-rent version on my first try.

Act 3: The first real question

After two days of setup, dependency hell, and questioning my life choices, I asked the system a question about an uploaded doc and, it did OK.

I may have done a small victory dance.

The trivial technical challenges nobody warns youÂ about

Then thereâ€™s â€œlibrary version rouletteâ€ when you get the latest version of something and it turns out one of your other somethings doesnâ€™t know how to work with that latest version, so you have to downgrade it. Then that happens the next time and eventually you remember to pin it (?) or just make it clearer what the acceptable version range is in yourÂ .env file.

Creating test data (fiction forÂ bots)

To properly test this thing, Claude made me a handful of realistic PM documents. This definitely saved me time. Writing good test data by hand woild have taken almost as long as conjuring up the prototype. But bad test data is like testing a boat in your bathtubâ€Šâ€”â€Šsure, it floats, but will it handle the ocean?

What actuallyÂ worked

RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation): Despite the terrible acronym, this approach was magic. The system could actually understand questions like â€œWhy did we choose PostgreSQL?â€ and give answers that didnâ€™t sound like they came from a fortune cookie.

The Modular Mess: My spaghetti code architecture accidentally turned out to be brilliantly modular. When I needed to swap vector databases, it only tookâ€¦ okay, it took six hours and a lot of swearing, but it COULD be done.

Local Development: No API costs during development meant I could fail fast, fail often, and fail spectacularly without explaining a $500 OpenAI bill to finance.

What tookÂ forever

Context Management: Maintaining conversation state was like teaching a goldfish to remember your birthday. Possible, but requires more engineering than youâ€™d think. This is something I still struggle with, even as I accumulate a growing bag of tricks

Error Handling: LLMs fail in creative ways but tend to generate extremely unhelpful error messages. Building even simple error handling took twice as long as building the happy path, and on the MVP today we still havenâ€™t made error handling much more helpful yet.

Bug squashing: Turns out vibe coding tends to mean spending more time doing QA and fixing bugs than generating new routines. Who knew? (Besides, well, everyone posting on LinkedIn these days, apparently.)

The path to production (spoiler: itâ€™s paved with broken prototypes)

The prototype worked! Sort of. If you:

  • Ran it locally
  • Didnâ€™t mind waiting 30 seconds for responses
  • Didnâ€™t expect it to do very much yet.
  • But it didnâ€™t seem to crash (much)!

And it proved the concept. An AI could understand our PM context and provide useful answers. Now I just had to make itâ€¦ you knowâ€¦ actually usable.

Lessons for my futureÂ self

Start with the data model: Understanding your information architecture beats having a pretty interface every time.

Build for replaceability: That perfect library you found? Itâ€™ll be deprecated next month. Plan accordingly.

Local first, cloud later: Work out the kinks without burning API credits. Your finance team will thank you.

Test data is real work: Budget time for it. Like, real time. Not â€œIâ€™ll throw something togetherâ€ time.

Document everything: Future you will not remember why you chose that specific chunking strategy at 2 AM on a Tuesday. This is a lesson I am learning incrementally.

The moment ofÂ truth

The CLI (command-line interface) prototype validated something important: AI could actually help with PM work. Not by being magic, but by maybe by being a really bright intern who never forgot what was in the documentation.

But a command-line tool that only did one trick wasnâ€™t going to shave much time off my day. Time to build something real.

The bottomÂ line

Building a working prototype taught me that AI development is 10% machine learning and 90% dealing with the same problems weâ€™ve always had: data quality, system integration, and user experience.

The prototype wasnâ€™t pretty. It wasnâ€™t fast. It occasionally made no sense. But it worked just well enough to prove it was worth doing right.

Next up: How adding a web interface and GitHub integration turned my simple prototype into a complex disaster (and then into something actually useful).

c7207687f711.subtitle: May 29, 2025
c7207687f711.content:
From CLI to Web App: When Prototypes Meet Real Workflows

May 29, 2025

The command-line prototype was working! Well, â€œworkingâ€ in the sense that a paper airplane â€œworksâ€ as an aircraft. Sure, it could answer questions about our documentation, but try explaining to your team why they need to open a terminal, activate a virtual environment, and type commands like itâ€™s 1985.

I could run github_agent.py and see a successful login:

% python github_agent.py
/Users/xian/Library/Python/3.9/lib/python/site-packages/urllib3/__init__.py:35: NotOpenSSLWarning: urllib3 v2 only supports OpenSSL 1.1.1+, currently the 'ssl' module is compiled with 'LibreSSL 2.8.3'. See: https://github.com/urllib3/urllib3/issues/3020
  warnings.warn(
2025-07-10 05:27:47,782 - pm_agent_app - INFO - Logging configured successfully.
2025-07-10 05:27:48,120 - pm_agent_app - INFO - âœ… Connected to GitHub as: mediajunkie
2025-07-10 05:27:48,120 - pm_agent_app - INFO - 
ğŸ“š Your repositories:
2025-07-10 05:27:48,647 - pm_agent_app - INFO -   - 7cups-testbot ğŸŒ
2025-07-10 05:27:48,647 - pm_agent_app - INFO -   - christiancrumlish.com ğŸŒ
2025-07-10 05:27:48,648 - pm_agent_app - INFO -   - civictech.club ğŸŒ
2025-07-10 05:27:48,648 - pm_agent_app - INFO -   - crumlish.me ğŸŒ
2025-07-10 05:27:48,648 - pm_agent_app - INFO -   - designinproduct ğŸŒ

Or I could run a separate command-line app github_reviewer.py to give it the URL of an issue to review. That was about it, and itâ€™s not like anyone else was going to be able to access this from my machine.

The CLI comfortÂ zone

Thereâ€™s something beautifully simple about command-line interfaces. No buttons to align, no CSS to fight with, no JavaScript framework wars. Just you, a terminal, and the naive belief that everyone loves typing commands as much as you do.

Some people believe we are currently in the CLI era with these LLM-powered AI thingies. I guess maybe I like this period when itâ€™s still all about typing and words?

My CLI prototype was elegant in its constraints:

  • Input: Type question
  • Output: Get answer
  • Error handling: Stack trace (thatâ€™s helpful, right?)
  • User experience: Whatâ€™s that?

This worked great for an audience of one (me). For an audience of more than one? Time to enter the wonderful world of web development, where everything takes four times longer than expected and nothing works in Internet Explorer (yes, Myron from Finance still uses it).

The great migration: OpenAI toÂ Claude

Before tackling the web interface, I made one â€œsmallâ€ change: switching from OpenAI to Claude. How hard could swapping LLM providers be?

Narrator: Actually not that hard!

The technical migration took less than 30 minutes thanks to my accidentally-brilliant adapter pattern. The prompt engineering (which was embedded in the code and not something I had paid any close attention to) carried over as is.

Why did I switch? Mainly due to a recommendation from my boss, the idea that Anthropic was the most advanced LLM out there these days, and some discomfort with OpenAI as an org. The truth is, though, the code is designed to swap out LLMs like rented mules. In fact, just recently I hit a token limit on Claude that broke the app, at which point we put in a silent fall-back to switch over to OpenAI when that happens, but Iâ€™m getting ahead of myself.

Enter Streamlit: The â€œsimpleâ€ web framework

Claude recommended we built the UI with Streamlit (new to me). Streamlit promised I could build a web UI with â€œjust Python!â€ No JavaScript! No CSS! No problems!

Ron Howard voice: There were problems.

Sure, Streamlit made it easy to create a basic interface. But â€œbasicâ€ is doing a lot of heavy lifting there. Want custom styling? Write CSS. Need real-time updates? Hello, JavaScript. Want to handle more than one user at a time? Welcome to the wonderful world of session state management.

The Streamlit app looksâ€¦ fine?

GitHub integration: The API that launched a thousandÂ errors

Adding GitHub integration seemed straightforward. The GitHub API is well-documented! There are Python libraries! What could go wrong?

Everything. Everything could go wrong.

Authentication Adventures: â€œJust use a personal access token!â€ they said. â€œItâ€™ll be easy!â€ they said. They didnâ€™t mention â€œdonâ€™t accidentally make it a read-only token.

The Repository Name Game: First I setup a repo called piper-morgan for the project. Then I realized I didnâ€™t want to clutter up the real repo with test issues so I made one called test-piper-morgan. Then I mistakenly told the code it was called piper-morgan-test and hilarity ensued.

The Plain Language Dance: Users donâ€™t think in GitHubâ€™s owner/repo format. They type things like â€œthe mobile repoâ€ or â€œthe design in product repo.â€ Building a repository resolver felt like teaching a GPS to understand directions like â€œturn left at where the old gas station used to be.â€

Context is everything (and everything isÂ context)

The biggest shock moving from CLI to web + GitHub was how much context matters. In the CLI, I could assume I (the only user) knew what I meant. In production, I would need to to handle inputs like:

â€œUsers are complaining they canâ€™t upload files bigger than 20 megâ€

From this, the system needed to infer that this is a bug or an engancement request, that it involves the file upload feature on some product weâ€™ve likely been discussing, and that there is a limit in place that is too strict. The extra work to go from that request to a well qualified ticket involves some leaps of logic.

This required building what I generously called an â€œintent resolution systemâ€ and what was actually at first some clever regex that looked for the hallmarks of different types of utterances (greetings, request to make a ticket, request to analyze a ticket, uhâ€¦ it didnâ€™t really do much else yet.

Integration hell: A circle for everyÂ API

By the time I had GitHub working, Iâ€™d created a integration hydra:

GitHub API: Authentication, rate limiting, webhook handling, permissions, repository management, issue templates, label managementâ€¦

Claude API: Prompt optimization, token counting, response streaming, fallback handling, cost tracking (ğŸ’¸)â€¦

Vector Database: Document chunking, embedding generation, similarity search, index management, backup strategiesâ€¦

Web Framework: Session state, concurrent users, WebSocket connections, file uploads, error boundariesâ€¦

Each integration point was a potential failure mode. The combinations were exponential. My error handling code grew longer than my actual application code.

What we actuallyÂ made

After that seemingly simple request (â€œCan we get a web UI on this thing), we now had made:

  • A web interface that didnâ€™t require a computer science degree to use
  • GitHub integration that created issues engineers actually wanted to read
  • Context resolution that right 80% of the time (and asked for clarification the other 20%)
  • A loading experience that didnâ€™t make people think their browser crashed

It wasnâ€™t perfect. But it was usable. Theoretically someday even by people who werenâ€™t me. That felt like a miracle.

Lessons learned (the hardÂ way)

Integration complexity grows exponentially: Two systems = 2x complexity. Three systems = 9x complexity. Four systems = maybe reconsider your life choices.

Error messages are user experience: Right now we had error handling only a robot could love.

Quality beats speed for professional tools: Fast and wrong is worse than slow and right. Your users are professionals; treat them like it.

Also, itâ€™s likely that Piper isnâ€™t up on Monty Python.

The accidental platform

By tackling the â€œsimpleâ€ problem of letting people create GitHub issues through a web interface, Iâ€™d accidentally started building a platform:

  • Async job processing (much harder than it sounds)
  • External API orchestration (harder than async job processing)
  • Context resolution engine (I still donâ€™t fully understand how it works)
  • And every time I asked for something else, Claude agreed and we got to work bolting it on.

This wasnâ€™t the plan. The plan was â€œmake CLI tool work on web.â€ The reality was building infrastructure for something much bigger.

The real productÂ lesson

Moving from CLI to web-based GitHub integration taught me the most valuable product lesson of all: The interface is not the product. The workflow is the product.

Users donâ€™t want to create GitHub issues. They want their problems solved. They donâ€™t want to query documentation. They want answers to their questions. They donâ€™t want AI. They want their job to be easier.

Every technical decision should serve that goal.

647704d46558.title: Domain-First Development: Actually Building What We Designed
647704d46558.subtitle: June 2, 2025
647704d46558.content:
Domain-First Development: Actually Building What WeÂ Designed

June 2, 2025

The decision was made: Time to start over. Iâ€™d synthesized the advice of multiple thinking parters and designed a $0 infrastructure. Iâ€™d written about the vision of a strategic thinking partner.

Now came the hard part: actually building it.

Starting where itÂ matters

The temptation was strong to dive straight into the AI integration. After all, this was an AI product, right? But years of watching projects fail (and a bit of asking around for advice from several LLMs) taught me better. Start with the domain.

While Docker containers spun up in the background (PostgreSQL, Redis, ChromaDB, Temporal, Traefikâ€Šâ€”â€Šthe whole orchestra), I opened a single file: models.py.

python@dataclass
class Product:
    id: str
    name: str
    vision: str
    strategy: str
    metrics: List['Metric']
    features: List['Feature']
    stakeholders: List['Stakeholder']

This wasnâ€™t code. This was philosophy. Every line was a statement about what product management actually is.

I was reminded of realizing back in the day (maybe when I was still at Yahoo) that a great User Experience started with the data structures. By the time youâ€™re painting the interface on, itâ€™s too late!

This is likely doubly true now that the presentation layer is evolving into this fuzzy language-based form of interaction.

Successful prototype syndrome

Hereâ€™s something nobody tells you about successful prototypes: theyâ€™re dangerous. The POC worked. It created GitHub issues, reviewed tickets, ingested documents. It would have been so easy to justâ€¦ keep building on it.

But thatâ€™s how you end up with a GitHub issue creator that happens to do PM tasks, instead of a PM assistant that happens to create GitHub issues.

The domain models forced the right perspective:

  • WorkItem not GitHubIssue
  • Stakeholder not GitHubUser
  • Feature not PullRequest

GitHub would be a plugin. So would Jira. So would whatever the hot new tool would be next year.

The SSH authentication dance

Of course, no development session is complete without authentication issues. I kept following advice to use obsolete GitHub workflows and would only realize when it asked for my password and then rejected the login saying GitHub doesnâ€™t support that form of authentication anymore.

Then Iâ€™d remember I had SSH keys set up and use that instead. But the dance continued.

bash

git push origin main
Permission denied (publickey)

But I have SSH keys! Theyâ€™re right there!

Turns out you can have SSH keys got GitHub that only let you read stuff and not write it. Why did I set one of thus up at first? I seriously canâ€™t remember.

Also, having SSH configured for GitHub and having it configured for this repository are also different things.

Twenty minutes later I found (or maybe created again from scratch) the right kind of PAT (personal access token) and was able to move on, for now.

Dependencies: the hidden timeÂ sink

With models defined and Git finally cooperating, time to install dependencies. How hard could it be? (Readers of this series may already have an idea.)

pip install -r requirements.txt

It was, in fact, quite hard.

The AI ecosystem in 2025 isâ€¦ energetic. Packages update daily. Breaking changes are a lifestyle choice. My terminal became a waterfall of version conflicts:

langchain 0.1.0 requires pydantic>=2.0
but anthropic 0.18.1 requires pydantic<2.0
but openai 1.0.0 requires pydantic>=2.0
but wait chromadb needs...

Solution? Start minimal. Add only what you need, when you need it. The final requirements.txt was surprisingly short:

fastapi
anthropic
openai
sqlalchemy
redis

Everything else could wait.

Infrastructure: when it justÂ works

Hereâ€™s the beautiful thing about that bootstrap script: it actually worked. One command and I had enterprise-grade infrastructure running locally:

./bootstrap-piper-1.0.sh

Five minutes later, Temporalâ€™s workflow engine was humming, PostgreSQL was ready for data, Redis was caching nothing (but ready to cache everything), and Traefik was routing traffic like a champ.

Boring infrastructure is good infrastructure.

The first realÂ test

With domain models defined and infrastructure running, time for the moment of truth. Could this architecture actually process PM requests?

@app.post("/api/v1/intent")
async def process_intent(request: IntentRequest):
    # For now, just echo back with mock classification
    return {
        "intent": "CREATE_WORK_ITEM",
        "confidence": 0.95,
        "suggested_action": "Create a new work item",
        "domain": "execution"
    }

Not exactly AI-powered yet, but the shape was right. The domain concepts were driving the API, not the other way around.

Multi-laptop reality

Then came anotherreal test: could I work on this from both laptops?

The work laptop (kindbook) had everything set up. The personal laptop (faoilean)â€¦ did not.

# On personal laptop
git clone git@github.com:mediajunkie/piper-morgan-platform.git
Permission denied (publickey)

Different laptop. Different SSH keys. Different dance.

But once the authentication tango was done, something magical happened. Pull the code, run the bootstrap script, and boomâ€Šâ€”â€Šidentical development environment. The Docker approach was proving its worth.

The power ofÂ boring

By the end of the session, I had:

  • Domain models that actually modeled the domain
  • Infrastructure that just worked
  • Version control that (eventually) cooperated
  • A foundation ready for AI integration

No AI responses yet. No clever features. Just solid, boring, foundational work.

And thatâ€™s exactly what was needed. Boring gets the donuts made.

Lessons from my new DayÂ One

Starting over taught me:

  1. Domain models are your North Starâ€Šâ€”â€Šthey keep you oriented when the implementation gets messy
  2. SSH authentication is worth the painâ€Šâ€”â€Šbut document every step
  3. Minimal dependencies winâ€Šâ€”â€Šyou can always add more later
  4. Boring infrastructure is beautifulâ€Šâ€”â€Šexcitement should come from features, not ops
  5. Multi-machine development is a featureâ€Šâ€”â€Šdesign for it from day one

Next steps

With the foundation in place, it was time to make it smart. Real LLM integration was next. But thatâ€™s a story for another post.

For now, I had something more important than AI responses: I had an architecture that could grow without falling apart. The domain was driving the design. The infrastructure was invisible. The stage was set.

Sometimes the best AI work doesnâ€™t involve any AI at all.

078e056a87e4.subtitle: Yes, still June 1, 2025
078e056a87e4.content:
The $0 Bootstrap Stack: Building Enterprise Infrastructure for Free (With UpgradeÂ Paths)

Yes, still June 1, 2025

After deciding to rebuild Piper Morgan from scratch, I faced a classic dilemma: How do you build enterprise-grade infrastructure when your budget is exactly zero dollars?

The answer turned out to be a 300-line bash script and some strategic thinking about the future.

The price of â€œenterpriseâ€

Let me paint you a picture. A typical â€œenterpriseâ€ PM platform might run:

  • Auth0: $240/month
  • Datadog: $75/month after free tier
  • Pinecone: $70/month after free tier
  • Various other services: $200+/month

Total: $500â€“600/month before youâ€™ve written a line of business logic.

For a side project? Thatâ€™s a non-starter. But if working at startups taught me anything, it was that sometimes constraints force better decisions.

The philosophy

The key insight wasnâ€™t to find free alternatives to enterprise tools. It was to find free tools that could become enterprise tools. Every component needed a clear upgrade path.

Hereâ€™s what that looked like:

  • Keycloak (free) â†’ Auth0 ($240/month) when ready
  • ChromaDB (free) â†’ Pinecone ($70/month) for scale
  • Prometheus/Grafana (free) â†’ Datadog ($75/month) for convenience

The migration path was built in from day one. No vendor lock-in, just vendorâ€¦ anticipation?

The bootstrap script

What emerged was a massive bash script that would set up everything:

#!/bin/bash
# bootstrap-stack.sh - Complete setup for $0 budget Piper Morgan infrastructure
echo "ğŸš€ Setting up Piper Morgan Bootstrap Stack..."

This script created:

  • PostgreSQL for core data
  • Redis for caching and queues
  • Keycloak for authentication
  • ChromaDB for vector storage
  • Temporal for workflow orchestration
  • Prometheus/Grafana for monitoring
  • Traefik as API gateway

All running in Docker. All configured and ready. All free.

Hilarity ensues

Of course, nothing ever works on the first try. Remember those python environment issues from the last post? They had friends.

docker info
Cannot connect to the Docker daemon at 
unix:///Users/xian/.docker/run/docker.sock

Docker wasnâ€™t running. Such a simple thing, but there I was, troubleshooting connection errors when the real problem was I forgot to start Docker Desktop. Itâ€™s always the simple things that get you.

Then came the environment variables. You know that feeling when you realize youâ€™ve been debugging the wrong thing for an hour? That was me discovering myÂ .env file wasn't being loaded because I was starting in the wrong directory.

What this stack actuallyÂ does

Beyond saving $600/month, this bootstrap approach provided:

  1. Complete isolation: Everything runs in containers
  2. One-command setup: New developers can be up in minutes
  3. Production parity: The same stack works locally and in production
  4. Monitoring from day one: Not an afterthought

The monitoring deserves special mention. By starting with Prometheus and Grafana, I had visibility into everything from the beginning. When things broke (and oh, did they break), I could actually see why.

The hiddenÂ costs

â€œFreeâ€ doesnâ€™t mean â€œcheap.â€ This approach cost:

  • 2 weeks of setup time
  • Significant Docker expertise required
  • More operational complexity
  • No vendor support when things break

But hereâ€™s the thing: I was going to spend those 2 weeks debugging vendor integrations anyway. At least this way, I understood my entire stack.

â€œBuild vs. buyâ€ was one of the first business consulting clichÃ© phrases I learned back at Groundswell when the millennium was young. To this day itâ€™s a fraught choice. Do you buy and risk lock-in and escalating costs? Do you build (or fork) and end up with escalating maintenance costs, not to mention tons of time spent on things that are not in your core competence?

Since this is primarily a learning project for me, it was build all the way, baby!

The upgrade pathÂ magic

The real magic was in the upgrade paths. When you outgrow ChromaDBâ€™s free tier, switching to Pinecone is a configuration change, not a code rewrite. When you need Auth0â€™s enterprise features, Keycloak has prepared you for OIDC patterns.

Every â€œfreeâ€ choice was actually a â€œfree to startâ€ choice.

What IÂ learned

1f9581a41633.content:
The Architectural Reckoning: When Three Experts Agree You Should StartÂ Over

Still June 1, 2025

There I was, knee-deep in a proof-of-concept that mostly worked, when I decided to get a second opinion. And a third. What happened next taught me something important about knowing when to stop polishing and start over.

The setup

After building a functional POC that could create GitHub issues from natural language, I found myself at that familiar crossroads every developer knows: Do I refactor this into something production-ready, or do I throw it all away and start fresh?

The POC worked. It could:

  • Ingest PM documents into a vector database
  • Answer questions about them
  • Create GitHub issues with Claudeâ€™s help
  • Even review existing tickets

But something felt off. The code was getting messier with each feature. Imports were tangled. The architecture was emerging organically rather than being designed. Classic symptoms of a POC thatâ€™s overstayed its welcome.

Getting multiple perspectives

Hereâ€™s where it gets interesting. Instead of just asking Claude Opus (my usual architectural consultant), I decided to get multiple perspectives. I asked both Claude and Gemini to review my POC and propose architectures for â€œPiper Morgan 1.0.â€

Thenâ€Šâ€”â€Šand this is the key bitâ€Šâ€”â€ŠI had another Claude instance synthesize both proposals into a unified plan.

The consensus was unanimous: Start over.

The moment ofÂ clarity

â€œOK, so am I right in thinking that if I want to go ahead with this new synthesized plan that the other items we were discussing are effectively moot and/or will be subsumed or obviated in building â€˜Piper Morgan 1.0â€™ (vs 0.1)?â€

Claudeâ€™s response was instructive:

â€œYES, youâ€™re absolutely right! The current POC served its purpose brilliantlyâ€Šâ€”â€Šit proved the concept and revealed whatâ€™s needed. But pursuing the synthesized â€˜Piper Morgan 1.0â€™ plan meansâ€¦â€

What followed was a comprehensive list of everything that would become irrelevant:

  • Refactoring the POC
  • Fixing the Sonnet vs Opus confusion in current code
  • Restoring the broken Streamlit UI
  • Debugging the empty knowledge base context
  • That pesky milestone bug

All of it. Moot.

The architecture they all agreedÂ on

The proposed architecture was ambitious but grounded:

User Interfaces â†’ Conversation Layer â†’ Intelligence Engine 
â†’ Execution Layer â†’ Integration Layer â†’ Knowledge & Learning Layer

Key principles everyone agreed on:

  1. Domain-First Architecture: Start with rich PM domain models, not tool integrations
  2. Event-Driven Core: Enable real-time learning and asynchronous operations
  3. Plugin Everything: Every external system is a plugin from day one
  4. AI-Native Design: LLMs arenâ€™t just for text generationâ€Šâ€”â€Štheyâ€™re the reasoning engine
  5. Learning-Centric: Every interaction teaches the system something

The path notÂ taken

Claude laid out the choice beautifully:

Path A: Keep patching the POC (maybe 2â€“3 months before hitting a wall)
Â Path B: Build Piper Morgan 1.0 right (4â€“6 months to surpass POC functionality)

The thing is, when three different AI systems independently tell you to start over, and their reasoning all converges on the same architectural principles, you should probably listen.

(I also ran these plans by some of my senior colleagues for a sniff test. Mostly their reaction was that it looked enterprise-grade for a hobby project and that the documentation had the sort of thoroughness only AIs have the patience for.)

The comedyÂ begins

Of course, making the decision to start over was the easy part. Actually starting over? Thatâ€™s where things got interesting.

There was that time I tried to run streamlist instead of streamlit. Classic muscle memory fail. Then I discovered my Python environment was completely borked from moving directories. "Command not found: python" despite having (venv) in my prompt.

The virtual environment was activated but pointing to the wrong Python. Hours of debugging later, I learned that moving a project with an active venv is like trying to transplant a tree by just moving the leaves.

But these little frustrations were nothing compared to what was coming.

What I didÂ learn

Sometimes the bravest thing you can do is admit that your proof-of-concept has taught you everything it can teach you. The POCâ€™s job was to prove the concept and reveal the challenges. It did both brilliantly.

The mistake would have been trying to evolve it into something it was never meant to be. As Claude put it: â€œDonâ€™t polish a prototype when youâ€™re building the real thing.â€

The decisionÂ point

Looking back, this was the moment Piper Morgan transformed from an experiment into a real project. Not when I wrote the first line of code, not when the POC started working, but when I accepted that the POC needed to die for the platform to live.

The POC got me here. Now it was time to build the real thing.

All those tactical issues we were discussing? They just became irrelevant in the best possible wayâ€Šâ€”â€ŠI was building something better from the ground up.

13896a87b7a9.title: From Task Executor to Problem Solver
13896a87b7a9.subtitle: June 2, 2025
13896a87b7a9.content:
From Task Executor to ProblemÂ Solver

June 2, 2025

â€œCreate an issue for dark mode.â€ Thatâ€™s where we started. A simple command, a simple response. Click, boom, GitHub issue created. Useful? Sure. Game-changing? Hold your horses now, son.

But what if instead you could ask: â€œWhatâ€™s the potential impact of adding dark mode based on our user segments?â€ Or â€œHow does dark mode priority compare to the other UI improvements in our backlog?â€

Thatâ€™s the vision that made me burn down a working proof of concept and start over.

The limitations of task execution

The original Piper Morgan prototype was actually pretty good at what it did do. Give it a task, it executed. Need a GitHub issue? Done. Want to review a ticket? Helpful!

But this just scratches the surface. Even if it was able to handle all such tasks for me, the real PM workâ€Šâ€”â€Šthe analysis, the strategy, the judgment callsâ€Šâ€”â€Šthat was still all on me. And if Iâ€™m doing all the thinking anyway, how much time am I really saving?

On the other hand, I do want this thing to be able to get smarter and to play a more meaningful role in assisting me, so what to do? What to do?

â€œSuccessful prototype syndromeâ€

During those architectural reviews (remember those three AIs telling me to start over?), we discovered what I now call â€œsuccessful prototype syndrome.â€ The POC worked so well that I kept extending it, patching features onto a foundation that was never designed for the building I wanted to construct.

The breakthrough insight: task execution and strategic thinking arenâ€™t just different in degreeâ€Šâ€”â€Štheyâ€™re different in kind. You canâ€™t retrofit jazz improvisation onto a recipe-following system.

But, what if Piper Morgan could:

  • Analyze patterns across hundreds of tickets to surface insights nobody saw coming
  • Synthesize feedback from multiple channels into actionable recommendations
  • Generate strategic alternatives, not just execute predetermined tasks
  • Learn what works for your specific team and domain

Then my assistant would (someday be not just a task executor, but a thinking partner.

What strategic thinking actuallyÂ demands

Task execution needs simple patterns: â€œcreate ticketâ€ maps to GitHub API calls. Strategic thinking needs something fundamentally different:

  • Understanding relationships between concepts
  • Learning from patterns over time
  • Reasoning about trade-offs and alternatives
  • Orchestrating multiple types of analysis

The POC could handle the first one. The other three required starting over.

The philosophical shift

This isnâ€™t just about making AI smarterâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s about changing the relationship entirely. The POC approached every problem like this: â€œYou tell me what to do, Iâ€™ll do it faster than you could.â€

The platform approaches problems like this: â€œLet me understand what youâ€™re trying to accomplish, consider what we know about similar situations, and help you think through the best approach.â€

One is automation. The other is augmentation.

Iâ€™ve never loved the idea of replacing people with AI. Not just because itâ€™s usually a bad idea in specific, but because it feels wasteful on both ends. What I do love is giving people superpowers that enable them to focus on the things people do best.

Comedy interlude: the environment wars

While planning this ambitious rebuild, I was still fighting with my development environment. Remember those Python path issues? Theyâ€™d multiplied like rabbits in a particularly fertile warren.

At one point, I had Python 3.9 from macOS, Python 3.11 from Homebrew, Python 3.12 from somewhere I couldnâ€™t identify. The command which python returned different results depending on which terminal I used, what time of day it was, and possibly the phase of the moon.

I considered keeping a notebook just for â€œwhich Python am I using now?â€ I imagined entries looked like archaeological field notes: â€œTerminal 2, Tuesday afternoon: Python 3.11. Same terminal, Wednesday morning: Python 3.9. Cause unknown. Recommend ritual cleansing.â€

Building the new foundation

On June 2, we started fresh. Instead of patching the POC, I spent eight hours building Piper Morgan 1.0 from scratch with lessons learned.

The new architecture puts PM domain conceptsâ€Šâ€”â€ŠProducts, Features, Stakeholdersâ€Šâ€”â€Šat the center, not tool integrations. GitHub, Jira, and Slack become plugins in a system that understands product management workflows natively.

We prepared to build a proper infrastructure stack: PostgreSQL for relational data, Redis for caching, ChromaDB for vector embeddings, Temporal for workflow orchestration. All running in Docker Compose for a $0 software budget with clear upgrade paths.

The domain-first breakthrough

The key insight was starting with PM domain models instead of just hackin together API integrations willy-nilly. When you define Intent, Product, Feature, and Stakeholder as first-class entities, everything becomes clearer.

The system understands that creating a feature might involve GitHub issues, Slack notifications, and documentation updatesâ€Šâ€”â€Šbut those are implementation details, not the core workflow.

By June 2, we had working domain models, a FastAPI server with real intent classification, and an orchestration engine that could execute multi-step workflows. The AI was achieving 0.95 confidence scores on classifying EXECUTION, ANALYSIS, and STRATEGY intents.

(Thatâ€™s good!)

The realityÂ check

But letâ€™s be honest about what actually works versus what weâ€™re building toward. As of June 2:

âœ… What actually works:

  • Intent classification that understands PM language
  • Multi-step workflow orchestration with context passing
  • Database persistence of workflow results
  • Plugin architecture foundation

ğŸ”„ What weâ€™re still building:

  • The strategic analysis capabilities I described above
  • Cross-project pattern recognition
  • Learning from outcomes over time
  • The kind of insights that would actually surprise me

The foundation is solid, but weâ€™re maybe 30% toward the thinking partner vision.

Making itÂ real

Of course, vision is cheap. Implementation is expensive. The new architecture required components that could learn, reason, and connect insights across interactions.

Instead of simple request-response patterns, we needed systems that could:

  • Maintain context across multiple conversation turns
  • Connect current requests to historical patterns
  • Reason about trade-offs using product management principles
  • Learn from outcomes to improve future recommendations

Each component had to be built with learning in mind. The intent understanding system didnâ€™t just categorize requestsâ€Šâ€”â€Šit captured nuance and ambiguity. The workflow engine didnâ€™t just execute stepsâ€Šâ€”â€Šit recorded decision points and outcomes for future reference.

What strategic thinking actuallyÂ means

Hereâ€™s an example of the difference in approaches. Instead of:

User: â€œCreate a ticket for improving search performanceâ€
Old Piper: Creates ticket with basic template

The new system is designed to engage like this:

User: â€œCreate a ticket for improving search performanceâ€
New Piper:

Iâ€™ve been analyzing recent user feedback and noticed search performance complaints have increased 40% since last sprint, primarily from mobile users. This correlates with the recent search index expansion.
I see three possible approaches:
Quick optimization of current algorithm (2 days, ~20% improvement)
Implement caching layer (1 week, ~60% improvement)
Full search infrastructure redesign (3 weeks, ~90% improvement)
Based on your Q3 roadmap and the mobile app launch timing, Iâ€™d recommend option 2. Should I create tickets for the caching implementation with specific subtasks for cache warming and invalidation strategies?

Thatâ€™s not just faster execution. Thatâ€™s strategic partnership.

What this enables (eventually)

With the new architecture, we can build toward that strategic thinking partner. We wonâ€™t get there in one hop, but the foundation can support it.

The domain models let us reason about PM concepts. The orchestration engine can chain together different types of analysis. The persistence layer captures enough context to enable learning over time.

But transforming â€œcreate a ticket for search performanceâ€ into a strategic conversation about user impact, resource allocation, and alternative approaches? Thatâ€™s still ahead of us.

Looking forward

The task executor is deadâ€Šâ€”â€Šwe buried it on June 2. The thinking partner is being born, but itâ€™s still early days. Each week we add capabilities that move us closer to real strategic collaboration.

The difference is that now we have an architecture that can get us there, instead of one that was fighting us every step of the way.

Sometimes you have to burn down something good to build something great.

The Question That Started Everything

The state of AI tooling (May 2025Â edition)

  • OpenAIâ€™s GPTsâ€Šâ€”â€Šâ€œEasy to start with, limited but good for testing conceptsâ€
  • Anthropicâ€™s Claude via APIâ€Šâ€”â€Šâ€œYou can build custom workflows using Claudeâ€™s API,â€ said Claude
  • LangChain/LangSmithâ€Šâ€”â€Šâ€œPopular framework for building AI applicationsâ€

Iâ€™d tried OpenAIâ€™s GPTs of course. Who hadnâ€™t? I even had an API key already but hadnâ€™t built anything with it yet. ChatGPT always felt like having an intern who forgot everything the moment they left the room.

The requirements emerge

That recommendation would set the course for everything that followed. Not because it was perfect (spoiler: weâ€™d eventually switch to Anthropicâ€™s Claude API), but because it was specific. Actionable. A starting point.

The moment before theÂ moment

  • This blog series

But in that moment, I was â€œjust askinâ€™ questionsâ€ and wondering â€œhow hard could it really be?â€ especially when you remember that I am a mere product manager, and not a programmer.

What I didnâ€™t knowÂ then

I didnâ€™t know that:

  • The first prototype would work just well enough to be dangerous
  • Weâ€™d throw it all away and start over (the best decision weâ€™d make)
  • Environment setup would become a running joke

The realÂ insight

Looking back, the genius wasnâ€™t in the architecture Claude proposed or the tools it recommended. The genius was in taking a vague desire (â€œI want an AI assistantâ€) and turning it into a specific plan with concrete next steps.

4c04e304a3a7.title: Building AI That Actually Thinks About Product Work
4c04e304a3a7.subtitle: June 2, 2025
4c04e304a3a7.content:
Building AI That Actually Thinks About ProductÂ Work

June 2, 2025

Iâ€™ve explained why we burned down a working prototype to build something more ambitious. Now letâ€™s talk about what it means to build an AI that understands product management workâ€Šâ€”â€Šand what â€œunderstandingâ€ really means when youâ€™re eight hours into a development session and still debugging environment variables.

The LLM integration reality

June 2 started with grand ambitions and ended with a working system, but the path between wasâ€¦ instructive.

First challenge: getting the AI to work at all. The old POC had mock responses everywhere. We needed real LLM integration that could handle different types of PM thinking with different AI models.

The implementation reality involved discovering that environment variables donâ€™t load automatically and getting familiar with error messages like â€œNo ANTHROPIC_API_KEY foundâ€ despite having a perfectly goodÂ .env file.

Pro tip: add load_dotenv() before imports that use environmental variables.

Task-based model selection (when itÂ works)

The breakthrough concept was treating different cognitive tasks differently. Intent classification needs speed and consistencyâ€Šâ€”â€Štemperature 0.3, fast model. Strategic reasoning needs creativity and depthâ€Šâ€”â€Šhigher temperature, more powerful model.

We built this as explicit configuration:

# Different models for different thinking types
SONNET_FOR_CLASSIFICATION = "claude-3-sonnet-20240229"
OPUS_FOR_REASONING = "claude-3-opus-20240229"

When it worked, the intent classifier was hitting 0.95 confidence scores on test cases. Thatâ€™s the kind of accuracy that makes you think â€œokay, maybe this AI thing has potential.â€

The orchestration insight

Hereâ€™s where it gets interesting. Product management isnâ€™t really about individual tasksâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s about workflows where each step informs the next.

We built this as an explicit design principle: context flows forward through multi-step processes. When analyzing a feature request, the insights from understanding user needs should inform requirement extraction, which should influence technical constraint analysis.

By the end of June 2, we had a working orchestration engine that could execute workflows like:

  1. Analyze request â†’ 2. Extract requirements â†’ 3. Create work item

Each step used AI analysis and passed rich context to the next step. Not just textâ€Šâ€”â€Šstructured data about stakeholders, assumptions, risks, and success criteria.

What â€œunderstanding PM workâ€ reallyÂ means

Let me be clear about what we built versus what weâ€™re working toward.

What actually worked as of June 2:

  • Natural language intent classification for PM requests
  • Multi-step workflow orchestration with context preservation
  • AI-powered analysis at each workflow step
  • Database persistence of workflow results

What weâ€™re still figuring out:

  • Whether the AIâ€™s analysis is actually insightful or just well-formatted
  • How to capture feedback to improve recommendations over time
  • Pattern recognition across different projects and teams

The system can execute a workflow that looks intelligent. Whether itâ€™s actually intelligentâ€¦ thatâ€™s harder to measure.

Domain modeling: the unglamorous foundation

The real work wasnâ€™t the AIâ€Šâ€”â€Šit was modeling PM concepts properly. We spent hours defining what a Feature actually is versus a WorkItem versus a Product. Boring? Yes. Essential? Absolutely.

When you define these relationships clearly, the AI can reason about them:

  • Features belong to Products
  • WorkItems implement Features
  • Stakeholders care about Products
  • Decisions affect multiple Features

This isnâ€™t just data modelingâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s teaching the system the vocabulary of product management.

The circular dependency dance

Around hour 6 of the June 2 session, we hit our first major architectural challenge: circular dependencies. The database layer needed workflow types, the orchestration needed database repositories, and Python was not having it.

This is actually a classic sign that a system is growing from prototype to platform. The solution revealed an important design principle: shared vocabulary, independent implementation.

We extracted shared enumerations (IntentCategory, WorkflowType) into a common module. Every service speaks the same language about PM concepts, but implements its own concerns independently.

The solution to the circular imports problem? Creating a shared_types.py file in the services directory.

When AI meetsÂ reality

The most humbling moment came when testing the end-to-end workflow. Everything looked perfect in theory. The AI classified intents correctly. The orchestration engine routed them properly. The database persisted results.

But the actual AI analysis? Generic and obvious. â€œThis feature request requires stakeholder alignment and technical investigation.â€ Well, yes. Thatâ€™s true of most feature requests.

The system was working mechanically but not intellectually. Weâ€™d built the plumbing for intelligence without the intelligence itself.

Integration philosophy: PM conceptsÂ first

One insight from the June 2 session: every external system must be a plugin. We caught ourselves designing GitHub-centric workflows (a habit inherited from the prototype) and had to course-correct.

The system thinks in PM concepts first: Features, Stakeholders, Decisions. Whether those map to GitHub issues, Jira tickets, or Notion pages is an implementation detail.

This matters because tools change constantly. The AIâ€™s understanding of product management concepts should be stable even when your team switches from GitHub to Linear.

The testing realityÂ check

By the end of June 2, we had working code, but working code that hadnâ€™t been stress-tested. The intent classifier achieved high confidence on our test cases, but test cases written by the same person who built the system arenâ€™t exactly unbiased.

The orchestration engine executed our demo workflow successfully, but weâ€™d only tested the happy path. What happens when the AI returns malformed JSON? When the database connection fails mid-workflow? When someone asks for something the system has never seen before?

It â€œworkedâ€ but it was super brittle.

What we learned about AI development speed

Eight hours on June 2 produced more working code than a weeks of iterating on the POC. Not because we got faster at coding, but because we stopped fighting the architecture.

When the foundation matches your goals, everything builds naturally. When it doesnâ€™t, every feature is a hack.

The new system let us add capabilities instead of patching problems.

Current status: promising foundation

As of June 2, we had:

  • Real AI integration (no more mocks)
  • Working multi-step workflows
  • Database persistence
  • Plugin architecture foundation
  • Domain models that make sense

What we didnâ€™t have:

  • Genuinely insightful AI analysis
  • Learning from user feedback
  • Cross-project pattern recognition
  • The strategic thinking capabilities that justified burning down the POC

The foundation is solid. The building is just getting started.

d9f839597278.subtitle: (End of) June 2, 2025
d9f839597278.content:
Persistence of Memory: AI Canâ€™t Learn withoutÂ It

(End of) June 2, 2025

Thereâ€™s a moment in every AI project when you realize the difference between intelligence and memory. Intelligence can solve problems. Memory can learn from solutions. Todayâ€™s story is about trying to give Piper Morgan the ability to rememberâ€Šâ€”â€Šand discovering that persistence is more complicated than â€œjust add a database.â€

The persistence problem

As of June 2, every conversation with Piper Morgan started from scratch. The intent classifier could achieve 0.95 confidence on PM requests, and the orchestration engine could execute multi-step workflows with context passing. But ask about a similar request the next day? Complete amnesia.

This was like having a brilliant consultant who gets a concussion between every meeting. Helpful in the moment, useless for building on previous insights.

The obvious solution was persistence. The less obvious challenge was figuring out what to persist.

The first attempt: store everything

My initial instinct was to save workflow results. User asks for feature analysis, AI generates recommendations, database stores the output. Simple enough.

But this approach treats AI interactions like static documents instead of dynamic learning opportunities. You get a historical record, not accumulated wisdom.

My LLM advisor suggested we shifted focus from storing outputs to storing the reasoning process itself.

Database design: domain models driveÂ schema

The earlier June 2 session had laid important groundwork here. Instead of generic â€œAI_interactionsâ€ tables, we modeled PM concepts as first-class database entities:

Products with features and stakeholdersÂ 
WorkItems that can map to any external system
Workflows that capture the complete analysis processÂ 
Events that track every decision and outcome

This isnâ€™t just better data modelingâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s teaching the database to think in PM concepts.

The repository pattern revelation

Rather than scattering database queries throughout the codebase, we implemented a repository pattern. Every domain concept gets its own repository with clean CRUD (Create, Read, Update, and Delete) operations.

This sounds like developer inside baseball, but it matters for AI memory. When the system needs to find â€œsimilar feature requests,â€ itâ€™s querying ProductRepository.find_similar(), not writing raw SQL scattered across different services.

The abstraction means we can later add sophisticated similarity search without changing how the rest of the system requests data.

What weâ€™re actually persisting

The current system captures:

  • Complete workflow executions with timing and context
  • AI decision points including confidence levels and alternatives considered
  • User interactions mapped to PM domain concepts
  • Cross-workflow relationships between related requests

But hereâ€™s what weâ€™re not capturing yet:

  • Outcome data (did the feature actually get built? how did it perform?)
  • User feedback on AI recommendations (were they helpful? accurate?)
  • Pattern improvements (learning from what works vs what doesnâ€™t)

The foundation supports these capabilities, but we havenâ€™t built the feedback loops yet.

The testingÂ reality

By the end of June 2, database persistence was working mechanically. Workflows got saved, domain entities had proper relationships, the repository pattern kept data access clean.

But we discovered something important: persistence without validation is just organized data hoarding. Weâ€™d successfully saved workflow results but hadnâ€™t verified that saving them actually enabled better future recommendations.

SQLAlchemy insights (the technical bits)

Some discoveries from the June 2 database implementation:

back_populates creates bidirectional relationships automatically. Set feature.product = X and SQLAlchemy adds the feature to X.features without explicit code.

JSON columns enable schema evolution. Instead of adding new database columns every time we expand PM concepts, we use JSON fields for flexible data that can evolve over time.

Async all the way. Using asyncpg with SQLAlchemyâ€™s async support enables non-blocking database operations. Critical when the AI is processing multiple workflows concurrently.

Note: I came to loath the string â€œasyncioâ€ as I tended to see it when tests were failing and it started to feel like we kept fixing async issues all the time. â€œAy-sink-ee-oh!â€ I would groan again, like some sort of demented bizarro bingo player.

The compound learning vision (not yetÂ reality)

The goal is compound learning: each interaction teaches the system something about how product work actually happens in your context. After analyzing dozens of feature requests, the AI should recognize patterns like â€œrequests from the enterprise team typically have hidden compliance requirements.â€

Thatâ€™s the vision. The current reality is more humble: we can store workflow results and query them later. The pattern recognition and insight generation? Still on the roadmap.

Current capabilities vs futureÂ promises

What actually worked as of June 2:

  • Structured persistence of workflow executions
  • Database queries for historical workflow data
  • Proper PM domain modeling in the database
  • Repository pattern for clean data access

What we were building toward:

  • Learning from workflow outcomes
  • Pattern recognition across similar requests
  • Feedback incorporation to improve recommendations
  • Cross-project insight generation

The architecture supports the vision, but weâ€™re maybe 20% of the way to genuine learning.

The late-night architecture insight

Some of the best discoveries happen during those late coding sessions when your critical brain is tired. Around 11 PM during the June 2 session, I made a decision that turned out to be crucial: store the uncertainty too.

When the AI classifies an intent with 0.95 confidence, save that confidence level. When it considers multiple workflow options, save the alternatives it didnâ€™t choose. When it makes assumptions, capture what those assumptions were.

This creates a research dataset about AI decision-making that could be incredibly valuable for improving the system over time.

The debugging reality

The June 2 session ended with working persistence but some unresolved circular import issues in the orchestration layer. Classic software development: you solve one problem and discover two more.

But the foundation was solid. The domain models felt right, the repository pattern kept data access clean, and the database schema could evolve as our understanding of PM concepts deepened.

What persistence actuallyÂ enables

With working database persistence, future versions of Piper Morgan could:

Resume interrupted workflows: â€œWe were analyzing that payment feature before the weekend. Hereâ€™s where we left off.â€

Reference historical decisions: â€œThe last time we worked on mobile performance, these three approaches worked best.â€

Track pattern evolution: â€œEnterprise feature requests have gotten 40% more complex over the last quarter.â€

But thatâ€™s conditional on building the learning loops that turn stored data into accumulated wisdom.

The honest assessment

Giving AI memory is like giving someone a library card. The potential is enormous, but the value depends on what they do with access to all that information.

Weâ€™ve built the library. The AI can check out books. Whether it becomes genuinely smarter over timeâ€¦ that depends on capabilities we havenâ€™t built yet.

But the foundation is in place. Every workflow execution is captured. Every decision point is logged. When weâ€™re ready to build learning algorithms, weâ€™ll have the data to train them on.
