117b25fa6bae.title: Digging Out of the Complexity Hole
117b25fa6bae.subtitle: June 17â€“18, 2025
117b25fa6bae.content:
Digging Out of the Complexity Hole

June 17â€“18, 2025

â€œI want us digging back out of this hole, not deeper into it.â€

That was my plea to Claude halfway through what had started as a simple multi-project support implementation and had somehow devolved into a 30-hour debugging marathon involving duplicate domain models, broken import chains, and the kind of architectural confusion that makes you question everything you thought you knew about your own codebase.

This is the story of what happens when complexity compounds faster than your ability to manage it, and how systematic recovery sometimes requires admitting youâ€™ve been digging in the wrong direction.

When simple features arenâ€™tÂ simple

PM-009 was supposed to be straightforward: add multi-project support so users could work with different repositories without manually specifying which one every time. We had patterns established, domain models in place, a test suite written. How hard could it be?

Famous last words.

The first sign something was wrong came when our migration script couldnâ€™t figure out which Project class to import. Turns out we'd accidentally created two completely separate model hierarchies: services.domain.models.Project and services.database.models.Project.

Both were called Project. Both served similar purposes. Neither knew the other existed.

The architectural awakening moment

â€œGlad I checked. It is already not a good â€˜scentâ€™ that we are chasing bugs on this script. It makes me wonder where we were not careful enough to begin with.â€

That was my moment of recognizing we werenâ€™t dealing with simple bugsâ€Šâ€”â€Šwe were dealing with architectural sloppiness that had been accumulating without anyone noticing.

Sometimes the most productive thing you can do is stop trying to make broken architecture work and start figuring out why itâ€™s broken in the first place.

When test-driven development meetsÂ reality

Hereâ€™s what made the situation particularly frustrating: weâ€™d been following test-driven development principles religiously for the earlier tickets. Write tests first, implement to pass the tests, refactor carefully. It had worked beautifully through PM-008.

But PM-009 was different. Complex business logic, multi-layer coordination, multiple decision paths. And somewhere in that complexity, weâ€™d abandoned TDD discipline without realizing it.

I should have instructed by assistants to read the test specifications carefully and implemented exactly what the tests expected, but instead they guessed at method names and signatures, and then we spent hours debugging why our llm.infer_project_id() calls didn't match the llm.complete() methods the tests were mocking

The tests werenâ€™t wrong. Our implementation was wrong. But weâ€™d been so focused on making the code work that weâ€™d stopped paying attention to what the tests were actually telling us.

The duplicate models anti-pattern

The root cause of our architectural confusion was hiding in plain sight: weâ€™d created two separate Project classes because an earlier example had shown the structure but not the naming conventions.

# What we accidentally built:
services.domain.models.Project      # Pure business logic
services.database.models.Project    # SQLAlchemy persistence

# What we should have built:
services.domain.models.Project      # Pure business logic  
services.database.models.ProjectDB  # SQLAlchemy persistence

Seems obvious in retrospect, right? But when youâ€™re deep in implementation mode, small naming decisions can have huge architectural consequences.

By the way, usually when I write â€œwe realizedâ€ or â€œwe discoveredâ€ here, what I really mean is that this was happening in collaboration with Claude as my architectural thinking partner. But the moment of stepping back and saying â€œwait, why do we have two Project classes?â€â€Šâ€”â€Šthat came from forcing myself to slow down and actually look at what weâ€™d built instead of continuing to patch symptoms.

The cost of violating TDD discipline

The most sobering discovery was realizing how far weâ€™d drifted from test-driven development without noticing.

Six test failures, all from method signature mismatches. Six opportunities to recognize we werenâ€™t following our own process. And weâ€™d been interpreting each failure as â€œsomethingâ€™s wrong with the environmentâ€ instead of â€œsomethingâ€™s wrong with our approach.â€

Complex features donâ€™t need less disciplineâ€Šâ€”â€Šthey need more discipline. But complexity has a way of making you feel like you donâ€™t have time for proper process.

The systematic recoveryÂ approach

Once we recognized we were digging deeper instead of climbing out, we took a systematic approach to recovery:

Step 1: Stop patching symptoms No more â€œquick fixesâ€ to make individual tests pass. No more environment tweaks to work around import issues.

Step 2: Fix the root architectural problem Renamed Project â†’ ProjectDB in the database layer, added explicit to_domain() and from_domain() mapping methods.

Step 3: Follow the tests exactly Changed method calls to match what the tests were expecting, not what we thought made sense.

Step 4: Verify the foundation Made sure basic imports and database connections worked before attempting business logic.

The recovery wasnâ€™t glamorous. It was mostly mechanical refactoring and careful attention to details weâ€™d been glossing over. But it worked.

An architectural lesson aboutÂ examples

One insight from the recovery was how architectural examples can mislead if theyâ€™re not complete.

Weâ€™d been following an example that showed the structure of domain and database models but didnâ€™t specify the naming conventions. So we created two Project classes instead of what we eventually eneded up with, a domain class called Project and database class called ProjectDB.

Good examples donâ€™t just show structureâ€Šâ€”â€Šthey show naming, relationships, and boundaries. Incomplete examples can be more dangerous than no examples at all.

Ancknowledging complexity

Iâ€™ve already made it clear that I find things complex enough as they are and strive to avoid adding any optional complexity, but there comes a time when you need to recognize that some things worth making are by necessity complex.

Once we were on an even keel. I commented â€œOK it makes sense that things have gotten harder and more complex. (whew)â€

That was my moment of accepting that PM-009 represented a genuine complexity jump from the earlier tickets. Not just more code, but more kinds of complexity:

  • Business logic complexity: Multiple decision paths for project resolution
  • Integration complexity: Coordinating between domain models, repositories, and LLM calls
  • State management complexity: Session-based project memory across user interactions

Complexity isnâ€™t a failureâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s a natural progression as systems grow. But complexity requires acknowledging its presence and adapting your process accordingly.

When architectural refactoring pays off immediately

The moment we fixed the duplicate models issue, everything started working. Not â€œsort of workingâ€ or â€œworking with workaroundsâ€â€Šâ€”â€Šactually working the way it was supposed to.

# After the refactor, imports became obvious:
from services.domain.models import Project        # Business logic
from services.database.models import ProjectDB    # Persistence

# Mapping became explicit:
project = project_db.to_domain()                  # Clean conversion
project_db = ProjectDB.from_domain(project)       # Clear direction

This is what clean architecture gets you: when you fix the foundation, everything else becomes easier.

The test environment archaeology

Part of our debugging odyssey involved figuring out why our test environment had become unstable. The discovery process was like archaeology:

  • Layer 1: pytest-asyncio version incompatibility
  • Layer 2: Import path inconsistencies with shared_types
  • Layer 3: NumPy 2.0 compatibility issues in ChromaDB dependencies

(Oh, NumPy compatibility issues, you numpty! I just canâ€™t quit you.)

Each layer revealed assumptions weâ€™d made about the environment that were no longer true. Each fix revealed the next layer of issues.

Environment issues can mask architectural problems, making you think the problem is with your setup when itâ€™s actually with your code.

The multi-AI coordination reality

One surprising aspect of this stage of development was that discovery that even with multiple AI assistants providing review and guidance, we could still all drift into architectural anti-patterns together.

  • Claude Opus: Architecture review and pattern recognition
  • Claude Sonnet: Detailed implementation planning
  • Cursor Copilot: Code execution and syntax assistance

Multiple perspectives, multiple checks, and we still ended up with duplicate domain models.

AI collaboration doesnâ€™t eliminate the need for architectural disciplineâ€Šâ€”â€Šit just distributes it across more participants.

The business-logic debugging phase

Once we had clean architecture, we could focus on the actual business-logic bugs:

  1. Inference vs. last-used logic: When LLM inference conflicts with session memory
  2. Default project confirmation: Whether users need to confirm obvious defaults
  3. Ambiguous project handling: How to handle â€œUNCLEARâ€ responses from LLM
  4. Missing project errors: Proper error types for non-existent projects

These were the bugs we should have been debugging from the start. But architectural confusion had made it impossible to isolate business logic issues from infrastructure issues.

Clean architecture creates clean debugging.

The 10/16 recovery milestone

â€œ10/16 tests passing (major improvement from 2/16)â€

That was our recovery milestone. Not perfect, but systematic progress in the right direction. From nearly complete failure to clear success, with specific remaining issues that had clear solutions.

Sometimes the most important measure isnâ€™t how many tests are passingâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s whether youâ€™re making systematic progress or continuing to accumulate problems.

Discovering documentation debt

The architectural refactoring revealed that our documentation was describing a system that didnâ€™t match what weâ€™d actually built. Domain models that werenâ€™t properly separated, import patterns that had evolved beyond recognition, test strategies that assumed simpler architecture.

Weâ€™d made a big effort at documentation, used that to power through the first nine github issues, and along the way forgot to update the docs to capture ongoing decisions and changes. Now they were pretty stale.

This is how technical debt compounds: inconsistent code leads to inconsistent documentation, which leads to incorrect assumptions in future development.

Good documentation isnâ€™t just helpfulâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s a forcing function for architectural clarity.

A lesson about stopping versus pushingÂ through

The most important lesson from the complexity hole was about knowing when to stop pushing forward and start digging back.

Signs youâ€™re pushing forward: Making progress on intended features, tests passing, clear next steps

Signs youâ€™re digging deeperÂ : Fighting the same issues repeatedly, accumulating workarounds, architectural confusion

The temptation when youâ€™re deep in a complex implementation is to keep pushing until you break through. But sometimes the breakthrough requires changing direction entirely.

The tension between systematic andÂ tactical

Throughout the session, there was constant tension between systematic approaches and tactical fixes. Cursor would unfailingly recommend or (even just go ahead and start making!) quick fixes to get the tests to pass, and I had to keep telling it to stop as systematically dug into the root causes.

Tactical approaches feel faster in the moment. Systematic approaches are faster over time. But when youâ€™re in the middle of complexity, itâ€™s hard to trust that systematic work will pay off.

The recovery proved that systematic approaches workâ€Šâ€”â€Šthey just require faith during the implementation.

Architectural discipline paysÂ off

By the end of the 30-hour session, we had:

  • Clean separation between domain and database models
  • Explicit mapping patterns that prevented future confusion
  • Test environment that worked reliably
  • Business logic bugs that were isolated and fixable

None of this was glamorous work. Most of it was cleaning up mistakes weâ€™d made earlier in the session. But it created the foundation for everything that came after.

This recovery work enabled the systematic implementation successes that (spoiler!) were to follow in the next weeks.

Managing complexity

What I learned from digging out of the complexity hole is that complexity management isnâ€™t about avoiding complexityâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s about managing it systematically.

Good complexity management: Acknowledging complexity, adapting process, maintaining discipline

Bad complexity management: Pretending complexity doesnâ€™t exist, abandoning process, accumulating technical debt

Complex features require more discipline, not less. But when youâ€™re drowning in complexity, discipline feels like a luxury you canâ€™t afford.

When recovery becomesÂ learning

The most unexpected outcome of the complexity hole was how much we learned about our own system architecture. The debugging process forced us to understand relationships and dependencies weâ€™d been taking for granted.

Sometimes you donâ€™t really understand your architecture until you break it and have to fix it systematically.

Learning to dig out of these complexity holes systematically has enabled us to recognize and address technical debt before it becomes overwhelming.

34c725384254.title: Successful Prototype Syndrome
34c725384254.subtitle: June 19, 2025
34c725384254.content:
Successful Prototype Syndrome

June 19, 2025

I was fresh off fixing our architectural drift issues and digging out of the PM-009 complexity hole and starting to feel like weâ€™d learned our lessons about systematic development. Time to add some query functionalityâ€Šâ€”â€Šjust a simple â€œlist projectsâ€ feature. How hard could it be? (Spoiler: this feature was still not yet working a month later, but letâ€™s not get ahead of ourselves).

Then I tried to implement it using our existing workflow orchestration system and realized we were trying to force a data-fetching operation through an architecture designed for state-changing commands. If that all sounds like gibberish to you, trust me. Itâ€™s not good.

Thatâ€™s when I discovered we had become the victims of something I may have mentioned already, â€œsuccessful Prototype Syndromeâ€â€Šâ€”â€Šwhen your proof-of-concept works so well that you donâ€™t notice itâ€™s become an architectural straightjacket.

When success becomes constraint

Our workflow orchestration system was beautiful. Task-based architecture, clean separation of concerns, perfect for complex operations like â€œcreate GitHub issueâ€ or â€œanalyze uploaded file.â€ Users could say things in natural language, weâ€™d classify their intent, route it through the appropriate workflow, and execute a series of coordinated tasks.

It worked so well that weâ€™d started putting everything through it, without really even thinking about it.

But when a user asks â€œwhat projects do I have access to?â€ theyâ€™re not requesting a workflow. Theyâ€™re asking a question. And questions have different architectural requirements than commands.

The CQRS revelation

The breakthrough came when I realized we were trying to force queries through a command architecture: Commands change the state of things (creat a task, upload a file, save settings). Queries fetch data for you (list my projects, show the analytics, search for documents).

Commands need orchestration, error handling, rollback capabilities, audit trails. Queries need speed, caching, read optimization, simple error responses.

Weâ€™d built an excellent command system and then tried to make it handle queries too. Like using a Formula 1 race car for grocery shoppingâ€Šâ€”â€Štechnically possible, but missing the point entirely.

The moment of recognizing that â€œlist projectsâ€ felt awkward because it wasnâ€™t a workflow came from trying to implement something simple and feeling the architectural resistance.

The prototype successÂ trap

Hereâ€™s what I learned about successful prototypes: they can become victims of their own success. Our workflow system worked so well for complex operations that weâ€™d started assuming it was the right approach for all operations.

The prototype had solved one problem beautifully. Weâ€™d unconsciously decided it should solve all problems. Success can be as dangerous as failure if it prevents you from recognizing when you need different approaches.

The architectural forcingÂ function

Trying to implement â€œlist projectsâ€ through our workflow system revealed several forcing functions that didnâ€™t make sense for simple queries:

  • Intent classification: Why does â€œwhat projects do I have?â€ need sophisticated NLP?
  • Task orchestration: Why does a database query need multi-step coordination?
  • Workflow persistence: Why are we storing â€œlist projectsâ€ requests as permanent workflow records?
  • Error handling complexity: Why does a read operation need rollback capabilities?

Each individual piece worked correctly. Together, they were architectural overkill for a simple data fetch.

A queryÂ service

The solution emerged once we stopped trying to fit queries into command architecture:

# Command path (complex state changes):
Intent â†’ Workflow â†’ Orchestration â†’ Tasks â†’ Results

# Query path (simple data fetches):
Intent â†’ Query Service â†’ Repository â†’ Results

Queries could bypass the entire orchestration layer and go directly to repositories. Faster, simpler, more appropriate complexity.

Sometimes the best architecture is the architecture you donâ€™t need.

Growing documentation debt

Implementing the query service revealed another layer of â€œSuccessful Prototype Syndromeâ€: our documentation was describing the system weâ€™d built, not the system we needed.

Every API endpoint went through workflows. Every user interaction required orchestration. Every feature was designed around the command pattern because thatâ€™s what our prototype had implemented successfully.

But a production system needs multiple interaction patterns, not just one really good one.

The â€œSuccessful Prototype Syndromeâ€ pattern

Once I recognized the pattern, I could see it everywhere in software development:

  • Authentication: â€œJWT tokens work great for API access, so letâ€™s use them for everythingâ€
  • Caching: â€œRedis solved our performance problem, so letâ€™s cache everything in Redisâ€
  • Messaging: â€œKafka handles our event streaming beautifully, so letâ€™s put all inter-service communication through Kafkaâ€

The successful prototype becomes the hammer that makes every problem look like a nail.

The three-tier collaboration effectiveness

What made this architecture session productive was our established collaboration pattern:

Claude Opus (Architecture): High-level pattern recognition and system design.Â 
Claude Sonnet (Implementation): Detailed planning and step-by-step guidance.Â 
Cursor Assistant (Execution): Code generation and syntax assistance

Each layer contributed its strengths without trying to do everything. Unlike our earlier drift experiences, this collaboration stayed within clear boundaries.

The documentation-first breakthrough

One of the most productive decisions was tackling documentation before implementation. We created ten comprehensive architecture documents:

  • Architecture Overview
  • Technical Architecture
  • Data Model Document
  • API Design Specification
  • Pattern Catalog
  • Development Guidelines
  • Implementation Roadmap
  • Test Strategy
  • Dependency Diagrams
  • Migration Guide

Documentation-first forced us to think through the query vs. command distinction before building it. And, honestly, if thereâ€™s one thing bots can do itâ€™s write excruciatingly boring but detailed and accurate docs.

The CQRS-lite implementation

We implemented something called â€œCQRS-liteâ€â€Šâ€”â€Šthe essential separation without full event sourcing complexity:

Command side: Workflows, orchestration, complex error handling, audit trails
Query side: Direct repository access, simple error responses, optimized for speed

Not full CQRS with event sourcing and eventual consistency, but enough separation to prevent architectural confusion.

Sometimes you donâ€™t need the full patternâ€Šâ€”â€Šjust the insight that drives the pattern.

Error-handling maturity

Implementing query services also forced us to mature our error handling beyond prototype-level responses:

Our prototype returned error messages only an engineer could love, code numbers, nothing actionable. Our production errors are still no paragons of user experience but at least they respect HTTP status codes (422/404/200) and provide actionable user messages.

Queries exposed error-handling gaps that complex workflows had been masking through their comprehensive exception management. These generic error message made the debugging twice as hard!

Simple operations revealed the need for simple, clear error communication.

Performance vs. complexity

The query service implementation taught me about the relationship between performance and architectural complexity:

Complex operations like most commands achieve performance through optimization, caching, and async processing. Simple operations such as queries gain performance through architectural simplicity

Weâ€™d been optimizing our workflow system for complex operations. But sometimes the best optimization is avoiding unnecessary complexity entirely.

AI system evolution

One insight from this session was recognizing that AI systems require different architectural thinking than traditional software. More of that fuzziness. Where traditional software is deterministic, can be scaled predictably, tends to have relatively stable interfaces, AI-using software seems to require ongoing calibration, â€œconfidence monitoring,â€ evolving prompts, and a whole bevy of tweaks Iâ€™m still figuribng out.

Our prototype had worked with simple intent classification. Production required A/B testing frameworks, classification confidence monitoring, and user correction feedback loops.

The successful prototype hadnâ€™t prepared us for the operational complexity of AI systems at scale.

The domain-first vindication

The query service implementation vindicated our domain-first architectural approach. We could add query paths without changing domain models because the domain logic was separate from the execution patterns.

  • Domain models: Stayed stable across command and query implementations
  • Service layers: Added query services alongside existing workflow services
  • API layer: Extended with query endpoints while maintaining command endpoints

Good domain architecture enables multiple access patterns without fundamental changes.

The checkpoint-driven development value

What made this session successfulâ€Šâ€”â€Šunlike our earlier complexity strugglesâ€Šâ€”â€Šwas checkpoint-driven development:

Checkpoint 1: Document the query vs. command distinction
Checkpoint 2: Implement basic query service
Checkpoint 3: Add error handling and HTTP semantics
Checkpoint 4: Update API documentation

Each checkpoint was small enough to complete and validate before moving forward.

A production-ready mindsetÂ shift

This session marked a transition from â€œworks in happy pathâ€ thinking to â€œrobust error handling with proper HTTP semanticsâ€ thinking.

Prototype mindset is about getting basic functionality working. Production mindset means handling edge cases, providing clear error messages, optimizing for operations.

The successful prototype had taught us to build features. Production required learning to build systems.

Architectural maturity benchmarks

Looking back, the ability to recognize and implement CQRS-lite showed architectural maturity. Instead of forcing new requirements into existing patterns, we could create new patterns appropriate to new requirements.

The successful prototype had been one really good pattern. The production system needed a toolkit of complementary patterns.

The compound learningÂ effect

What struck me about this session was how lessons from our earlier architectural struggles compounded to make this session smoother:

  • Multi-AI drift experience: Better coordination and explicit human oversight
  • Complexity hole recovery: Systematic approaches and checkpoint validation
  • CQRS implementation: Right-sized architecture for different problems

Each challenge had taught us something that made the next challenge more manageable.

Anti-prototype wisdom

The biggest insight from overcoming Successful Prototype Syndrome is developing â€œanti-prototype wisdomâ€â€Šâ€”â€Šthe ability to recognize when something that works well has become a constraint.

Questions to ask: Is this pattern appropriate for this problem? Are we using it because itâ€™s right or because itâ€™s familiar? What would a purpose-built solution look like?

Signals to watch for: Implementation that feels harder than it should, architectural resistance to simple features, complexity that doesnâ€™t match problem complexity.

Another fâ€™inâ€™ â€œahaâ€Â moment

This session felt like the culmination of everything weâ€™d learned about systematic architecture during the complex PM-009 implementation. We could recognize architectural problems early, implement solutions systematically, and document decisions for future reference.

The struggles with complexity and drift had taught us when to trust existing patterns and when to create new ones.

ca9c8039b20d.title: When TDD Saves Your Architecture
ca9c8039b20d.subtitle: June 25, 2025
ca9c8039b20d.content:
When TDD Saves Your Architecture

June 25, 2025

Thirty-four tests. Zero compromises. One unshakeable foundation.

This is the story of how Test-Driven Development didnâ€™t just help me build featuresâ€Šâ€”â€Šit saved my architecture from death by a thousand shortcuts.

Sometimes the discipline of writing tests first forces you to make better decisions than you would have made if you were just trying to ship quickly.

The pressure to cutÂ corners

File analysis seemed straightforward enough. Read CSV files, extract data, return some statistics. Maybe use a library, maybe hardcode a few things, get it working and move on to the next feature.

The pressure was real: I had a working integration pipeline waiting for actual file analysis. The temptation was to just make it work, clean it up later. Weâ€™d marked PM-011 done ages ago and while supposed just â€œtestingâ€ the UI we were now finding that whatever had claimed to work under the hood by passing unit, integration, and orchestration tests was now failing in actual use.

But weâ€™d made this commitment to Test-Driven Development for this feature: Write the test first, watch it fail for the right reason, implement just enough to pass, refactor if needed. When tempted to skip a step, or alter a test to make it pass, resist!

TDD catches what code reviewÂ misses

The first test I wrote was for path traversal security. Basic stuffâ€Šâ€”â€Šmake sure user-provided file paths canâ€™t escape the upload directory.

The test failed. Good.

I implemented basic validation. The test passed. Also good.

But when we looked at the implementation, Claude realized it was wrong. The path validation was checking after normalization, not before. A classic security vulnerability that would have been easy to miss in code review but impossible to miss when the test made the expectation explicit, or so Iâ€™m told?

TDD didnâ€™t just catch a bugâ€Šâ€”â€Šit caught a security hole before it made it into the codebase.

Domain models stayÂ sacred

Hereâ€™s where TDD really proved its worth. As we built analyzers for different file types, tests started expecting specific output formats. The CSV analyzer test wanted detailed statistics, the document analyzer expected key findings, the text analyzer needed content summaries.

The easy fix would have been to modify the domain modelsâ€Šâ€”â€Šadd fields here, change structures there, whatever makes the tests pass.

But Iâ€™d learned this lesson the hard way before: domain models are sacred. They represent the business logic contract. Tests conform to models, not the other way around.

So instead of changing the AnalysisResult model, we used the metadata field for variable content. Instead of adding type-specific fields, we designed the analyzers to work within the established contract.

The result: a consistent domain model that every analyzer could implement cleanly, without special cases or architectural exceptions.

The factory patternÂ emerges

Twenty tests in, a pattern started emerging. I was creating analyzers in every test, duplicating setup code, and making assumptions about how theyâ€™d be instantiated in production.

TDD forced the question: how should these components actually be created and wired together?

The answer was a â€œfactory patternâ€ following the existing codebase conventions:

  • Stateless factory with per-call dependency injection
  • Clear registration of analyzer types
  • Easy extension with new file formats
  • Thread-safe concurrent creation

The factory pattern didnâ€™t emerge from architectural planningâ€Šâ€”â€Šit emerged from the pressure of writing clean, maintainable tests.

Security, performance, and errorÂ handling

Because we were the writing tests first, we had to address edge cases before implementing happy paths:

  • What happens with corrupted files?
  • How do we handle files that are too large?
  • What about malformed CSV data?
  • How do we validate file types safely?

Each edge case became a test. Each test forced architectural decisions. Should we throw exceptions or return error results? How do we communicate partial failures? Whatâ€™s the boundary between domain logic and infrastructure concerns?

The tests didnâ€™t just verify behaviorâ€Šâ€”â€Šthey designed the behavior by making trade-offs explicit.

Of course I mostly just sat and watched this part, but it was educational!

The 34-test milestone

When I hit 34 passing tests, something interesting had happened. I wasnâ€™t just testing file analysisâ€Šâ€”â€ŠIâ€™d built a comprehensive security layer, a flexible factory system, proper error handling, and clean domain model compliance.

All driven by the discipline of test-first development.

The architecture wasnâ€™t planned in advance. It emerged from the pressure of writing testable code, handling edge cases explicitly, and maintaining consistency across components.

What TDD reallyÂ does

TDD isnâ€™t about testingâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s about design. Writing tests first forces you to think about interfaces before implementations, contracts before code, edge cases before optimizations.

Tests reveal design problems early. Bad interfaces are hard to test. Complex dependencies make setup painful. Unclear contracts lead to confusing assertions.

Tests force explicit decisions. Should this throw an exception or return an error? How should components communicate? What are the actual requirements vs. nice-to-have features?

Tests prevent architectural drift. When every behavior is specified in a test, shortcuts become obvious and uncomfortable. The test suite becomes a guardian of consistency.

Another frigginâ€™ compoundÂ effect

Hereâ€™s the really interesting part: the 34 tests didnâ€™t just validate 34 behaviors. They created a foundation that made subsequent development faster and more reliable.

When integration time came, the file analysis components dropped in cleanly. When error scenarios arose, the handling was already built in. When new file types needed support, the factory pattern made extension straightforward.

Good tests donâ€™t just catch bugsâ€Šâ€”â€Šthey prevent entire categories of problems from emerging.

A lesson about discipline

The temptation to skip tests is always strongest when youâ€™re building something new, when the pressure to ship is high, when â€œweâ€™ll add tests laterâ€ seems reasonable.

But TDD is most valuable exactly when it feels most inconvenient. When the architecture is fluid, when requirements are emerging, when shortcuts beckonâ€Šâ€”â€Šthatâ€™s when the discipline of test-first development pays the highest dividends.

Not because tests catch bugs, but because tests force good decisions.

98ad7b8cefd0.title: When Your Docs Lie
98ad7b8cefd0.subtitle: June 21â€“22, 2025
98ad7b8cefd0.content:
When Your DocsÂ Lie

June 21â€“22, 2025

Fresh off completing three planned issues,PM-009 (multi-project support), PM-010 (production error handling), and PM-011 (web chat interface), feeling pretty good about our systematic development progress. Time to update the documentation to reflect our new capabilities.

Thatâ€™s when I realized our user guide still claimed â€œno web UI existsâ€ for a system that now had a fully functional web chat interface.

This is the story of documentation debtâ€Šâ€”â€Šhow it accumulates faster than you think, compounds more dangerously than technical debt, and requires its own systematic reckoning process.

Celebrating technical wins while ignoring communication debt

Weâ€™d been on a roll with systematic development. Three major features completed in sequence, each building on solid architectural foundations. PM-009 gave us sophisticated multi-project context resolution. PM-010 delivered production-quality error handling. PM-011 provided a working web interface with real-time updates. (We were soon to learn the user interface was really only skin-deep so far, but no spoilers.)

But while weâ€™d been disciplined about technical debt, weâ€™d completely ignored documentation debt. And documentation debt, it turns out, is more insidious than technical debt because it affects every stakeholder who tries to understand what youâ€™ve built.

It also squanders the opportunity to provide language-eating bots with the lastest accurate information about what theyâ€™re working on for you.

The crisis language re-discovery

The worst part wasnâ€™t just outdated informationâ€Šâ€”â€Šit was the tone of our documentation. Our requirements document was full of â€œğŸš¨ BLOCKINGâ€ assessments for features weâ€™d already completed. Crisis language describing problems weâ€™d already solved.

This dated to my earliest attempt to tame the LLMsâ€™ tendency for hype. When the first set of docs claimed our patchy prototype was production-ready, I had insisted on a more realistic (and dour, it turns out) assessment.

But now our old docs still said things like â€œCritical gaps in GitHub integration preventing production useâ€ when in fact we had since already implicated some pretty slick GitHub issue analysis, with 95% intent accuracy and professional improvement suggestions

The documentation wasnâ€™t just wrong about capabilitiesâ€Šâ€”â€Šit was wrong about our trajectory. Anyone reading it, even a bot! would think we were in crisis mode when we were actually hitting our development milestones systematically.

This, as noted, was an overcorrection. Thereâ€™s been an ongoing tension when documenting Piper between technical accuracy and hype. These tools canâ€™t resist positive spin unless you actively frame the tone and perspective you want.

In this case, there was no one to hype! I donâ€™t need to impress a boss or investor. I donâ€™t have deadlines. This is a learning project fundamentally, but itâ€™s really hard for these AIs to overcome their training.

The â€œno web UIâ€ embarrassment

The most embarrassing discovery was our user guide prominently stating â€œno web UI existsâ€ while our system had a fully functional web chat interface that weâ€™d been demoing to stakeholders.

This wasnâ€™t just an oversightâ€Šâ€”â€Šit would actively mislead anyone trying to evaluate or use our system. Imagine a new team member reading the docs and concluding they needed to use command-line tools when there was a perfectly good web interface available. Good thing itâ€™s just me working on this thing, and my language bots of course.

Compound interest on documentation debt

What struck me about this documentation reckoning was how fast documentation debt compounded. It wasnâ€™t like technical debt where problems accumulate graduallyâ€Šâ€”â€Šdocumentation debt created immediate credibility issues.

Week 1: Documentation slightly behind reality
Week 2: Documentation describes different system than what exists
Week 3: Documentation actively contradicts stakeholder experience

Each week of delay made the documentation exponentially more misleading rather than just incrementally outdated.

The systematic consolidation approach

Once I recognized the scope of the documentation debt, I knew this needed systematic attentionâ€Šâ€”â€Šnot just quick fixes to the most obvious problems. One of the theme of this journey has been gradually re-discovering why software development has evolved as it has.

Oh, right! Accurate documentation. Thatâ€™s important. (Remember, I was a content strategist before I was an information architect before I was a UX lead before I was product guy, and before all that I wrote technical books! How could I of all people overlook the importance of writing it all down?).

Time to get back on track:

  1. Conduct complete audit of all documentation folders
  2. Identify documents that were fundamentally misaligned vs. incrementally outdated
  3. Replace crisis-language documents entirely rather than patching them
  4. Establish documentation standards to prevent future drift

With clear instructions, this is a much better job for them than us. They happily spew out docs all day long, to any spec.

The decision to replace rather than incrementally update the requirements document was crucial. When documentation is fundamentally misaligned with reality, patching creates more confusion than clarity.

Archaeology on our ownÂ system

The systematic documentation review became like archaeological workâ€Šâ€”â€Šuncovering layers of assumptions and outdated understandings about our own system.

Architecture layer: Discovered weâ€™d achieved CQRS-lite patterns organically without documenting them
Integration layer: Found weâ€™d evolved sophisticated error handling contracts without recording them
User experience layer: Realized weâ€™d built production-ready workflows while documentation still described proof-of-concepts

Sometimes you donâ€™t understand what youâ€™ve built until you try to document it accurately.

AIs need docs theÂ most

One insight from this session was how AI collaboration changes documentation requirements. Working with AI assistants requires more comprehensive documentation because AI needs explicit context that humans might assume.

Traditionally, documentation was made to serve humans who could fill in gaps where needed. Now, documentation serves as context for AI systems that canâ€™t make assumptions.

Session logs, architectural decision records, and detailed context documentation become critical enablers rather than optional nice-to-haves.

AIs have no sense ofÂ thime.

During the documentation review, we discovered a freshly created requirements document that was dated â€œDecember 2025â€â€Šâ€”â€Šsix months in the future.

â€œItâ€™s funny you think itâ€™s December though? maybe we are ahead of our roadmap lol. It is June 21 today. In fact, from now on letâ€™s always make sure our docs have the date they were last updated right up near the top!â€

That spontaneous decision to establish dating standards turned out to be crucial for documentation maintenance workflow.

One thing Iâ€™ve noticed is that these bot friends tend to make schedule assumptions based on human developer output. This makes sense since the bulk of their training sets deal with such scenarios. This tends to lead to them being constantly astounded at how they are crushing the schedule. After the first week we often had docs saying Iâ€™d been at it for months, and because we were so far ahead on some early conservative roadmap, it just did the math and assumed it must be six months in by now.

Adopting progressive disclosure emojis

One architectural insight from the documentation consolidation was implementing â€œprogressive disclosureâ€ through status indicators:

âœ… Complete
ğŸ”„ In Progress
ğŸ“‹ Planned

Progressive disclosure enables quick scanning while detailed information remains available.

Documentation as architecture

The consolidation process revealed that documentation structure should mirror system architecture. Our scattered docs reflected confused thinking about system boundaries.

Our updated doc tree separated documentation into categoriesâ€Šâ€”â€Šarchitecture/, development/, planning/, project/â€Šâ€”â€Šhelping to keep things uncluttered.

When documentation structure is unclear, it usually indicates architectural thinking is unclear.

Doppleganger docs

During consolidation, we discovered we had made API documentation files twice: one was a comprehensive specification and the other a basic reference guide. Instead of consolidating them, we made sure they were accurate and then established complementary purposes:

The comprehensive doc contains complete contracts, error handling, WebSocket specs, etc. The other is a streamlined quick reference for daily development work.

Different audiences need different detail levels. Forcing everything into one document serves no audience well.

The mid-writing handoff-context crisis

The session was interrupted when â€œthings went sidewaysâ€â€Šâ€”â€Šsystem issues occurred during the documentation work. For all of their adeptness with words and language, a lot of these tools are unaware of their own limitations, and when you give them a big editing job, they can try to cram all the text into their â€œheadsâ€ until they get confused and give up or start making big mistakes.

One way I learned to deal with that, especially with the somewhat unimaginative Cursor assistant, was to give strict one-at-a-time instructions, requiring the bot to write and edit discrete chunks of work and then report in on success or failure before proceeding to a next step. This prevents it from trying to juggle all the pieces at once.

The mini-crash that interrupted our work combined with the filling up of a chat before I could get a clean handoff prompt created its own documentation challenge: how do you hand off incomplete work when the work itself is about improving handoff documentation?

We managed to repair the session log, provide enough context about the work in progress, and get things continued, but managing across these sorts of disjunctions can be a constant challenge that requires the focused attention of the primate in the loop.

This recursive problem only underlined why systematic session logging is critical for AI collaboration projects.

The documentation-driven development insight

What emerged from this reckoning was â€œdocumentation-driven developmentâ€â€Šâ€”â€Šusing documentation accuracy as a forcing function for architectural clarity.

Documenting our work forces us to ask questions such as, â€œWhat exactly does this component do?â€ and â€œHow do these pieces connect?â€ and â€œWhat are the actual error conditions?â€

Capturing this info provides architectural benefits: clear boundaries, explicit contracts, honest capability assessment

When you canâ€™t document something clearly, itâ€™s usually because the architecture isnâ€™t clear.

Systematic vs. reactive documentation

This session established the difference between systematic and reactive documentation approaches. Being reactive means letting docs get stale till someone complains. Being systematic means incorporating documentatiom updates as acceptance criteria for feature completion.

This feels like a lesson I have to learn again and again in each new context. Forgot to instrument the new feature and had no data for the first sprint after launch? It goes in the acceptance criteria and the feature-brief template and you never forget to do it again.

Systematic documentation prevents the compound interest problem by addressing drift before it becomes misleading.

The systematic approach also helped us develop an effective documentation consolidation workflow:

  1. Complete auditâ€Šâ€”â€Šwhat exists, whatâ€™s accurate, whatâ€™s missing
  2. Triageâ€Šâ€”â€Šincremental updates vs. complete replacement
  3. Systematic updatesâ€Šâ€”â€Šworking through one category at a time
  4. Cross-referencingâ€Šâ€”â€Šensuring documents connect appropriately

Trying to update everything simultaneously creates inconsistency. Sequential consolidation maintains coherence.

Forgetting to document our architectural evolution

One major discovery was that weâ€™d achieved sophisticated architectural patterns (CQRS-lite, multi-project context resolution, provider-agnostic design) without documenting them.

This meant new team members (human or otherwise) wouldnâ€™t understand the systemâ€™s design principles. Even we werenâ€™t fully conscious of what patterns weâ€™d established.

Converting implicit architectural knowledge to explicit documentation enables system evolution and team growth.

Another thing this reckoning taught me is that documentation quality gates are as important as code quality gates.

Systems that check code quality but not documentation quality inevitably accumulate communication debt.

Like a bridge over troubled documents

This documentation reckoning session served as a bridge between our architectural learning period and the systematic recovery work that followed. Learning to address documentation debt systematically prepared us for addressing technical debt systematically.

Good process disciplines transfer across different types of maintenance work.

b4d9193ec579.title: The 48-hour rollercoaster: from working tests to â€˜Failed attemptâ€™ and back to â€˜LIFE SAVERÂ !!!â€â€™
b4d9193ec579.subtitle: June 24â€“26, 2025
b4d9193ec579.content:
The 48-Hour Rollercoaster: From working tests to â€˜Failed attemptâ€™ and back to â€˜LIFE SAVERÂ !!!â€â€™

June 24â€“26, 2025

Tuesday afternoon working on file analysis architecture: â€œ34/34 tests passing.â€

Thursday evening: â€œFailed attempt to recreate lost work from session logsâ€

Friday afternoon: â€œSession Complete! ğŸ‰ 64+ tests validating the integrationâ€

This is the story of how 48 hours can contain a complete cycle of triumph, disaster, and redemption in AI-assisted development. And why the most important commit you never make might be the one that teaches you the most.

The triumph: 34 tests of architectural perfection

It started with one of those sessions where everything clicks. Test-Driven Development humming along, components falling into place, domain models staying clean despite pressure to compromise.

By Tuesday afternoon I had built a complete file analysis system: security validation, type detection, content sampling, factory patterns, comprehensive error handling. Every edge case tested, every interface clean, every abstraction earning its place.

Thirty-four tests. Zero shortcuts. The kind of foundational work that makes future development a joy instead of a struggle.

The integration realityÂ check

Wednesday brought the next challenge: wiring all these beautiful components into the existing workflow system. Integration testingâ€Šâ€”â€Šwhere unit test perfection meets messy reality.

And you know what? It worked. File upload â†’ reference resolution â†’ workflow creation â†’ analysis execution â†’ UI success. The complete vertical slice, end-to-end, with real LLM provider fallbacks and proper error handling.

The foundation was so solid that integration was almost anticlimactic. Good architecture tends to work that way.

The cascade of complexity

But then Thursday morning arrived with that familiar development challenge: how do you continue work across AI chat sessions? How do you maintain context, preserve architectural decisions, communicate complex state?

This is where things got interesting. The integration wasnâ€™t quite completeâ€Šâ€”â€Šthere were interface violations to fix, type mismatches to resolve, import paths to straighten out. The kind of detail work that requires understanding the full context.

What followed was a master class in how architectural complexity can compound when context gets lost:

  • String-to-enum conversion issues
  • Interface violations in concrete analyzers
  • Liskov Substitution Principle failures (I know, right!?)
  • Import-path inconsistencies
  • Test-assertion mismatches

Each fix revealed another issue. Each issue required understanding decisions made in previous sessions. The context overhead started dominating the actual work.

The moment ofÂ loss

It was clear I had screwed something up. Was it the usual laptop dance? The environmental shuffle? Some sort of failure-to-save-my-work boogie? Whatever it was, when I started my next work session I encountered that moment every developer has experienced but hopes never to repeat: uncommitted work, gone. Unretrievable.

I filled up a whole nother chat trying to rebuild it by following the previous plan. But this time around Claude was making me up slightly different new versions of each file I or change I asked for, and nothing was working. I ended up naming that one â€œFailed attempt to recreate lost work from session logs.â€

Thirty-four passing tests. Hours of architectural decisions. Clean abstractions and careful interface design. All of it existing only in session logs and failing memory.

The emotional impact was real: â€œI feel like Iâ€™ve wasted two days of workâ€ I wrote to my superficially sympathetic partner. The frustration of losing not just code, but context, decisions, the accumulated understanding of how pieces fit together.

The lesson in theÂ loss

But hereâ€™s what made this more than just a cautionary tale about version control discipline. The attempt to recreate the work from session logs revealed something important about AI-assisted development:

Context handoff is the critical bottleneck.

Itâ€™s not enough to build great features. You need systems for preserving decisions, communicating architectural choices, maintaining the thread of reasoning across sessions and agents.

The session logs were detailed enough to recreate the functionality, but not the understanding. I could rebuild what the code did, but not why it was designed that way.

The disciplined recovery

Friday morning: â€œSwitching to retracing original successful TDD approach.â€

Instead of continuing to fight the recreation, I went back to first principles. Test-Driven Development. Clean interfaces. Domain-first design. The methodology that had worked the first time.

But this time with a crucial difference: commit working code immediately.

The triumphant return

What happened next surprised me. Not only did I restore the lost functionalityâ€Šâ€”â€ŠI improved it.

The TDD discipline forced by the recovery led to better architecture:

  • WorkflowExecutor refactored from anti-pattern construction to proper dependency injection
  • Error handling standardized to exceptions instead of error results
  • Consistent serialization patterns applied throughout
  • Import issues fixed across the codebase

Session Grade: A+

  • 97% test pass rate (62/64 tests)
  • Zero regressionâ€Šâ€”â€ŠAll existing functionality preserved
  • Architectural improvements throughout

The work wasnâ€™t just restoredâ€Šâ€”â€Šit was better than before. I went back to that log from the first time the tests passed and changed its title from â€œ*6/24â€Šâ€”â€ŠFile Analysis Architecture (o)â€ (the asterisk means it filled up, and the (o) means itâ€™s Opus) to â€œ*6/24â€Šâ€”â€ŠFile Analysis Architecture (o)â€Šâ€”â€ŠLIFE SAVERÂ !!!â€

What the rollercoaster taughtÂ me

Good process beats heroic recovery. The TDD discipline that created the original work also guided the successful recreation. Methodology matters more than individual brilliance.

Context preservation is architecture. AI-assisted development needs systems for preserving not just code, but decisions, reasoning, architectural choices. Session logs are necessary but not sufficient.

Loss can lead to improvement. The forced reconstruction, guided by solid principles, resulted in cleaner architecture than the original. Sometimes starting over with accumulated wisdom beats incremental improvement.

Commit discipline isnâ€™t optional. In traditional development, uncommitted work might cost hours. In AI-assisted development, it can cost context thatâ€™s impossible to fully recreate.

A meta-insight about AI development

Building with AI assistance creates a paradox: incredible speed when things work, but fragile handoffs when context gets lost. The same tools that accelerate development also make it more dependent on external session state.

The solution isnâ€™t to slow downâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s to build better systems for context preservation, decision documentation, and architectural communication.

The compound value of discipline

Hereâ€™s what I learned from going from triumph to disaster to better triumph in 48 hours: good process compounds, shortcuts decay.

The TDD discipline that created the original architecture also guided the successful recovery. The commitment to clean domain models, proper interfaces, and comprehensive testing made both the initial success and the eventual recovery possible.

But the shortcutsâ€Šâ€”â€Šthe uncommitted work, the assumed context, the informal handoffsâ€Šâ€”â€Šthose created the disaster.

So, you know, itâ€™sÂ helpful

We now have not just working file analysis, but bulletproof file analysis. Components that integrate cleanly, error handling that works consistently, architecture that makes the next feature easier to add.

The 48-hour rollercoaster taught lessons that months of smooth development wouldnâ€™t have: about context preservation, disciplined recovery, and the compound value of doing things right even when it feels slower.

Sometimes the best learning comes disguised as the worst setbacks.

160bc294b0b5.title: The Technical Debt Reckoning
160bc294b0b5.subtitle: June 26
160bc294b0b5.content:
The Technical Debt Reckoning

June 26

So there I was, supposedly at the end of a successful integration sprint, staring at what should have been a celebration moment, and instead discovering Iâ€™d accidentally built two orchestration systems.

And only one of them actually worked.

This is the kind of discovery that makes you question everything you thought you knew about your own codebase. Like finding out youâ€™ve been wearing mismatched socks for a week, except instead of socks, itâ€™s fundamental architecture, and instead of a week, itâ€™sâ€¦ well, however long it takes to accidentally build duplicate systems without noticing.

Welcome to the technical debt reckoning.

Success with a side of confusion

Weâ€™d just completed a major integration milestone. File analysis was working end-to-end. The tests were passing. Users could upload files, get intelligent analysis, and everything flowed through our task-based architecture beautifully.

But as I started preparing for the next integration (GitHub functionality), I kept running into this nagging confusion about which orchestration system I was supposed to use (without really understanding what was going on).

There was OrchestrationEngineâ€Šâ€”â€Šthe newer, cleaner task-based architecture that aligned perfectly with our domain models. And there was WorkflowExecutorâ€Šâ€”â€Šthe older system that had grown organically from our early GitHub proof-of-concept work.

Both worked. Both had tests. Both were actively maintained. And I had no clear memory of making a conscious decision to keep both. This is a side effect of working with AIs that â€œknowâ€ a lot more about programming than I do. They suggest things, I say â€œthat sounds good,â€ and the implications escape me. (I try to ask for tradeoffs and pros and cons these days!)

The detective workÂ begins

When you suspect architectural confusion, you start with the basics: grep for usage patterns and see whatâ€™s actually running in production.

grep -r "OrchestrationEngine" services/
grep -r "WorkflowExecutor" services/

What I found wasâ€¦ interesting.

OrchestrationEngine was everywhere the application was actually working. The main API used it exclusively. File analysis flowed through it. The domain models were designed around its task-based approach.

WorkflowExecutor wasâ€¦ well, it was thoroughly tested, had its own handlers, and was definitely being maintained. But it wasnâ€™t being used by anything that mattered.

It was like discovering youâ€™ve been paying rent on two apartments but only sleeping in one.

The â€œwhy did this happen?â€Â moment

Hereâ€™s the thing about technical debt: it doesnâ€™t usually happen because you make bad decisions. It happens because you make reasonable decisions that become less reasonable over time, and then you keep making more reasonable decisions on top of them.

WorkflowExecutor started as a perfectly sensible solution for GitHub integration. Quick, focused, got the job done. When we needed file analysis, OrchestrationEngine emerged as a better architectural approachâ€Šâ€”â€Šmore extensible, better separation of concerns, aligned with our evolving domain models.

But instead of migrating WorkflowExecutorâ€™s functionality to the new system, we justâ€¦ kept both. Because WorkflowExecutor was working, and who has time to fix something that isnâ€™t broken when youâ€™re trying to ship features? And, well, I didnâ€™t ask and nobody suggested it.

I was starting to understand how AOL Instant Messenger had gotten into the spaghettified state it was in when I was director of product in its final years.

Classic technical debt formation: each individual decision makes sense, but the accumulated result is architectural confusion.

The testing gap that should have been a redÂ flag

Hereâ€™s what really should have tipped me off: OrchestrationEngineâ€Šâ€”â€Šthe system that was actually running our applicationâ€Šâ€”â€Šhad zero tests.

Zero.

WorkflowExecutor, the legacy system that nothing was using? Comprehensive test coverage.

This is like having a perfectly maintained spare car while your daily driver has no brakes. It works right up until you need to stop.

The test coverage gap existed because OrchestrationEngine had evolved organically from real usage patterns, while WorkflowExecutor had been built with proper TDD discipline from the start. Good process applied to the wrong system.

Itâ€™s like we had built a bicycle with state-of-the-art precision and were running our errands in a go-kart.

The hardÂ decision

When you discover architectural debt like this, youâ€™ve got three options:

  1. Ignore it: Keep both systems, accept the confusion, hope future developers figure it out
  2. Merge: Try to combine the best of both systems into some hybrid approach
  3. Choose: Pick the right system and migrate everything to it

Option 1 is what got us here in the first place. Option 2 is how you end up with three systems instead of two. That left Option 3.

But choosing means admitting that time and effort spent on one system was essentially waste. It means having uncomfortable conversations about sunk costs and technical priorities.

Sometimes the kindest thing you can do for your codebase is stop maintaining the parts that donâ€™t serve it anymore.

The OrchestrationEngine decision

So why OrchestrationEngine over WorkflowExecutor?

Domain alignment: OrchestrationEngineâ€™s task-based approach matched how our business logic actually worked. Tasks could be composed, reused, and tested independently.

Production reality: It was already handling our most complex workflows successfully. File analysis, user interactions, the stuff that actually matteredâ€Šâ€”â€Šall flowing through OrchestrationEngine.

Extension patterns: Adding new functionality (like GitHub integration) fit naturally into the task handler pattern.

Future flexibility: The architecture anticipated growth in ways WorkflowExecutor didnâ€™t.

WorkflowExecutor wasnâ€™t badâ€Šâ€”â€Šit was just optimized for a different phase of the project. Early exploration versus systematic growth.

The cleanup discipline

Once you make the architectural decision, the cleanup work is mostly mechanical. But it requires discipline.

Step 1: Ensure the chosen system has proper test coverage (we wrote 11 comprehensive tests for OrchestrationEngine)

Step 2: Extract any unique functionality from the deprecated system (WorkflowExecutor had some GitHub handlers we needed to preserve)

Step 3: Update all documentation to reflect the single-system approach

Step 4: Actually delete the deprecated code (the hardest step psychologically)

The temptation is to just comment out the old system â€œin case we need it later.â€ But keeping dead code around is how you end up with technical debt in the first place.

By the way, this all sounds like I clean up code messes every day. A few weeks earlier I would have despaired of fixing this. Iâ€™d haveâ€Šâ€”â€Šat bestâ€Šâ€”â€Šbeen trying to follow stepwise advice, showing screens and errors to the chatbot, making typos, breaking stuff. Iâ€™d have made a bigger mess. But this far along, trusting the development process weâ€™d, well, developed and was impressed at how smoothly the cleanup went.

So, really, my assistants fix it, but the initial recognition that we had two systems serving the same purposeâ€Šâ€”â€Šthat came from forcing myself to slow down and actually understand what weâ€™d built.

Documentation-debt dÃ©jÃ Â vu

Cleaning up the architectural confusion revealed a second layer of debt: our documentation was describing a system that didnâ€™t match what weâ€™d actually built.

The technical specs talked about WorkflowExecutor as the primary orchestration system. The architecture diagrams showed workflows that werenâ€™t actually in use. The API documentation described patterns that had evolved beyond recognition.

This is how technical debt compounds: inconsistent code leads to inconsistent documentation, which leads to incorrect assumptions in future development decisions.

This happens a lot when you have AIs generate you a bunch of docs as a one-off. Who is going to maintain those docs and keep them up to date? You? Did you even read them? The bots? How will they remember to check, and when? (Over time we solved these problems, but that would be weeks later.)

And good documentation isnâ€™t just nice to haveâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s a forcing function for architectural clarity.

What I learned about noticingÂ debt

Technical debt isnâ€™t always obvious. Sometimes it hides in plain sight as â€œworking systemsâ€ that just happen to be redundant.

Signals to watch for:

  • Developer confusion about which pattern to follow
  • Multiple ways to accomplish the same fundamental task
  • Test coverage gaps in systems that are actually being used
  • Documentation that doesnâ€™t match implementation reality
  • Integration work that feels harder than it should

The key insight: Technical debt isnâ€™t just bad code. Itâ€™s confusing code. Code that makes the next developer (including future you) have to make decisions that should already be made.

The relief ofÂ clarity

Thereâ€™s something deeply satisfying about resolving architectural confusion. Not just because the codebase is cleaner, but because your mental model finally matches the reality of what youâ€™ve built. Itâ€™s like having a headache go away.

After the cleanup, adding GitHub integration became straightforward. Create a task handler, register it with OrchestrationEngine, write tests. No decisions about which system to use, no studying two different patterns to figure out which one to follow.

Clarity compounds just like debt does. Every future integration gets easier because the patterns are consistent and well-understood.

A systematic approach toÂ debt

What turned this from a frustrating discovery into a productive session was approaching it systematically:

  1. Assess honestly: What do we actually have, versus what we think we have?
  2. Trace usage patterns: Which systems are actually serving users?
  3. Evaluate architectural fit: Which approach serves our long-term goals?
  4. Plan migration: What needs to be preserved, what can be discarded?
  5. Execute with discipline: Follow through on the cleanup, donâ€™t leave loose ends

You donâ€™t have to pay off all your debt, certainly not at once. There are acceptable levels of debt at times if it is not slowing you down and not creating compound problems, but other forms of debt cannot be ignored without eventually tanking your project.

Technical debt isnâ€™t inherently badâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s just the accumulation of decisions that made sense at the time. The problem comes when you stop making conscious choices about it.

More compoundÂ effects

The architectural cleanup paid dividends immediately. The next day, when we were working on domain contract enforcement, the clean single-system architecture made it easy to understand where problems were coming from and how to fix them.

Later in the week, systematic GitHub integration flowed naturally through the established patterns. No confusion, no competing approaches, just clear implementation following clear architecture.

This is what good technical debt management gets you: not perfect code, but predictable code. Code where the next step is obvious and the patterns are consistent.

When debt becomes opportunity

Hereâ€™s what I didnâ€™t expect about the technical debt reckoning: it wasnâ€™t just about cleaning up mistakes. It was about discovering what weâ€™d actually learned about building this kind of system.

OrchestrationEngine emerged from real usage patterns. It had evolved to solve actual problems weâ€™d encountered with WorkflowExecutorâ€™s approach. The â€œaccidentalâ€ architecture was actually better architectureâ€Šâ€”â€Šwe just hadnâ€™t recognized it yet.

Sometimes technical debt isnâ€™t just waste to be cleaned up. Itâ€™s evidence of learning that hasnâ€™t been systematized yet.

The ongoing discipline

Technical debt management isnâ€™t a one-time cleanupâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s an ongoing practice. But having gone through this systematic reckoning gave us patterns for recognizing and addressing debt before it compounds.

Regular architecture reviews: Periodic check-ins on whether our documented patterns match our implemented patterns

Usage audits: Grep for whatâ€™s actually being used versus whatâ€™s being maintained

Test coverage monitoring: Gaps in test coverage often indicate unclear architectural boundaries

Developer confusion signals: When integration work feels harder than it should, thatâ€™s usually a debt signal

The goal isnâ€™t to eliminate all technical debtâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s to make conscious decisions about which debt to accept and which debt to address.

Sunk costs make us feelÂ bad

Maybe the most important lesson from the technical debt reckoning was about honest assessment. Itâ€™s easy to rationalize keeping multiple systems because â€œthey both workâ€ or â€œwe might need the flexibility.â€

But architectural clarity is worth more than theoretical flexibility. Having one well-understood system beats having two sort-of-understood systems, even if both work.

The hardest part wasnâ€™t the technical cleanupâ€Šâ€”â€Šit was admitting that effort spent on WorkflowExecutor was essentially waste, even though every individual decision that led to it was reasonable.

Sometimes the most productive thing you can do is stop being productive in directions that no longer serve the project.
