5243027aa9f6.title: Battle-Testing Your Architecture: When Recovery Becomes Learning
5243027aa9f6.subtitle: June 29
5243027aa9f6.content:
Battle-Testing Your Architecture: When Recovery BecomesÂ Learning

June 29

Fresh off implementing GitHub integration in what felt like record time, I was ready to test our freshly implemented GitHub integration end-to-end. PM-011 was finally completeâ€Šâ€”â€Šcomprehensive documentation updated, architectural patterns discovered, integration handlers properly registered. Time for the victory lap: run the test, watch it create a real GitHub issue, close the ticket.

Three hours later, Iâ€™d accidentally triggered AI security warnings with a dad joke about Personal Access Tokens, lost my entire Docker database to a directory rename, and learned why â€œredo it properlyâ€ beats â€œpatch the recoveryâ€ every single time.

This is the story of how battle-testing integration reveals everything your development environment was hiding from you.

When victory laps become obstacleÂ courses

The GitHub integration was architecturally sound. Weâ€™d established clean patternsâ€Šâ€”â€Šrepository enrichment, singleton orchestration engine, proper error handling. The documentation was comprehensive. The test script was ready.

All I needed to do was verify the GITHUB_TOKEN was set, run test_github_integration_simple.py, and watch our AI PM assistant create its first real GitHub issue. Classic Friday afternoon testing of completed work.

The â€œAll Access Patâ€ securityÂ moment

The first hiccup was almost too ridiculous to believe. I was setting up the GitHub token and made what I thought was a harmless pun, saying â€œcall me All Access Patâ€ (because PAT = Personal Access Token, get it?).

Cursor immediately triggered security warnings about potential prompt injection attempts.

Classic Little Bobby Drop-Tables moment: My innocent dad joke about access tokens looked exactly like someone trying to manipulate the AI with fake authorization credentials. The security system was doing exactly what it should doâ€Šâ€”â€Štreat unexpected â€œaccessâ€ language with suspicion.

The recovery cascadeÂ begins

Once I got past the token setup comedy, the real fun started. The test script was missing. Not â€œcanâ€™t find itâ€â€Šâ€”â€Šactually deleted from the filesystem.

Discovery process:

  1. Check current directory: Not there
  2. Check git history: Never committed
  3. Check trash folder: Found it!
  4. Restore and verify: Working again

This should have been a warning sign. When your test infrastructure isnâ€™t under version control, youâ€™re already operating without a safety net.

The Docker data loss revelation

But the missing test script was just the warm-up act. When I tried to run the recovered test, the database was completely empty. Not â€œmissing some dataâ€â€Šâ€”â€Šzero tables, like a fresh PostgreSQL installation.

Root cause discovery: Iâ€™d renamed the project directory earlier in the week. Our Docker setup used bind mounts that were path-dependent:

# Fragile approach (what we had)
volumes:
  - ./data/postgres:/var/lib/postgresql/data

# Robust approach (what we should have had)  
volumes:
  piper_postgres_data:
    name: piper_postgres_data_v1

The directory rename broke the bind mount path, so Docker created a fresh database volume. All our test data, project configurations, and GitHub integration setup: gone.

The backup archaeology expedition

â€œNo problem,â€ I thought. â€œIâ€™ll restore from the backup I made last week.â€

The 46MB backup file looked promising. Restored it carefully, restarted services, checked the databaseâ€¦

Still empty.

Turns out the backup was a completely empty PostgreSQL cluster. Iâ€™d successfully backed up nothing and didnâ€™t realize it until I needed it. Classic backup validation failureâ€Šâ€”â€Šnever tested restoration until the emergency.

Backup lesson: The only backup you can trust is one youâ€™ve successfully restored from.

Confidence meets consequences

After our systematic approach to GitHub integrationâ€Šâ€”â€Šfollowing established patterns, writing proper tests, documenting everythingâ€Šâ€”â€ŠI was feeling pretty good about our architectural discipline. Weâ€™d built something clean, tested it thoroughly, and documented the patterns for future use.

(Spoiler alert: there is a meta-pattern clearly at at work where after every victory lap I get my comeuppance again.)

Time for the victory lap: a simple test to create a GitHub issue and verify the end-to-end flow worked as intended. At this point I was starting to take success for granted. What could go wrong with testing a system weâ€™d just built systematically?

Turns out: everything.

The cascade of smallÂ failures

The first sign of trouble was subtle: the test script Iâ€™d created the day before was missing. Not deletedâ€Šâ€”â€Šjustâ€¦ gone. Disappeared from the file system with no trace in the git history.

No problem, I thought. Iâ€™ll just recreate it. It was a simple script.

Except when I tried to run the new test, the GitHub token wasnâ€™t being recognized. Then I realized theÂ .env file was namedÂ .env.txt somehow. Then fixing that revealed that the database was emptyâ€”all my test projects had vanished.

Each problem was small and solvable individually. But they started compounding: fixing the token issue revealed the database problem, fixing the database revealed missing dependencies, fixing dependencies revealed that my virtual environment had somehow disappeared.

This is how systems fail in the real world: not with dramatic crashes, but with cascading small failures that expose hidden fragilities.

(Note: Did I wonder why so many things seemed to have gone wrong at once? No, I did not. Like a chatbot, I got absorbed in the chase.)

The nuclear optionÂ moment

The most dramatic failure came when I was trying to clean up some corrupted git state. My spidey sense was tingling when Claude recommended I use this command:

rm -rf .*

Seemed reasonable, right? Remove all the hidden files and start fresh.

ExceptÂ .* includesÂ .git.

Iâ€™d just deleted the entire git repository, meaning anything I had not committed to the remote repository (and I was not, at this point as of yet, disciplined about committing my changes after every session) was gone, daddy, gone.

Thereâ€™s a special kind of silence that follows the moment you realize youâ€™ve just destroyed something that took weeks to build. Itâ€™s the sound of all your confidence in your own competence evaporating at once.

The recovery discipline

Hereâ€™s what I learned about resilience: itâ€™s not about avoiding failures. Itâ€™s about recovering from them systematically.

Step 1: Stop and assess Instead of panicking and trying random fixes (OK, after panicking for a bit and then taking some deep breaths), I forced myself to stop and understand exactly what Iâ€™d lost and what I still had.

Step 2: Use external backups The git repository was gone locally, but GitHub still had pretty much everything. Fresh clone, reconfigure SSH, back in business.

Step 3: Fix root causes, not symptoms Instead of just restoring the missing test script, I figured out why it had disappeared in the first place.

Step 4: Document what you learn Every failure became a pattern to avoid in the future.

The Docker data persistence revelation

The biggest architectural lesson came from the database failure. Iâ€™d been using Docker bind mounts for data persistence, mapping local directories to container volumes. Simple, straightforward, works greatâ€¦ until you rename your project directory.

Which Iâ€™d done recently. See the first repository for the proof of concept was called piper-morgan. When I started the â€œrealâ€ project, Claude suggested calling the new repository piper-morgan-platform (it still says that in some of the docs) and I didnâ€™t think much of it at the time. Later I changed the github repository name to piper-morgan-product, which seemed like a more reasonable goal, although now I donâ€™t know.

But more to the point, I had renamed my local folder on my Mac from piper-morgan-platform to just piper-morgan and this is what broke stuff, not surprisingly.

Suddenly the database containers were looking for data in (sometimes hardcoded) paths that no longer existed. All my test projects: gone. All my GitHub integration configurations: gone. All evidence that the system had ever worked: gone.

This led to a complete overhaul of our Docker data strategy:

Before: Bind mounts tied to specific directory paths

volumes:
  - ./data/postgres:/var/lib/postgresql/data  # Fragile!

After: Named Docker volumes managed by Docker itself

yaml

volumes:
  piper_postgres_data:
    name: piper_postgres_data_v1

The new approach survives directory renames, project moves, and filesystem changes. Itâ€™s what we should have been using from the start.

Now, they tell me!

The environment reconstruction challenge

Rebuilding the development environment revealed how many assumptions weâ€™d baked into our setup process. Things that â€œjust workedâ€ when set up incrementally over weeks became puzzles when they needed to work from scratch.

Missing documentation: Setup steps that seemed obvious when you just did them

Hidden dependencies: Environment variables that were set but not documented

Tool version assumptions: Things that worked with specific Python/Node/Docker versions

Path dependencies: Hardcoded references to directory structures

Each missing piece was small. Together, they made the system much more fragile than weâ€™d realized.

Iâ€™ve been hearing â€œworks on my machine!â€ from engineers half my life and now I really understand the feeling. This is why battle-testing matters: it reveals the difference between â€œworks in my current setupâ€ and â€œworks reliably anywhere.â€

Our growing patternÂ catalog

Battle-testing revealed patterns we hadnâ€™t documented during the smooth implementation phase:

Pattern #13: Repository Domain Model Conversion We discovered that repositories were returning database models instead of domain models in some cases, causing AttributeError exceptions when business logic tried to use domain methods.

Pattern #14: Async Relationship Eager Loading
Â Async SQLAlchemy canâ€™t lazy-load relationships outside the session context, leading to â€œgreenlet_spawnâ€ errors. Always eager load relationships that will be accessed after the query.

These werenâ€™t patterns we designedâ€Šâ€”â€Šthey were patterns we discovered through failure, often the best kind.

Real-world testing doesnâ€™t just validate your architecture; it teaches you about architectural requirements you didnâ€™t know you had.

The discipline of documenting underÂ pressure

Hereâ€™s what impressed me about our systematic approach: even in the middle of debugging and recovery, we maintained documentation discipline.

Five documentation files got updated with the lessons learned:

  • architecture.md: Docker best practices and data persistence lessons
  • pattern-catalog.md: New patterns discovered through failure
  • technical-spec.md: Workflow execution return structure clarifications
  • data-model.md: Model distinctions and relationship loading guidance
  • api-reference.md: Actual response structures vs. expected ones

Documentation under pressure is different from documentation during smooth development. It captures not just what works, but what fails and why.

Resilience vs. robustness

Battle-testing taught me the difference between robust systems and resilient systems.

Robust systems are designed to avoid failures. They have comprehensive error handling, validation, and safety checks.

Resilient systems are designed to recover from failures gracefully. They assume failures will happen and provide systematic ways to detect, diagnose, and recover from them.

Our GitHub integration was robustâ€Šâ€”â€Šit handled API failures, missing configuration, and invalid inputs gracefully. But our development environment wasnâ€™t resilientâ€Šâ€”â€Šit had hidden dependencies and fragile data persistence that made recovery difficult.

Both matter. But resilience, it turns out, is what lets you sleep at night.

Discovering hidden brittleness

The most sobering lesson was realizing how much hidden brittleness existed in what seemed like a solid system.

Environment brittleness: Dependencies on specific directory names and paths

Data brittleness: Persistence strategies that broke under common operations

Configuration brittleness: Setup assumptions that werenâ€™t documented

Tool brittleness: Version dependencies that werenâ€™t explicit

None of these showed up during normal development. They only became visible when we needed to recover from failures or recreate the environment from scratch. Much of this no doubt can be attributed to my not being a true developer and not having developed many good habits yet, but Iâ€™ve been getting a crash course!

This is why you need to battle-test early and often. Not just to find bugs, but to find fragilities.

Systematic recoveryÂ methods

What saved us during the recovery wasnâ€™t having perfect systemsâ€Šâ€”â€Šit was having systematic approaches to recovery.

Git discipline: Everything important was committed and pushed to remote repositories

Documentation culture: Even informal setup notes were preserved in README files

Environment isolation: Docker meant we could recreate infrastructure without affecting the host system

Pattern recognition: Previous recovery experiences provided templates for this one

The systematic approach to development weâ€™d been building included systematic approaches to recovery.

The infrastructure as code revelation

One of the most valuable outcomes of the battle-testing session was realizing we needed to treat our development environment as code as well, not just as accumulated configuration knowledge.

Before: Incremental setup with manual configuration

After: Reproducible environment defined in version-controlled files

# Everything defined explicitly
version: '3.8'
services:
  postgres:
    image: postgres:15
    environment:
      POSTGRES_DB: ${POSTGRES_DB}
      POSTGRES_USER: ${POSTGRES_USER}
      POSTGRES_PASSWORD: ${POSTGRES_PASSWORD}
    volumes:
      - piper_postgres_data:/var/lib/postgresql/data
    healthcheck:
      test: ["CMD-SHELL", "pg_isready"]
      interval: 30s
      timeout: 10s
      retries: 5

This approach makes failures recoverable and environments reproducible.

The testingÂ pyramid

The battle-testing experience also revealed gaps in our testing strategy. We had good unit tests and integration tests, but we were missing environment testsâ€Šâ€”â€Štests that verify the system can be set up and torn down reliably.

Unit tests: Individual components work correctly âœ…

Integration tests: Components work together correctly âœ…

Environment tests: System can be deployed and operated reliably âŒ

That missing layer is what allowed environment brittleness to accumulate without being detected.

Real-world systems need all three layers to be truly reliable.

When failure becomes feature discovery

The most unexpected outcome of the battle-testing session was discovering features we didnâ€™t know weâ€™d built.

During recovery, we realized that our error handling was actually quite sophisticated. The system degraded gracefully when GitHub wasnâ€™t available, provided helpful error messages when configuration was missing, and maintained functionality even when external services failed.

Weâ€™d built resilient features without realizing it, because weâ€™d followed good patterns consistently.

Sometimes you donâ€™t know how good your architecture is until you stress-test it.

Thanks, past us!

The compound value of systematic approaches

Looking back at the battle-testing session, what struck me most was how the systematic approaches weâ€™d been developing throughout the week compounded to help with recovery.

Systematic documentation meant we could reconstruct what weâ€™d built Systematic testing meant we could verify recovery quickly Systematic patterns meant we could rebuild missing pieces following established approachesÂ 
Systematic git discipline meant we never lost source code, even when local environments failed

Each individual practice was helpful. Together, they made recovery almost routine instead of catastrophic.

Operational maturity

Battle-testing marked a transition from development maturity to operational maturity. We stopped thinking just about whether code worked and started thinking about whether systems could be operated reliably.

Development questions: Does the feature work? Are the tests passing? Is the code clean?

Operational questions: Can this be deployed reliably? What happens when it fails? How do we recover from problems? How do we detect issues before users do?

Both sets of questions matter, but operational maturity is what separates hobby projects from production systems.

The documentation debt thatÂ helps

One unexpected discovery was that some of our â€œdocumentation debtâ€ was actually helpful during recovery. Informal notes, commit messages, and even commented-out code provided context about decisions weâ€™d forgotten making.

Not all documentation needs to be polished and comprehensive. Sometimes breadcrumbs are enough to help you retrace your steps when you need to understand how something broke.

Formal documentation: Architectural decisions, API contracts, deployment procedures

Informal documentation: Debug notes, commit messages, TODO comments

Living documentation: Code that explains itself through good naming and structure

All three types proved valuable during battle-testing.

Bringing it allÂ home

This battle-testing session completed a sequence that started with architectural cleanup, continued through systematic implementation, and ended with real-world validation.

Each phase taught different lessons:

  • Cleanup: Face technical debt honestly and systematically
  • Implementation: Follow established patterns instead of reinventing
  • Testing: Build and document resilience, not just robustness
  • Battle-testing: Validate operational maturity, not just development maturity

Together, they represent a complete cycle from architectural confusion to operational confidence.

When architecture survives contact withÂ reality

The ultimate test of architecture isnâ€™t whether it works in ideal conditions. Itâ€™s whether it survives contact with reality: missing files, corrupted environments, operator errors, and unexpected failures.

Our systematic approach to development survived this test. Not because we didnâ€™t encounter failures, but because weâ€™d built systematic approaches to recovery alongside systematic approaches to development.

This is what mature engineering looks like: not the absence of problems, but the presence of systematic solutions to inevitable problems.

The resilience dividend

The battle-testing session was frustrating while it was happening, but it paid a resilience dividend immediately. The next time we encountered environment issues, database problems, or configuration errors, we had established patterns for diagnosing and recovering from them.

More importantly, we had confidence that the system could survive operator errors, environment changes, and deployment challenges.

That confidence is worth more than perfect code. Perfect code thatâ€™s fragile to operate is less valuable than good code thatâ€™s resilient to operate.

The operational documentation discipline

One of the most valuable outcomes was establishing operational documentation as a first-class concern, not an afterthought.

Deployment procedures: Exactly how to get the system running from scratch

Recovery procedures: What to do when specific things go wrong

Troubleshooting guides: Common problems and their solutions

Environment management: How to maintain and update the development environment

This documentation proved its value immediately during recovery. Itâ€™ll prove its value again when team members need to set up environments or when we need to deploy to new infrastructure.

Plus, remember these bots can read a lot of docs too and not just spew them out. Most of us human find technical specs a bit overwhelming if they are properly thorough. TL;DR kicks in fast. But AI bots just lap that stuff up.

Stacking discipline on top ofÂ rigor

What made the battle-testing session ultimately successful wasnâ€™t any single decisionâ€Šâ€”â€Šit was the compound effects of systematic discipline across multiple areas.

Git discipline preserved our work when local environments failed

Documentation discipline provided recovery procedures

Testing discipline let us verify recovery quickly

Pattern discipline made rebuilding predictable

Each discipline was helpful individually. Together, they created a development approach that was antifragile: it got stronger when stressed instead of weaker.

0822585cb51a.title: Following Your Own Patterns
0822585cb51a.subtitle: June 28, 2025
0822585cb51a.content:
Following Your OwnÂ Patterns

June 28, 2025

Hereâ€™s what happened when we went to add GitHub integration to Piper Morgan: it took about an hour, and most of that was just writing the tests.

Not because GitHub integration is simple (though their API is quite nice). Not because we cut corners or built something half-baked. But because weâ€™d finally reached that magical state where your architecture makes new features feel inevitable rather than difficult.

This is the story of what it looks like when you start following your own patterns instead of fighting them.

Building on clean foundations

Coming off our technical debt cleanup from a couple days earlierâ€Šâ€”â€Šwhere weâ€™d consolidated two orchestration systems into one and actually wrote tests for the system we were usingâ€Šâ€”â€ŠI was ready to tackle GitHub integration.

The plan was straightforward: enable users to say â€œcreate a ticket for this bugâ€ and have Piper automatically create a properly formatted GitHub issue in the right repository with all the relevant context.

This was something the prototype was doing on, like, itâ€™s second day, so I was pretty excited to be getting this MVP feature working in â€œthe real thing.â€

What I didnâ€™t expect was how obvious the implementation path would be once we started following the patterns weâ€™d already established.

Architecture that teaches you how to useÂ it

Good architecture is like a well-designed kitchen: once you understand the layout, everything has a logical place and the workflow feels natural.

When we started looking at GitHub integration, the OrchestrationEngine pattern weâ€™d been developing basically told us exactly what to do:

  1. Task handlers manage specific types of work
  2. Context enrichment happens during workflow creation
  3. Repository pattern keeps external integrations separate from business logic
  4. Error handling follows established domain contracts

We didnâ€™t have to invent new patterns. We just had to follow the ones weâ€™d already discovered worked.

The pattern recognitionâ€Šâ€”â€Šseeing how GitHub integration could fit into our existing approach â€”came from having clean, consistent architecture to work from.

The internal task handler revelation

The first decision point was where to put the GitHub integration logic. In our earlier technical debt cleanup, weâ€™d established that OrchestrationEngine was our canonical orchestration system. But how should new task types connect to it? We had three choices:

  1. Create separate GitHubTaskHandler classes
  2. Build handlers as internal methods within OrchestrationEngine
  3. Create some hybrid plugin architecture

When we looked at how file analysis was already integrated, the answer was obvious: OrchestrationEngine used internal methods, not separate handler classes.

# The pattern we'd already established:
self.task_handlers = {
    TaskType.ANALYZE_FILE: self._analyze_file,
    TaskType.PROCESS_CONTENT: self._process_content
}

# So GitHub integration became:
self.task_handlers[TaskType.GITHUB_CREATE_ISSUE] = self._create_github_issue

This wasnâ€™t a grand architectural decisionâ€Šâ€”â€Šit was just following the pattern that was already working.

The context enrichment pattern

The second insight came when we thought about user experience. Nobody wants to specify which repository to create an issue in every time they ask for a ticket. The system should just know.

But how do you â€œjust knowâ€ which repository to use without requiring users to specify it every time?

The answer was hiding in plain sight: we already had a context enrichment pattern from file analysis. When a workflow gets created, we automatically look up and add relevant context that the task handlers will need.

For GitHub integration, that meant:

  • Look up the projectâ€™s GitHub integration configuration
  • Find the repository associated with the project
  • Add that repository context to the workflow automatically
  • Let the task handler just use the context thatâ€™s already there
# Context enrichment during workflow creation
if workflow.type == WorkflowType.CREATE_TICKET:
    github_config = await self._get_github_config(project_id)
    if github_config:
        workflow.context["repository"] = github_config.repository

Seamless user experience through systematic context management.

When patterns accelerate development

Hereâ€™s what was remarkable about following our established patterns: the implementation work became almost mechanical.

Task registration: Add the task type to the enum, map it to the handler method

Handler implementation: Follow the established signature (workflow, task) â†’ TaskResult

Error handling: Return results with error metadata, never throw exceptions

Testing: Write tests that verify the handler behavior, not the internal implementation

We didnâ€™t have to make architectural decisions because the architecture had already been decided. We didnâ€™t have to debate error handling approaches because weâ€™d already established the domain contract. We didnâ€™t have to figure out how to structure tests because we had working examples.

The result: GitHub integration that felt like a natural extension of the system rather than something bolted on.

The repository context enrichment insight

The most elegant part of the implementation was the repository context enrichment. Users can just say â€œcreate a ticketâ€ without specifying where, and the system figures it out automatically.

But hereâ€™s the architectural insight: this works because we designed it as a non-blocking enrichment. If the system canâ€™t find GitHub configuration for a project, it doesnâ€™t fail the workflow creationâ€Šâ€”â€Šit just logs a warning and lets the task handler deal with the missing context gracefully.

This pattern enables a much better user experience:

  • Power users get automatic repository detection
  • New users get helpful error messages about missing configuration
  • The system remains functional even when integrations arenâ€™t perfectly set up
# Non-blocking enrichment pattern
try:
    repository = await self._lookup_repository(project_id)
    workflow.context["repository"] = repository
except ConfigurationError:
    logger.warning(f"No GitHub repository configured for project {project_id}")
    # Workflow continues without repository context

Graceful degradation built into the architecture from the start.

Getting disciplined about documentation

Once the implementation was working, we had a choice: ship it and move on, or take the time to document what weâ€™d learned.

This is where following your own patterns really pays off. Weâ€™d established during our technical debt cleanup that architectural discoveries should be documented immediately, not â€œwhen we have time later.â€

So we updated six different documentation files:

  • architecture.md: GitHub integration status and new patterns
  • pattern-catalog.md: Internal Task Handler Pattern and Repository Context Enrichment Pattern
  • technical-spec.md: Orchestration details and GitHub examples
  • data-model.md: Workflow context structures
  • api-reference.md: GitHub-specific usage examples
  • api-specification.md: Complete API contracts

Six files. In one session. Because weâ€™d learned that architectural insights are fragileâ€Šâ€”â€Šif you donâ€™t capture them immediately, you lose the context that made them insights in the first place. Plus, letâ€™s face it, bots write docs fast.

Pattern discovery vs. pattern following

What struck me about this session was the difference between discovering patterns (what weâ€™d been doing in earlier development) and following patterns (what we were doing now).

Pattern discovery is hard work: lots of false starts, architectural decisions, refactoring when you realize your first approach doesnâ€™t scale. Pattern following isâ€¦ well, itâ€™s almost easy. Not because the work itself is simple, but because the decisions have already been made. Youâ€™re implementing, not architecting.

This is what good architecture gets you: it makes the next feature obvious.

The compound effects of consistency

By following established patterns instead of inventing new ones, we got several benefits we didnâ€™t expect:

Testing became routine: Same patterns as file analysis testing, just different inputs and outputs

Error handling was automatic: Domain contract already established, just needed to follow it

Integration felt natural: New functionality flowed through existing orchestration without friction

Documentation was straightforward: Adding to established pattern catalogs rather than documenting entirely new approaches

Most importantly: the next developer (including future us) would immediately understand how GitHub integration worked, because it followed the same patterns as everything else in the system.

When architecture becomes invisible

The best architecture is invisible architecture. Not because you canâ€™t see it, but because it feels so natural that you stop thinking about it.

During this GitHub integration session, we spent very little time making architectural decisions. Instead, we spent time implementing features, writing tests, and documenting patterns.

The architecture had become the foundation for work rather than the subject of work.

This is what systematic architectural cleanup gets you: the ability to focus on solving user problems instead of solving architectural problems.

The â€œInternal Task Handlerâ€Â pattern

One of the patterns we documented was the â€œInternal Task Handler Patternâ€â€Šâ€”â€Šthe decision to implement task handlers as methods within OrchestrationEngine rather than separate classes.

This wasnâ€™t a grand architectural vision. It emerged from practical considerations:

  • Simpler architecture: Fewer files, fewer abstractions to maintain
  • Direct access: Task handlers can access engine state and dependencies directly
  • Easier testing: Test the orchestration engine as a unit, not a collection of loosely coupled handlers

But documenting it as a pattern meant future integrations could follow the same approach without having to rediscover the reasoning.

Sometimes the best architectural decisions are the ones you donâ€™t have to make because someone (even if it was past you) already made them thoughtfully.

The â€œRepository Context Enrichmentâ€ pattern

The other pattern we documented was â€œRepository Context Enrichmentâ€â€Šâ€”â€Šthe automatic lookup and injection of GitHub repository information during workflow creation.

This pattern enables the â€œjust worksâ€ user experience: say â€œcreate a ticketâ€ and the system figures out where to create it based on your project configuration.

But the pattern is more general: context enrichment can apply to any external integration where users shouldnâ€™t have to specify configuration details every time they want to use a feature.

Future integrations (Slack, Jira, email) can follow the same pattern: look up configuration during workflow creation, inject context automatically, handle missing configuration gracefully.

What following patterns teachesÂ you

Following your own patterns teaches you things about your system that you didnâ€™t know you knew.

Consistency compounds: When every integration follows the same approach, the cognitive load for adding new integrations decreases over time

Documentation matters: Patterns only help if theyâ€™re documented well enough for future developers to follow

Error handling is architecture: How you handle missing configuration or failed operations is as important as how you handle success cases

User experience is systematic: Good UX comes from consistent system behavior, not just individual feature polish

Most importantly: good patterns make good features feel inevitable. Users donâ€™t think â€œwow, the GitHub integration is so well-architected.â€ They think â€œof course creating tickets works exactly like I expected it to.â€

The velocity paradox: speedÂ soothes

Hereâ€™s the paradox of following patterns: the session where we added GitHub integration felt almost boring compared to our earlier architectural discovery sessions.

No major insights. No breakthrough moments. No complex problems to solve. Justâ€¦ implementing a feature according to established patterns and documenting what we learned.

But that â€œboringâ€ implementation session was actually the payoff for all the earlier architectural work. The ability to add significant functionality without drama is what good architecture provides.

Sometimes the most productive sessions are the ones where you donâ€™t have to solve any architectural problems because youâ€™ve already solved them.

Building patternÂ literacy

One thing this session reminded me is that pattern literacyâ€Šâ€”â€Šthe ability to recognize and follow established approachesâ€Šâ€”â€Šis a different skill from pattern discovery. And Iâ€™m an old pattern guy from way back!

Pattern discovery requires architectural thinking, systems perspective, willingness to experiment and refactor.

Pattern following requires discipline, attention to detail, and the humility to implement rather than innovate when innovation isnâ€™t needed.

Both skills are essential. But knowing when to use which skill might be the most important skill of all.

The systematic documentation payoff

Updating six documentation files in one session might seem like overhead, but it paid immediate dividends. When we tested the GitHub integration the next day and ran into issues, the documentation weâ€™d written helped us debug problems and understand the intended behavior.

Good documentation isnâ€™t just helpful for other developersâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s helpful for you, debugging your own code weeks later when youâ€™ve forgotten the design decisions that seemed obvious at the time.

Plus, systematic documentation discipline means you never lose architectural insights. The Internal Task Handler Pattern and Repository Context Enrichment Pattern are now part of our permanent architectural toolkit, not just â€œsomething we did that one time.â€

The seriesÂ arc

Looking back at the sequence of sessionsâ€Šâ€”â€Štechnical debt cleanup, test guidance, and now systematic implementationâ€Šâ€”â€ŠI can see how each session built on the previous ones.

Clean architecture (from debt cleanup) enabled test guidance (domain contract clarity) which enabled pattern following (systematic implementation).

None of these sessions would have worked as well in isolation. But together, they created a compound effect where each improvement made the next improvement easier.

When good architecture feels effortless

The best measure of good architecture isnâ€™t how impressive it looks in diagrams. Itâ€™s how effortless it makes future development feel.

After this GitHub integration session, I had confidence that the next integration (whatever it might be) would follow similar patterns and feel similarly straightforward. Not because the individual features would be simple, but because the architectural decisions wouldnâ€™t need to be re-made.

This is what â€œfollowing your own patternsâ€ really means: building on your past good decisions instead of starting over every time.

c00a94c09c2c.title: When Your Tests Tell You What Your Code Should Do
c00a94c09c2c.subtitle: June 27
c00a94c09c2c.content:
When Your Tests Tell You What Your Code ShouldÂ Do

June 27

We were down to just two failing tests out of 64, and my first instinct was what it always is when tests fail after escaping a crisis: these tests must be wrong.

I mean, it made sense. Weâ€™d just come through the 48-hour rollercoasterâ€Šâ€”â€Šthat epic journey to complete disaster and back with from â€œLIFE SAVERÂ !!!â€ redemption. The system was working. File uploads were processing. Analysis was running end-to-end. Surely a couple of stubborn test failures were justâ€¦ artifacts from the chaos.

Turns out, the tests werenâ€™t wrong. They were trying to teach me about my own architecture.

Coming back fromÂ chaos

After the 48-hour rollercoaster, we had msfr this beautiful recovery: 64 tests, clean architecture, everything working. But when I ran the full suite, 2 tests were still failing in the DocumentAnalyzer.

Classic developer reaction: â€œWell, those tests are probably just outdated expectations from before we fixed everything.â€

The failing tests were complaining that DocumentAnalyzer was throwing FileAnalysisError exceptions instead of returning AnalysisResult objects with error metadata. My first thought? â€œThese tests just havenâ€™t been updated to match our new exception-handling approach.â€

So I started to â€œfixâ€ the tests. (Always a bad instinct.)

The moment everything clicked

But then I did something I donâ€™t always remember to do: I looked at the other analyzers to see what pattern they were actually following (OK, I asked Cursor to look and tell me).

  • CSVAnalyzer: Returns AnalysisResult with error info in metadata.
  • TextAnalyzer: Returns AnalysisResult with error info in metadata.
  • DocumentAnalyzer: Throws FileAnalysisError exceptions.

Hmm.

One of these things was not like the others.

Thatâ€™s when it hit me: the tests werenâ€™t wrong about what they expected. DocumentAnalyzer was doing it wrong.

Tests as architectural documentation

Hereâ€™s what I learned from those two â€œfailingâ€ tests: they werenâ€™t testing what the code currently did. They were documenting what the code should do according to our domain model.

The AnalysisResult domain object was designed with a clear contract: analyzers always return results, with errors going into the metadata field. Never throw exceptions. Always return something useful.

CSVAnalyzer and TextAnalyzer were following this contract perfectly. But somewhere along the wayâ€Šâ€”â€Šprobably during one of those frantic â€œletâ€™s just get this workingâ€ momentsâ€Šâ€”â€Šsomeone (okay, it was probably me) had allowed DocumentAnalyzer to throw exceptions instead.

The tests were trying to tell me: â€œHey, you have a domain contract here. DocumentAnalyzer is violating it.â€

When code drifts from intention

This is one of those subtle ways systems drift from their original intentions. Itâ€™s not dramatic architectural decayâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s just inconsistency. One component doing things slightly differently from its siblings.

But that inconsistency compounds. Today itâ€™s â€œDocumentAnalyzer throws exceptions while everyone else returns error metadata.â€ Tomorrow itâ€™s â€œwell, some analyzers throw exceptions, so I guess PDFAnalyzer can too.â€ Before you know it, your error handling is a mess and nobody remembers what the original pattern was supposed to be.

Mind you, this kind of drift happens to everyone. Especially when youâ€™re moving fast, fixing urgent issues, or trying to get something working after a crisis. The question is whether you catch it before it spreads.

The beauty of domain contracts

What struck me about this whole episode was how clear the domain contract actually was, once I paid attention to it.

AnalysisResult was designed to always be returned. Success or failure, you get an AnalysisResult object. If something went wrong, the error information goes in the metadata field, but you still get a proper result object with whatever analysis could be completed.

This isnâ€™t just a nice-to-have pattern. Itâ€™s what allows the rest of the system to handle analysis results consistently, regardless of which analyzer produced them or whether everything went perfectly.

When DocumentAnalyzer started throwing exceptions instead, it broke that contract. The calling code had to start handling two different error patterns: sometimes you get an AnalysisResult with error metadata, sometimes you get an exception. Thatâ€™s cognitive overhead for every developer who touches the code.

Following the testÂ guidance

So instead of changing the tests to match the exception-throwing behavior, I changed DocumentAnalyzer to honor the domain contract.

The fix was straightforward: wrap the analysis logic in try-catch, and when things go wrong, return an AnalysisResult with the error information in metadata instead of throwing the exception.

# Before: Contract violation
if analysis_failed:
    raise FileAnalysisError("Analysis failed")

# After: Honoring domain contract  
if analysis_failed:
    return AnalysisResult(
        content_type="document",
        metadata={"error": "Analysis failed"}
    )

The moment I made that change: 64/64 tests passing.

Tests as conversation partners

What this experience taught me is that tests can be conversation partners in architectural decisions, not just validators of current behavior.

When tests fail, especially after a period of rapid change, the question isnâ€™t just â€œwhat do I need to change to make this pass?â€ Itâ€™s â€œwhat is this test trying to tell me about my systemâ€™s intentions?â€

Those two â€œfailingâ€ tests werenâ€™t obstacles to overcome. They were documentation of a better way to structure error handling across the analysis layer. They were architectural guidance disguised as test failures.

The largerÂ pattern

This connects to something larger about how tests function in a mature codebase. Good tests donâ€™t just verify that code worksâ€Šâ€”â€Šthey document what â€œworkingâ€ means according to your systemâ€™s design principles.

When you write tests, youâ€™re not just checking current behavior. Youâ€™re encoding architectural intentions. Youâ€™re creating a conversation between your current understanding and your future selfâ€™s implementation decisions.

The pattern recognitionâ€Šâ€”â€Šseeing that DocumentAnalyzer was the outlierâ€Šâ€”â€Šcame from slowing down enough to actually look at what the tests were expecting versus what the code was doing.

When to trust yourÂ tests

So when should you trust your tests over your code? Here are some signals Iâ€™ve learned to watch for:

Trust tests when: Theyâ€™re checking domain contracts, not just implementation details. When multiple similar components follow one pattern and one outlier follows another. When tests are failing after rapid changes or crisis periods.

Question tests when: Theyâ€™re testing implementation details that could reasonably change. When theyâ€™re checking specific error messages instead of error handling patterns. When they were written for a different phase of the projectâ€™s evolution.

The key is learning to distinguish between tests that encode architectural wisdom and tests that encode temporary implementation choices.

The 64/64Â moment

Thereâ€™s something satisfying about seeing 64/64 tests pass after making an architectural decision based on test guidance. Itâ€™s not just â€œyay, green checkmarks.â€ Itâ€™s validation that your system has a coherent design philosophy, and that your tests are documenting it accurately.

That moment when DocumentAnalyzer fell into line with the established pattern, and suddenly all the error handling across the analysis layer was consistentâ€Šâ€”â€Šthatâ€™s what good architecture feels like. Not perfect code, but coherent code.

Listening to yourÂ codebase

The broader lesson here is about listening to your codebase. Tests are one way it talks to you. Patterns across similar components are another. Inconsistencies that make you pause and think â€œwait, why does this one work differently?â€â€Šâ€”â€Šthose are conversations waiting to happen.

Your codebase is constantly trying to tell you about its own design principles. Sometimes through test failures. Sometimes through code that feels awkward to write. Sometimes through inconsistencies that make onboarding new team members harder than it should be.

The trick is slowing down enough to listen.

7fc3aadc2a3b.title: The Day We Stopped Fighting the System
7fc3aadc2a3b.subtitle: July 3
7fc3aadc2a3b.content:
The Day We Stopped Fighting theÂ System

July 3

The day started with what seemed like a simple mission: complete UI testing for Piper Morgan. You know how these things go by now, Iâ€™m sure? Six hours later, Iâ€™m having philosophical conversations with my Lead Developer about architectural integrity and the nature of document summarization.

Let me walk you through this particular journey into the depths of technical debt, POC contamination, and the humbling realization that sometimes your AI knows better than you do.

The ghost of POCÂ past

We kicked off with what looked like a straightforward import error:

ImportError: cannot import name 'WorkflowDefinition' from 'services.domain.models'

â€œThis should be quick,â€ I thought. Famous last words, right?

What we uncovered was a classic case of POC haunting: code from a month-old proof of concept had survived to contaminate the MVP implementation. The POC used input_data and output_data fields, while the production code had moved to context and result. Tests were passing because they were mocked to death, but the actual persistence layer was failing silently.

My gut check to the Lead Developer: â€œAre we still properly following domain-driven design?â€ Often, this question helped nudge us back on track, but this time the answer was yes. Itâ€™s just that weâ€™d allowed POC code corrupt our clean architecture. Time for an exorcism.

The repository thatÂ wasnâ€™t

After successfully removing the POC contamination, we hit our next puzzle. File queries were returning â€œfile not foundâ€ despite the file clearly existing in the database. This led to my favorite exchange of the session:

Lead Developer: [Writes elaborate grep commands to investigate repository patterns]

Me: â€œWhy were you guessing at all? Just ask me for a tree or for files if you need to inspect directly?â€

TouchÃ©. Sometimes the PM needs to remind the architect that they have a human with direct file access right there. (This is one of those things they donâ€™t teach you in distributed team management courses.)

What we discovered was architecturally fascinating: Piper Morgan was using a two-tier data access pattern:

  • Tier 1: Domain entities use SQLAlchemy with session management
  • Tier 2: File operations use raw asyncpg with connection pooling

This wasnâ€™t a bugâ€Šâ€”â€Šit was an intentional performance optimization. Files donâ€™t need ORM overhead. But I hadnâ€™t reviewed the architecture docs recently enough to remember this design â€œdecision.â€

The case of the stubbornÂ LLM

Hereâ€™s where things got genuinely interesting. We wanted document summarization to be a simple QUERY operation. The LLM had other ideas:

Intent classified as - Category: IntentCategory.SYNTHESIS, Action: generate_summary

We updated prompts. We added examples. We restructured the classification logic. The LLM remained unmovedâ€Šâ€”â€Šsummarization was SYNTHESIS, and that was final. I started wonderign if we had someone mistrained something but was assured we werenâ€™t even doing any of our own training yet.

My response: â€œOK backâ€¦ whatâ€™s next? I can do a few more steps then need to run out to pick up dinner.â€

This perfectly captured our incremental approachâ€Šâ€”â€Šlife happens, architecture endures. But also: I was starting to feel that familiar itch of fighting the system instead of listening to it.

The architectural reckoning

As we tried to patch our way to a working summarization feature, I had to drop the wisdom bomb on myself:

â€œI am concerned we may be losing our architectural perspective if we keep patching bugs as we find them.â€

I sometimes feel like the stern papa asking my bots if they really brushed their teeth and washed their hands before bed but the question needed to be asked.

We were fighting the system instead of working with it. The LLM classified summarization as SYNTHESIS because it is synthesisâ€Šâ€”â€Šcreating new content from existing material. Our attempts to force it into a QUERY pattern were architectural hubris.

You know that feeling when youâ€™re trying to force a USB cable in upside down? Thatâ€™s what we were doing to our intent classification system.

The plotÂ twist

The real discovery? SYNTHESIS was completely unimplemented. It had no routing, no handlers, just a generic â€œIâ€™ll help you create thatâ€ response. Weâ€™d been trying to shoehorn functionality into the wrong category when the right category was sitting there, abandoned and waiting.

Itâ€™s like finding out youâ€™ve been trying to unlock your front door with your car key when the right key was in your other pocket the whole time.

Some things I learned (or how systematic thinking saved us from ourselves)

1. Consult architecture docsÂ first

My failure to review the architecture docs cost us investigation time. The two-tier data pattern was documentedâ€Šâ€”â€ŠI just didnâ€™t look. This is the PM equivalent of RTFM, and I earned that lesson the hard way.

2. Work WITH theÂ system

When the intent classifier consistently makes a choice, maybe it knows something we donâ€™t. Document summarization IS synthesis, not a query. Sometimes the AI is trying to tell you something about the nature of the work itself.

3. TDDÂ works

Our FileQueryService succeeded because we followed TDD strictly: Red â†’ Green â†’ Refactor. No shortcuts. The discipline pays off every time, even when (especially when) youâ€™re tempted to skip it.

4. Know when toÂ stop

The moment we started our third â€œquick fix,â€ we should have stopped. Multiple patches indicate architectural work is needed, not more patches.

5. Session logs areÂ critical

I noticed the Lead Developer wasnâ€™t maintaining a session log as I generally ask each bot to do. Creating one, even retrospectively, immediately helped track our journey and decisions. Documentation isnâ€™t bureaucracyâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s institutional memory.

The code weÂ shipped

Despite the challenges, we accomplished significant work:

  • âœ… Removed POC contamination completely
  • âœ… Implemented FileQueryService with proper TDD
  • âœ… Fixed file query routing (discovered file_id vs resolved_file_id mismatch)
  • âœ… Passed UI Tests 1, 2.1, and 2.2
  • âœ… Documented architectural patterns for future reference

The code we didnâ€™tÂ ship

More importantly, we chose NOT to ship a hacky summarization implementation. Instead, we documented exactly what needs to be built:

  • A proper document operations layer
  • TaskType.GENERATE_SUMMARY with an appropriate handler
  • SYNTHESIS category implementation
  • LLM-based summarization service

Sometimes the best code is the code you choose not to write. Know when to fold â€™em and all that, right?

The humanÂ side

This session reminded me why being the primate in the loop working with AI agents is so valuable. My interventions werenâ€™t disruptionsâ€Šâ€”â€Šthey were course corrections:

  • â€œDid my instructions also provide a template for how to structure the instructions for CA?â€
  • â€œLetâ€™s also do an architectural gut checkâ€
  • â€œLetâ€™s stop hereâ€¦ We donâ€™t need to rush to meet an arbitrary cutoff timeâ€

Each intervention prevented technical debt and maintained architectural integrity. Itâ€™s like having a very patient pair programming partner who never gets tired of answering the question, â€œare we sure this is the right approach?â€

The denouement

We ended the session not because we ran out of time, but because we chose to stop. The next session would begin with architectural design, not bug fixes.

This is what systematic thinking looks like in practice: recognizing when youâ€™re fighting the system instead of working with it, and having the discipline to pause and reassess.

Final thought: If your AI assistant argues with you about categorization, maybe listen. It might be trying to tell you something about the nature of the work itself.

Session Stats:

  • Duration: 6 hours (with dinner break)
  • Lines of code: ~200 added, ~150 removed
  • Architectural insights: Priceless
  • Times the system saved us from ourselves: At least 4

437a3ec04316.title: The Day We Taught Piper to Summarize (Almost)
437a3ec04316.subtitle: July 4
437a3ec04316.content:
The Day We Taught Piper to Summarize (Almost)

July 4

A tale of hidden infrastructure, session mysteries, and the importance of actually showing your work

Picture this: UI Test 2.3â€Šâ€”â€Šâ€œDocument Summarization.â€ Should be simple, right? Upload a file, ask for a summary, get a summary. We had spent the entire previous work session wrestling with the workflow and finally realizing we needed to build out the SYNTHESIS function. We were ready to do it the right way. What could go wrong?

Everything, as it turns out. But in the most educational way possible.

Act 1: The syntax error that blocked everything

We started with the API server crashing on startup. The culprit? Two lonely backticks on line 23 of engine.py:

from services.integrations.github.github_agent import GitHubAgent
``
logger = structlog.get_logger()

Those backticks. Just sitting there. Mocking us.

Act 2: The infrastructure we alreadyÂ had

After fixing the syntax error, we went hunting for document operations. I wondered if we needed to build a whole new system for summarization. Then Cursor Agent made a discovery:

CA: â€œI found the exact location where workflow results are handled and the generic â€˜Workflow completed successfully!â€™ message is generatedâ€

But hereâ€™s the twistâ€Šâ€”â€Šwe already HAD a complete document analysis system! Hidden in services/analysis/ was a DocumentAnalyzer that could extract text from PDFs, call an LLM for summarization, and return structured results.

Weâ€™d been prepared to build something that already existed. Classic.

Act 3: Settling the great SYNTHESIS debate

The LLM insisted that â€œsummarize this documentâ€ was a SYNTHESIS operation, not a QUERY. We had tried to fight it. We had considered forcing it. Then I had a moment of clarity:

â€œThanks, that helps me understand a lot better and Iâ€™m much more comfortable with â€˜not fighting it.â€™ Learning, for me, often involved covering some ground a few times until it really sinks in.â€

This led to a philosophical discussion about the nature of LLMs and intent classification. My lead developer clarified again that we werenâ€™t fighting any learned behavior of Piperâ€™s, but Claude (the LLM we were shopping out the analys to) was applying its own training. Summarization IS synthesisâ€Šâ€”â€Šyouâ€™re creating something new. The LLM was architecturally correct, and we were the ones being stubborn.

Act 4: The session IDÂ mystery

Hereâ€™s where it got interesting. The file was uploaded. The workflow was created. But it kept failing with â€œNo file ID found in workflow context.â€

We traced through layers of code:

  • Intent enricher âœ“
  • File resolver âœ“
  • Workflow factory âœ“
  • Session handlingâ€¦ âœ—

The session ID wasnâ€™t being propagated! Files were uploaded with session IDs like session_20250703_161508_10668, but the workflows had no session ID at all.

I wrote â€œThis makes sense as we have continued tests through restarts, etc. But in reality we will need to refer to docs from earlier sessions somehow.â€

Thus turning a bug discovery into an architectural discussion.

Act 5: The multi-word patternÂ problem

Even after fixing session propagation, we hit another snag. The user said â€œPlease summarize that pattern catalog file I just uploadedâ€ but the file reference detector only matched patterns like â€œthat fileâ€ or â€œthat data fileâ€â€Šâ€”â€Šsingle words between â€œthatâ€ and â€œfileâ€.

CA (Cursor Agent) caught this beautifully, explaining how the regex \b(that \w+ file)\b couldn't match "pattern catalog" because it's two words. One regex update later, and we were in business.

The moment ofÂ truth

Finally, (almost) everything clicked:

  1. âœ… File uploaded with session
  2. âœ… Intent classified as SYNTHESIS
  3. âœ… Session ID propagated
  4. âœ… File reference detected
  5. âœ… File resolved to ID
  6. âœ… Analysis completed
  7. âœ… â€œWorkflow completed successfully!â€
  8. â“ Butâ€¦ whereâ€™s the summary?

Amusing interlude

At one point, CA referenced some blog posts about this exact issue. I asked where it was finding the blog post.

CA: The blog posts I was referring to are pm011-blog-post.md and pm011-blog-post-claude-pov!.md in your Downloads folder.

I didnâ€™t recall letting it look in that folder, but points for doing the extra reading! Even our AI assistant was learning from its own history.

The lesson

We succeeded in making the document summarization pipeline work end-to-end. The workflow completes successfully. But thereâ€™s no actual summary displayedâ€Šâ€”â€Šjust a success message.

The bots were ready to declare victory. The human (me) told them that if I donâ€™t actually get to see the summary then the feature is still not working.

Itâ€™s a perfect metaphor for software development: you can have all the pieces working perfectly, but if you donâ€™t show the tree to the user, did it really fall?

Tomorrowâ€™s adventure

The summary is there, somewhere in the workflow context. The response formatting we added should extract it. But somethingâ€™s not quite right. Maybe itâ€™s the file type detection (why was markdown analyzed as a CSV?). Maybe the formatting code isnâ€™t being hit. Maybe the summary is in a different field than expected.

Thatâ€™s tomorrowâ€™s mystery. Today, we celebrate that we can upload a file, reference it naturally, and have it analyzed by an LLM. The pipeline works. We just need to show our work.

My parting (lazy) wisdom: â€œLetâ€™s also make a note down the road (probably post-MVP) to make error messages that speak to what part of a process actually failed, in some natural language way.â€

Indeed. â€œTASK_FAILEDâ€ helps no one. Happy Fourth of July! Today we celebrated independence from generic success messages (almost).

336d98a417e4.title: The Real Bugs Live in the UI (A Testing Reality Check)
336d98a417e4.subtitle: July 1
336d98a417e4.content:
The Real Bugs Live in the UI (A Testing RealityÂ Check)

July 1

After weeks of building sophisticated architecture, implementing AI reasoning, and solving complex integration challenges, I sat down to run four simple UI tests.

How hard could that be?

Test 1: Can it sayÂ hello?

First challenge: The web UI wasnâ€™t running.

Failed to fetch: Connection refused on port 8081

Oh. Right. The web server needs to beâ€¦ started. Separately. Because itâ€™s a separate FastAPI app that serves the frontend.

bash

cd web
uvicorn app:app --host 0.0.0.0 --port 8081

There we go. UI loads. But waitâ€Šâ€”â€Šwhereâ€™s the logo? Just a ğŸ¤– emoji staring back at me. Didnâ€™t I just add that? Made a note to fix it later. First, the tests.

â€œHow are you?â€ I typed.

The response was perfectly professional, task-oriented, and slightly cold. Exactly as designed. We built a PM assistant, not a friend. Working as intended.

Test 1: âœ…

The CORSÂ dance

Tried to continue testing but got hit with the classic â€œFailed to Fetchâ€ error. Not connection refused this timeâ€Šâ€”â€ŠCORS.

I was accessing the UI via http://0.0.0.0:8081 but the API expected http://localhost:8081. Same machine, same port, different origin according to CORS.

Twenty minutes of my life Iâ€™ll never get back, debugging why identical addresses arenâ€™t identical.

Solution: Use localhost. Always use localhost.

I swear, one month or so into this project, that I had by then spent more time chasing environment issues than writing fresh code or fixing actual bugs.

Test 2: The file uploadÂ saga

Time to test file uploads. This had four subcases:

  1. Basic upload
  2. Give context about a file
  3. Give instructions about a file
  4. Use file as reference for GitHub issue

Uploaded a file. Got back a UUID. Success!

Asked â€œWhatâ€™s in the file I just uploaded?â€

Error: 'Workflow' object has no attribute 'input_data'

Wait, what? This was working last week.

The bug huntÂ begins

Started digging. The intent was recognized correctly. The workflow was created. But when it tried to persist to the databaseâ€¦ boom.

Domain model vs database model mismatch. Classic.

Dug deeper. Found another error:

QueryRouter missing conversation_query_service argument

The QueryRouter initialization was incomplete. Missing dependency injection. Another classic.

But the best was yet to come.

The asteriskÂ incident

Deep in the orchestration engine, on line 483, Claude found this:

async def *analyze*file(self, workflow: Workflow, task: Task) -> TaskResult:

Those arenâ€™t underscores. Those are asterisks. In a method name.

This turned out to be a red herring. At this point I was still pasting errors and terminal output into chat windows to get help, and unfortunately the markdown interpreter was reading _analyze_file as analyzefile (treating the underscores as italics, as markdown does) and then de-encoding the italics back to *analyze*file because * is another way of indicating italics in markdown.

There went another half hour of my life till I realized and explained it to Claude and we stopped hunting for nonexistent typos. Shades of the most expensive hyphen in history!

Fixed the logo, atÂ least!

While taking a break between test 2.2 and 2.3, I decided to have Cursor just fix that missing logo, oh and make me a favicon at the same time. (I used to struggle with things like that!)

Found the static file configuration. Cursor added the logo path. Refreshed.

Piper Morganâ€™s dolphin logo smiled back at me from the UI. Sometimes the small victories matter most.

Testing justÂ begunâ€¦

By end of day:

âœ… Test 1: Greeting/chitchatâ€Šâ€”â€ŠPASSED

âš ï¸ Test 2: File uploadâ€Šâ€”â€ŠPARTIAL

  • âœ… 2.1: Basic upload works
  • âŒ 2.2: Context fails (workflow persistence)
  • âŒ 2.3: Instructions fail (asterisk method name)
  • â³ 2.4: Not tested yet

â³ Test 3: Error handlingâ€Šâ€”â€ŠNOT STARTED

â³ Test 4: GitHub integrationâ€Šâ€”â€ŠNOT STARTED

Three major bugs found. Two architectural issues exposed. One logo fixed.

This is what testing really looks like.

Some lessons

  1. The UI is where reality livesâ€Šâ€”â€ŠYour beautiful architecture meets actual users here
  2. Simple tests find real bugsâ€Šâ€”â€ŠForget edge cases; start with â€œdoes it turn on?â€
  3. Environment issues waste more time than logic errorsâ€Šâ€”â€ŠCORS, ports, servers not running

The Coordination Tax: When Copy-Paste Becomes Your Biggest Bottleneck

July 8

Monday morning, and weâ€™re down to what should have been the simplest possible fix: â€œThe UI shows â€˜Workflow completed successfully!â€™ instead of the actual document summary. Should be a quick fix.â€

But the real revelation wasnâ€™t about the bugs themselvesâ€Šâ€”â€Šit was about the coordination tax I was paying with every copy-paste, every context switch, every â€œlet me check the logsâ€ round trip.

By the end, I had a working document summarizer and a visceral understanding of why developer tools that reduce coordination overhead arenâ€™t just nice-to-haveâ€Šâ€”â€Štheyâ€™re essential for maintaining both development velocity and developer sanity.

I maybe should have picked up on this earlier. Iâ€™m a product manager. Itâ€™s glue work. Coordinating work and the people (or, I guess, entities) doing it? Thtatâ€™s my bread and butter. OK, sometimes I am slow.

The cascadeÂ resumes

What followed was a perfect demonstration of how integration bugs cascade through a system, each fix revealing the next issue lurking beneath like sedimentary layers of technical debt:

Bug 1: The UI displayÂ illusion

  • Symptom: Generic success message instead of summary
  • Assumed fix: Update JavaScript to show response.message
  • Reality: The data structure was fundamentally wrong
  • Coordination cost: 5 copy-paste cycles to discover this

Bug 2: Data structure mismatch

  • Symptom: workflow.result.data was completely empty
  • Discovery: Backend stored unwrapped data, frontend expected wrapped
  • Fix applied: Wrap the data properly in the result envelope
  • New problem: â€œNo file ID found in workflow contextâ€
  • Coordination cost: Another 3 round trips through logs and database queries

Bug 3: File ID resolution chaos

  • Symptom: File analyzer couldnâ€™t find the file to analyze
  • Root cause: Intent enricher used probable_file_id, engine looked for file_id
  • Fix applied: Support both field names with fallback logic
  • New problem: Still getting basic statistics, not actual summaries
  • Coordination cost: Grep commands through multiple services, more log diving

Bug 4: The missing LLMÂ client

  • Symptom: TextAnalyzer only returned â€œ115 lines, 559 wordsâ€
  • Investigation: TextAnalyzer HAD summarization code but llm_client was None
  • Root cause: AnalyzerFactory() called without passing the LLM client
  • Fix applied: AnalyzerFactory(llm_client=self.llm_client)
  • New problem: â€˜LLMClientâ€™ object has no attribute â€˜summarizeâ€™

Bug 5: The method that neverÂ was

  • Symptom: AttributeError on llm_client.summarize()
  • Investigation: TextAnalyzer calling non-existent method
  • Worse discovery: DocumentAnalyzer ALSO calling non-existent methods
  • Reality check: Nobody had ever successfully called the LLM for document analysis

Bug 6: The final fix (finally!)

  • Correct pattern: await self.llm_client.complete(task_type="analyze_file", prompt=...)
  • Applied to: Both TextAnalyzer AND DocumentAnalyzer
  • Result: Finally, actual LLM-powered summaries!

Each fix felt like victory until the next problem revealed itself. Itâ€™s like debugging whack-a-mole, but the moles are architectural assumptions you didnâ€™t know you were making.

The real cost of coordination

This session perfectly illustrated why coordination overhead is the hidden killer of development productivity:

What actually happened:

  • 2 hours of debugging time
  • 15â€“20 copy-paste cycles between logs, UI, and code
  • Multiple context switches as each fix revealed the next problem
  • 6 sequential bugs discovered one at a time
  • Growing frustration with each â€œone small fixâ€

What could have happened with better tooling:

  • Direct navigation: â€œShow me how DocumentAnalyzer calls the LLMâ€
  • Instant verification: â€œDoes LLMClient have a summarize method?â€
  • Dependency tracing: â€œWhere is AnalyzerFactory instantiated?â€
  • Estimated time: 30 minutes with high confidence

The difference isnâ€™t just about speedâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s about maintaining context and flow. Every copy-paste cycle is a mini context switch that forces you to rebuild your mental model of the system.

Imagine if you had to drive a car with someone else looking of the windshield and telling you whatâ€™s coming? Thatâ€™s what it felt like.

Architectural lessons from theÂ trenches

My pain is your education, though. Iâ€™m sharing my adventures in part to save other people the time of making my mistakes.

1. Integration points are where bugsÂ hide

Every component boundary in our system had a hidden mismatch:

  • API â†’ UI: Data structure assumptions
  • Orchestrator â†’ Analyzer: Missing dependencies
  • Analyzer â†’ LLM: Wrong method names

The individual components all worked perfectly. The bugs lived entirely in the handshakes between them.

2. Assumptions are expensive

  • The UI was the only problem
  • Data structures matched across layers
  • LLM methods existed because code called them
  • One component working meant the pipeline worked

Each assumption cost 15â€“30 minutes of debugging time. And each one felt reasonable until it wasnâ€™t.

3. Simple verification isÂ powerful

  • grep -n "message" web/app.py
  • grep -n "to_domain" repositories/
  • grep -n "llm_client" services/analysis/
  • grep -n "summarize" services/llm/

But without direct file access, each verification required a copy-paste round trip through a human intermediary (me). The friction compounds quickly.

The beautiful irony

Want to know the best part? The first document our finally-working summarizer processed was an Architecture Decision Record about adopting Claude Code to reduce coordination overhead.

(I was starting to twig to the value of letting Claude see my code directly, so I asked my chief architect bot to propose a plan for adopting Code and gave it the data from these sessions to make the case.)

The AI understood the assignment perfectly, summarizing how Claude Code â€œpromises complete implementation traces, self-directed task completion, architectural rule enforcement, and reduced context switching.â€

We had just spent two hours proving exactly why we need better tooling. The universe has a sense of humor about these things.

The coordination tax isÂ real

This debugging session wasnâ€™t a failureâ€Šâ€”â€Šit was data. Real, visceral data about the hidden costs of coordination overhead in modern development.

Every copy-paste operation is a tax on your cognitive resources. Every context switch between logs and code breaks your mental model. Every â€œlet me check thatâ€ conversation is a tiny friction that seems harmless in isolation but compounds into hours of lost productivity.

When youâ€™re building complex systems with multiple AI agents or even just working with traditional tools, the coordination tax can easily become your biggest bottleneck. Not the complexity of the problems, not the technical challenges, but the simple friction of moving information between contexts.

Moving forward with systematic approaches

The document summarization feature works now, and it works well. But more importantly, we have a perfect case study for why systematic approaches to reducing coordination overhead arenâ€™t just productivity improvementsâ€Šâ€”â€Štheyâ€™re essential for maintaining development sanity.

Sometimes you have to experience the pain to truly appreciate the solution. Two hours of copy-paste debugging has a way of crystallizing exactly what needs to be fixed in your development workflow.

7aaec260ede5.subtitle: July 7
7aaec260ede5.content:
The Debugging Cascade: A 90-Minute Journey Through Integration Hell

July 7

Sunday morning, and Iâ€™m staring at handoff notes that read: â€œThe document summarization feature is one line away from working.â€ The pipeline processed files, generated summaries, stored them in the database. All we needed was to display them to the user.

As a lazy writer I know is prone to say: Famous last words, right?

Ninety minutes later, Iâ€™d traversed five architectural layers, discovered three separate bugs, and learned a profound lesson about how distributed systems fail at their most interesting boundaries.

Spoiler alert: it was indeed one line of code. But finding that line required an archaeological expedition through our entire integration stack.

The symptom that wouldnâ€™tÂ die

â€œThe summary isnâ€™t displaying.â€

That was it. One symptom. But like the mythical hydra, every time we chopped off one cause, two more appeared in its place. The fascinating part? Each layer of the system was working perfectly in isolation. The bugs lived in the spaces betweenâ€Šâ€”â€Šthose liminal zones where services shake hands and sometimes fumble the handoff.

This is what makes distributed systems debugging so beautifully maddening. Itâ€™s not enough for your code to work. Everyone elseâ€™s code has to agree with your code about what â€œworkingâ€ means.

Act I: The API returns an error (but everything works)

My first clue came from the browserâ€™s network tab:

{
    "message": "I've completed the analysis but couldn't generate a summary."
}

Wait, what? The logs showed the analysis completed successfully. The summary was generated and stored. The database had the data. So why the pessimistic error message?

Bug #1: The API was checking for the summary in the wrong place. It looked for analysis.get("summary") but received None because the analysis object itself was empty.

But why was the analysis object empty when the database clearly had data? Down the rabbit hole we goâ€¦

Act II: The case of the emptyÂ data

Adding debug logging revealed the plot twist:

DEBUG workflow.result: WorkflowResult(success=False, data={}, error=None)
DEBUG workflow.result.data: {}
DEBUG analysis object: None

The workflow result was completely empty! But the SQL logs told a different story:

UPDATE workflows SET output_data='{"analysis": {"summary": "Text file with 478 lines..."}}'

The data was being saved, but it wasnâ€™t making the round trip back to the API. This sent us deeper into the architectural layers, like spelunking through code that we wrote but suddenly felt foreign.

Act III: The contractÂ mismatch

Hereâ€™s where things got interesting from an architectural perspective. The repository expected data structured like this:

{
    "success": true,
    "data": { /* actual results */ },
    "error": null
}

But the orchestration engine was saving it like this:

{
    "analysis": { /* results */ },
    "file_id": "...",
    "filename": "..."
}

Bug #2: The orchestration engine stored unwrapped data, but the repository expected it wrapped in a standard result envelope.

Classic impedance mismatch. Two perfectly reasonable design decisions that became incompatible when they met.

The fix? One line (I told you so):

output_data={
    "success": True,
    "data": workflow.context,  # Wrap it!
    "error": None
}

Act IV: The field nameÂ follies

With data flowing correctly, we hit our next failure: â€œNo file ID found in workflow context.â€

The intent enricher was doing its job beautifully:

"probable_file_id": "78034767-3b3d-4420-bce6-1d22722d56ae",
"file_confidence": 0.57

But the orchestration engine was looking for file_id or resolved_file_id. Classic case of the right information, wrong name tag.

Bug #3: Field name mismatch between services. Each component had its own vocabulary for the same concept.

Another one-line fix:

file_id = workflow.context.get('file_id') or \
          workflow.context.get('resolved_file_id') or \
          workflow.context.get('probable_file_id')  # The missing piece

The architectural revelation

What made this debugging session fascinating wasnâ€™t the bugs themselvesâ€Šâ€”â€Šthey were all trivial fixes. It was how they revealed the systemâ€™s architecture through its failure modes, like a medical scan that shows bone structure by highlighting where things break.

Each bug represented a contract violation between layers:

  1. The API expected data in one format, received another
  2. The repository had serialization rules the engine didnâ€™t follow
  3. Services used different field names for the same concept

These werenâ€™t bugs in the traditional sense. Each component worked perfectly when tested in isolation. The bugs existed purely at the integration pointsâ€Šâ€”â€Šin those delicate handshakes between services where assumptions become specifications.

Halfway through Zenoâ€™sÂ paradox

Like Zenoâ€™s ancient paradox where you must travel half the remaining distance infinitely, each fix revealed we were only halfway to the solution. Fix the API layer, discover the domain layer issue. Fix that, find the repository problem. Fix that, uncover the field naming mismatch.

This cascade effect is characteristic of distributed systems. When components communicate through contracts (APIs, data structures, field names), violations propagate through the system like fault lines in an earthquake, manifesting as the same symptom at every level.

You think youâ€™re debugging one problem, but youâ€™re actually debugging the relationships between components. The code isnâ€™t brokenâ€Šâ€”â€Šthe conversation between the code is broken.

Lessons for building AIÂ systems

This session reinforced several principles that feel especially relevant when building AI-assisted software:

1. Integration points are failureÂ points

Design integration contracts explicitly. Document them. Test them. In distributed systems, the majority of bugs will live at these boundaries, not within the components themselves.

2. Clear architecture enables systematic debugging

Because each layer had clear responsibilities, we could debug systematically: UI â†’ API â†’ Domain â†’ Repository â†’ Database. No guesswork needed, just following the data flow upstream until we found where it got corrupted.

3. The same symptom can have different causes at eachÂ layer

â€œNo summary displayedâ€ meant completely different things at each level:

  • At the UI: Wrong conditional check
  • At the API: Empty data structure
  • At the domain: Serialization mismatch
  • At the orchestration: Field name differences

4. One-line fixes can take hours toÂ find

We changed approximately five lines of code in 90 minutes. The work wasnâ€™t in the fixingâ€Šâ€”â€Šit was in the finding. Most debugging is detective work, not coding work.

5. AI assistance amplifies both speed and confusion

With AI assistance, we could generate fixes instantly. But we could also generate fixes for the wrong problems instantly. The discipline of systematic verification became even more critical.

The meta-learning

Perhaps the most valuable outcome wasnâ€™t fixing the bugs, but understanding how our system fails. These failure modes are now documented, understood, and can be prevented in future features.

Building software isnâ€™t just about making things work. Itâ€™s about understanding how they break, why they break, and designing systems that break in debuggable ways. A good architecture reveals its problems clearly rather than hiding them in mysterious symptoms.

Epilogue: Still one lineÂ away

As I write this, the UI still shows â€œWorkflow completed successfully!â€ instead of the actual summary. The backend works perfectly, the API returns the right data, but somewhere in the frontend, one line of code isnâ€™t reading response.message properly.

Some things never change. Software is still, always, perpetually, one line away from working.

The difference is that now I know exactly which line it is, and why itâ€™s broken, and what it means for the next feature I build. Thatâ€™s progress, even when it doesnâ€™t feel like it.
