The Zenoâ€™s Paradox of Debugging: A Weekend with PiperÂ Morgan

Jul 6, 2025

It should have been a simple request: â€œPlease summarize that file I just uploaded.â€

How hard could it be, right? We had all the piecesâ€Šâ€”â€Šfile upload working, storage functional, an LLM ready to summarize. The feature had even worked in previous sessions. Yet this deceptively simple request led me through what I can only describe as Zenoâ€™s paradox in software form.

Sometimes the last mile really is theÂ longest

You know the ancient Greek paradox where you can never reach your destination because you always have to cover half the remaining distance first? Thatâ€™s exactly what debugging this document summarization feature felt like.

I donâ€™t know if â€œrealâ€ programmers also experience this phenomenon, but the emotional ride (believing that each new fix, each time a bot assistant crows â€œI found the issue!â€ that the feature will finally work, only to get no response, or the same error, orâ€Šâ€”â€Šat bestâ€Šâ€”â€Ša fresh error message and something new to debug) can get exhausting.

The layers of theÂ onion

Each â€œfixâ€ peeled back another layer, revealing new problems that looked identical from the outside but were completely different underneath:

Layer 1: The NoneTypeÂ error

  • Symptom: â€œWorkflow completed successfully!â€ (but no summary)
  • Reality: Workflow retrieval was crashing on null data
  • Fix: Add proper null checking
  • Result: Still no summary, but now we could see the workflow was stuck

Layer 2: The polling loop ofÂ doom

  • Result: Workflow executes! Butâ€¦ still no summary

Layer 3: The wrongÂ drawer

  • Reality: Looking for summary in workflow.context instead of workflow.result.data
  • Fix: Update extraction logic
  • Result: Still no summaryâ€¦ wait, what?

Layer 4: The lying errorÂ message

  • Symptom: â€œIâ€™ve completed the analysis but couldnâ€™t generate a summaryâ€
  • Reality: Summary exists! The check is just wrong

The maddening thing? Each layer had exactly the same user-facing symptom but completely different root causes.

The coordination dance

What fascinated me wasnâ€™t just the bugs themselves, but the human side of debugging complex systems:

Copy-paste fatigue: How many times can you send the same logs and say â€œitâ€™s still not workingâ€ before you start questioning your own sanity?

Context switching: Each layer required different mental models. Database queries, workflow orchestration, API response formatting, error handlingâ€Šâ€”â€Šmy brain kept having to shift gears.

The â€œWe Fixed It!â€ loop: That moment of celebration when you solve a problem, only to discover it revealed the real problem underneath. (This happened four times.)

Explanation exhaustion: â€œNo, this is a different problem with the same symptomâ€ becomes a surprisingly common phrase.

Itâ€™d be like peeling off the layers of an onion only to find youâ€™ve still got a whole onion.

Lessons in architectural archaeology

What made this particularly challenging was that each fix was correct and necessary. We werenâ€™t going in circlesâ€Šâ€”â€Šwe were drilling down through geological layers of issues that had accumulated over time:

  1. A hasty null check skip (Layer 1)â€Šâ€”â€Šprobably from some earlier â€œquick fixâ€
  2. An incomplete code path for file references (Layer 2)â€Šâ€”â€Šfeature shipped before edge cases were handled
  3. A data location mismatch (Layer 3)â€Šâ€”â€Šleft hand not knowing what the right hand was doing
  4. Error handling that was too pessimistic (Layer 4)â€Šâ€”â€Šdefensive coding gone wrong

Each layer told a story about past development decisions. Technical debt really is like sedimentary rockâ€Šâ€”â€Šit builds up over time, and debugging becomes the archaeological dig that reveals each stratumâ€™s story.

The beauty of persistent state

Despite the frustration, thereâ€™s something genuinely beautiful about how well-designed systems preserve evidence at each layer. Database logs showed successful execution. Task results proved the summary was generated. The final response revealed the formatting bug.

Each layer left breadcrumbs. The system was workingâ€Šâ€”â€Šit was just hiding its success from the user. Sometimes I think our software can be more honest about its internal state than we can about our own.

Almost there (the eternalÂ refrain)

As I write this, weâ€™re one conditional check away from victory. The document summarization pipeline works perfectly end-to-end. The summary is sitting in the database, generated successfully, waiting patiently. We just need to convince the API to share it with the user.

Itâ€™s like having a beautifully wrapped gift that you canâ€™t figure out how to open.

The Zenoâ€™s paradox aspect isnâ€™t really about never reaching the destinationâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s about how each step forward reveals that the destination was farther away than you thought, but also that you were making real progress the entire time.

Sometimes the last mile really is the longest. But itâ€™s also where you learn the most about your systemâ€™s actual behavior versus its intended behavior.

Now, I sleep.

987eb4c5cc42.title: The AI Detective Squad: When Three Agents Solve One Mystery
987eb4c5cc42.subtitle: July 12
987eb4c5cc42.content:
The AI Detective Squad: When Three Agents Solve OneÂ Mystery

July 12

Sometimes the most interesting bugs arenâ€™t bugs at allâ€Šâ€”â€Štheyâ€™re architectural mysteries that reveal how well (or poorly) youâ€™ve designed your system. Yesterdayâ€™s â€œorchestration false positiveâ€ investigation turned into a masterclass in domain-driven design, solved by deploying three different AI agents like a detective squad.

The mystery: Why was the UI reporting success when workflows were clearly failing?

The false positive thatÂ wasnâ€™t

The problem seemed straightforward. Users would submit requests like â€œUsers are complaining that the mobile app crashes when they upload large photosâ€ and the UI would respond:

  1. â€œI understand you want to investigate this issue. Iâ€™ve started a workflow to handle this.â€ âœ“
  2. [Long pause]
  3. â€œIâ€™ve completed the analysis but couldnâ€™t generate a summary.â€ âœ—

This looked like a classic orchestration failure. The system was marking workflows complete despite task failures, creating false positives that would erode user trust.

Or so we thought.

Deploying the detective squad

Rather than diving in myself, I decided to try something different: deploy multiple AI agents with different investigation approaches and see what each discovered.

Opus (Principal Technical Architect): Strategic oversight and hypothesis formation

Claude Code: Rapid file navigation and pattern matching

Cursor Assistant: Systematic analysis and architectural investigation

Each got different instructions based on their strengths. Think of it like assigning a tech lead, a senior engineer, and a platform architect to the same bug.

The investigation unfolds

Claude Codeâ€™s discovery (the fastÂ tracker)

Claude Code immediately started grep-ing through the codebase looking for success/failure propagation patterns. Within minutes, it found something interesting:

The SUMMARIZE task handler was storing results differently than other analysis tasks:

  • SUMMARIZE: output_data={"message": response,Â ...}
  • ANALYZE_FILE: output_data={"analysis": {"summary": "...",Â ...}}

But this felt like a symptom, not a root cause.

Cursor Assistantâ€™s systematic analysis (the methodical one)

Cursor took a different approach: mapping the entire workflow state machine and tracing how task failures should propagate to workflow status. The investigation revealed:

  • Workflow status management was working correctly
  • Task failure propagation was implemented properly
  • The UI polling logic was sound

So if everything was architected correctly, why the false positive?

The breakthrough moment

Then we tried actually testing the bug scenario again. And something unexpected happened:

The workflow completed successfully.

No rate limits. No failures. A complete 2,429-character analysis generated and stored properly. The â€œcouldnâ€™t generate a summaryâ€ message wasâ€¦ wrong.

Thatâ€™s when Opus had the insight: this wasnâ€™t an orchestration problem. This was a domain modelâ€’consistency violation.

The domain-driven design revelation

Hereâ€™s what we discovered: The UI was correctly expecting analysis results to be structured as workflow.result.data["analysis"]["summary"]. This was the established domain contract, followed consistently by the ANALYZE_FILE handler.

But the SUMMARIZE handler was violating this contract by storing results as {"message": response} instead of following the established pattern.

The â€œbugâ€ wasnâ€™t that the system was reporting false positives. The bug was that one task handler wasnâ€™t following the domain model that all the others used.

This is exactly why domain-driven design matters. When you have clear, consistent contracts, violations become obvious and easy to fix.

The fix and theÂ victory

The architecturally correct solution was simple: update the SUMMARIZE handler to follow the established domain pattern:

output_data = {
    "analysis": {
        "summary": response,
        "analysis_type": "general_analysis", 
        "original_request": original_message,
    }
}

Instead of the contract-violating:

output_data = {"message": response}

Suddenly the UI could find the summary where it expected it, and the mysterious â€œcouldnâ€™t generate a summaryâ€ message disappeared.

What this taught us about AI collaboration

The three-AI approach revealed something important about different types of intelligence:

Pattern matching (Claude Code) found the immediate discrepancy quickly but couldnâ€™t assess architectural significance.

Systematic analysis (Cursor) validated that the architecture was sound but couldnâ€™t identify the specific violation.

Strategic reasoning (Opus) connected the technical details to architectural principles and recognized the domain model violation.

Each AI brought different cognitive strengths to the same problem. The combination was more powerful than any individual approach.

Not to anthropomorphize, but this is eerily similar to working with real people with their own panoply of strengths, growth areas, and stuff they really just hate doing or arenâ€™t good at.

The meta-lesson about debugging complexÂ systems

This investigation reinforced something Iâ€™ve learned over years of building systems: the most interesting problems arenâ€™t usually what they appear to be.

What looked like an orchestration failure was actually a domain-modeling inconsistency. What seemed like a technical bug was actually an architectural-pattern violation. What appeared to be AI coordination failure was actually a successful discovery of emergent system behavior.

The debugging process was as valuable as the fix. We validated that:

  • âœ… The orchestration engine correctly propagates failures
  • âœ… The workflow state management is sound
  • âœ… The UI polling and status interpretation work properly
  • âœ… The domain model contracts are being followed (mostly)
  • âœ… The architectural patterns catch violations when you look for them

The broader implications

This investigation revealed that Piper Morganâ€™s architecture is more robust than I thought. The domain-driven design principles we built in are workingâ€Šâ€”â€Šthey made the contract violation obvious and the fix straightforward.

But it also highlighted the importance of consistency reviews. When youâ€™re building with multiple AI assistants, each implementing different components, itâ€™s easy for domain model violations to creep in. Regular architectural review sessions are essential.

The AI debugging workflow thatÂ emerged

The July 12 investigation suggests a pattern for complex debugging with AI assistance:

  1. Strategic AI (Opus) formulates hypotheses and provides architectural context
  2. Tactical AIs (Code, Cursor) execute different investigation approaches in parallel
  3. Human synthesizes findings and makes architectural decisions
  4. All parties collaborate on fixes that maintain domain consistency

This is different from traditional pair programming or even AI-assisted coding. Itâ€™s more like having a entire debugging team available instantly.

Looking forward

The â€œorchestration false positiveâ€ turned out to be a domain model consistency check in disguise. The investigation validated our architectural choices while revealing areas for improvement.

More importantly, it demonstrated that debugging complex systems with AI assistance isnâ€™t just about fixing bugsâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s about validating architectural decisions and discovering emergent system behaviors.

The detective squad approach is now part of our toolkit for investigating complex issues. Different AIs, different perspectives, better solutions.

Three Bugs, One Victory: The Day We Finally ShippedÂ PM-011

July 12

After three weeks of architectural work, domain modeling, and infrastructure building, yesterday we finally shipped PM-011: complete end-to-end GitHub integration. The victory came down to one focused hour of debugging that fixed three distinct bugs and delivered a working system.

Sometimes the most satisfying moments in software development arenâ€™t the big architectural breakthroughsâ€Šâ€”â€Štheyâ€™re the systematic debugging sessions where everything finally clicks into place.

Three weeks in theÂ making

PM-011 started as â€œadd GitHub integrationâ€ but quickly became something much bigger. Weâ€™d built the orchestration engine, implemented intent classification with real AI, created database persistence, and designed a plugin architecture. All the pieces were there, but they werenâ€™t quite talking to each other properly.

The frustrating part? Each component worked in isolation. The intent classifier was hitting 0.95 confidence scores. The orchestration engine could execute multi-step workflows. The GitHub API integration could create issues. But put them together andâ€¦ mysterious failures.

The kind of bugs that make you question your life choices.

The debugging session that changed everything

July 12, 5:49 PM. I fired up both Cursor Assistant and Claude Code with a simple mission: fix the remaining bugs blocking PM-011 completion. Three bugs stood between us and a working system.

Bug 1: The context handlingÂ error

The symptom: UnboundLocalError when processing certain intents

The cause: workflow_factory.py line 66 referenced intent.context without null checking

The fix: Null-safe context access with (intent.context or {}).get() pattern

Classic defensive programming oversight. The kind of bug that makes you realize youâ€™ve been lucky more than careful.

Bug 2: The missing databaseÂ enum

The symptom: PostgreSQL error about unknown SUMMARIZE TaskType

The cause: Code added SUMMARIZE enum value but database migration was missing

The fix: Proper Alembic migration following the established pattern

This one was architectural debt catching up with us. Weâ€™d been moving fast on domain models but not keeping the database schema in sync.

Bug 3: The domain model consistency violation

The symptom: UI showing â€œcouldnâ€™t generate a summaryâ€ despite successful workflow completion

The cause: SUMMARIZE task handler storing results as {"message": response} while UI expected {"analysis": {"summary": "..."}}

The deeper issue: SUMMARIZE wasn't following the established domain pattern that ANALYZE_FILE had set

This was the most interesting bug. Not a coding error, but an architectural consistency violation. The kind of issue that domain-driven design principles are supposed to catch.

The moment ofÂ truth

With all three bugs fixed, we ran the comprehensive test suite:

Bug Report

  • Input: â€œUsers are complaining that the mobile app crashes when they upload large photosâ€
  • Intent: ANALYSIS/investigate_crash
  • Workflow: GENERATE_REPORT
  • Result: 2,429 character analysis
  • Status: âœ…

Explicit Ticket

  • â€œCreate a ticket for the new payment integrationâ€
  • EXECUTION/create_ticket
  • CREATE_TICKET
  • GitHub Issue #21
  • âœ…

Performance Issue

  • â€œThe login page is too slow and users are getting frustratedâ€
  • ANALYSIS/performance_analysis
  • GENERATE_REPORT
  • 2,804 character analysis
  • âœ…

Feature Request

  • â€œWe need to add dark mode support to improve user experienceâ€
  • EXECUTION/add_feature
  • CREATE_TICKET
  • GitHub Issue #22
  • âœ…

Every. Single. Test. Passed.

Real GitHub issues were created. Comprehensive analyses were generated. The intent classification was working with scary accuracy. The orchestration engine was executing complex workflows flawlessly.

The architectural discovery

But hereâ€™s what surprised me: the system was more sophisticated than Iâ€™d realized.

The intent classification wasnâ€™t just categorizing requestsâ€Šâ€”â€Šit was embedding product management best practices:

Analysis triggers (confidence 0.85): Problem descriptions like â€œusers are complainingâ€ or â€œX is too slowâ€ â†’ investigate first, understand the issue before creating tickets

Execution triggers (confidence 0.95): Direct action requests like â€œcreate a ticketâ€ or â€œwe need to addâ€ â†’ immediate action, clear requirements already provided

The system was preventing ticket spam while enabling quick execution when appropriate. Weâ€™d accidentally built PM workflow intelligence into the intent classification.

The production readiness moment

7:06 PM, Claude Code delivered the verdict: â€œThe system is ready for production use with complete end-to-end GitHub integration functionality.â€

Three weeks of architectural work. Dozens of commits. Multiple AI assistants coordinating fixes. All culminating in one beautiful sentence.

Thatâ€™s the thing about complex systems workâ€Šâ€”â€Šprogress feels incremental until suddenly it doesnâ€™t. Youâ€™re debugging individual components for weeks, and then one day everything clicks into place and you have something that actually works.

What we learned about AI-assisted debugging

The July 12 session validated something important about working with multiple AI assistants:

Cursor Assistant excelled at systematic investigation and following established patterns for the database migration.

Claude Code was brilliant at rapid pattern matching and finding the domain model inconsistency.

Me was essential for knowing when to stop and ship instead of looking for more problems to solve.

The collaboration pattern that emerged: human sets objectives, AIs execute with different strengths, human makes the ship/donâ€™t-ship call.

The honest assessment

Is PM-011 perfect? Not even close. Thereâ€™s still technical debt, the error handling could be more graceful, and we havenâ€™t built the learning loops that will make the system truly intelligent over time.

But it works. Real GitHub issues get created from natural language. Complex analyses get generated that actually provide value. The intent classification understands the difference between problems to investigate and features to build.

Sometimes â€œit worksâ€ is exactly what you need.

Looking forward

With PM-011 shipped, we can finally move beyond infrastructure and start building the capabilities that make Piper Morgan genuinely useful. Multi-project support, learning from feedback, cross-system orchestration.

The prototype is officially dead. Long live the platform.

Two-Fisted Coding: Wrangling Robot Programmers When Youâ€™re Just aÂ PM

July 8

Thereâ€™s a moment in every product managerâ€™s life when you realize youâ€™re doing something completely absurd. For me, it was Tuesday at 2:30 PM Pacific, watching two different AI assistants simultaneously rewrite my codebase while I played referee.

Claude Code was in the terminal, implementing a domain service for markdown formatting. Cursor Assistant was in the IDE, refactoring the entire frontend. And I was in the middle, trying to keep them from stepping on each otherâ€™s toes.

This is either the future of development or the setup to a very nerdy joke.

The problem that started itÂ all

PM-011 UI testing had revealed what we call a â€œuser experience challenge.â€ What users might call it would be less polite. Our document summarization was producing output that looked like markdown had a fight with Unicode and everybody lost.

The output looked something like this:

â€¢ - Important point
  â€¢ - Sub-point that's also a bullet
â€¢ ## Header pretending to be a list item

Suddenly I flashed back to the only computer programming class I took in college. My final project was a simple word processor written in Pascal. I could never get word wrap working right.

Meet theÂ players

Claude Code: The philosopher

Iâ€™d just gotten access to Claude Code after ADR-002 promised a 50% reduction in coordination overhead. Bold claim. Time to test it.

Claude Code approaches problems like a philosophy major who discovered programming. Every status update is an existential meditation:

  • â€œHoping this implementation aligns with your architectural visionâ€¦â€
  • â€œSoothing the troubled waters of markdown parsingâ€¦â€
  • â€œSavoring the elegance of domain-driven designâ€¦â€

It also has a long vocabulary of funny gerunds to describe whatâ€™s doing (â€œcombobulating,â€ â€œruminating,â€ etc.).

Cursor assistant: The silent professional

Meanwhile, Cursor Assistant (or is Cursor Agent? branding issues, so we usually call it CA or just Cursor) was doing what it does best: working. No commentary. No progress poetry. Just steady, methodical refactoring of the frontend.

If Claude Code was the chatty coworker who narrates their work, CA was the one with noise-canceling headphones who just ships code.

The MarkdownÂ wars

By 3:00 PM Pacific, we were deep in what I might now call â€œThe Markdown Wars.â€ Despite our best efforts:

  1. Explicit prompts: â€œPlease use ONLY standard markdown bulletsâ€
  2. Domain validation: Three layers of cleaning
  3. Battle-tested libraries: marked.js for rendering
  4. Prayer: Seriously considered it

The LLM kept producing malformed markdown. It was like asking someone to write in English and getting back Esperanto with emoji.

The two-fisting revelation

At 6:05 PM Pacific (yes, this had been going on for hours), something clicked. Instead of fighting the complexity, what if I embraced it?

Stream 1â€Šâ€”â€ŠClaude Code (Backend):

  • Building the markdown processing domain service
  • Implementing CommonMark compliance
  • Writing comprehensive tests
  • Providing philosophical commentary

Stream 2â€Šâ€”â€ŠCursor Assistant (Frontend):

  • Refactoring the message renderer
  • Updating documentation
  • Creating test coverage
  • Working in blessed silence

Two AI assistants. Two different parts of the system. One human conductor.

The human moment that changed everything

At 6:35 PM Pacific, staring at the still-broken output, I had a thought. Not a technical insight. Not an architectural epiphany. Just a simple observation:

â€œI bet weâ€™re the ones making those weird bullets.â€

Claude Code investigated. Twenty minutes later, we found it: three different formatting layers all â€œhelpingâ€ each other:

  1. MarkdownFormatter.clean_and_validate() - Adding its opinions
  2. format_key_findings_as_markdown() - Adding more opinions
  3. clean_markdown_response() - Making everything worse

It was like hiring three proofreaders who all use different style guides.

My insight was really just pattern matching (and memory, something the bots lackâ€Šâ€”â€ŠI remembered the earlier efforts we had made at forcing the formatting).

What we learned aboutÂ process

The efficiency metrics told an interesting story:

Single AI Assistant (Sprint Zero baseline):

  • Time to implement feature: 2 hours
  • Context switches: Constant
  • Frustration level: High

Dual AI Assistant Approach:

  • Time to implement: 80 minutes
  • Context switches: Minimal
  • Frustration level: Moderate (with entertainment value)

But hereâ€™s the thing: it wasnâ€™t really about the time savings.

The realÂ insights

1. Different Tools for Different Jobs

Claude Code excels at:

  • Deep architectural thinking
  • Complex multi-file changes
  • Philosophical progress updates

Cursor Assistant excels at:

  • Focused refactoring
  • Quick iterations
  • Actually finishing things

2. Human Orchestration StillÂ Matters

The AIs didnâ€™t coordinate with each other. They coordinated through me. And that turned out to be the secret sauce. At times I may feel like a glorified copy-paste monkey, but as the â€œsimian in the loopâ€ my job is to stay awake and notice when things arenâ€™t right.

3. Sometimes You Need to StopÂ Digging

By 7:15 PM Pacific, Claude Code did something remarkable. It wrote a report saying, essentially: â€œThis needs research, not more code.â€ Or maybe I wrote that. Iâ€™m now falling into the LLM habit of keeping track of text but not who wrote it. The point is, we recognized that each new patch or attempt at cleanup was just another layer on the problem.

And if it was the AI that knew when to stop trying? Thatâ€™s maturity. Even if itâ€™s artificial.

Comedy ofÂ errors

Looking back, the funniest part wasnâ€™t the progress messages or the markdown madness. It was the moment we realized weâ€™d spent hours building increasingly complex solutions to clean up markdown that we were making dirty in the first place.

Classic engineering: solving problems we created for ourselves.

Where we endedÂ up

The Good:

  • Two AIs working in parallel = faster development
  • Clear separation of concerns
  • Entertainment value from progress messages
  • Valuable process insights

The Bad:

  • Markdown still broken
  • Three formatting layers fighting each other
  • Hours spent on self-inflicted problems

The Ugly:

  • The actual markdown output (seriously, it was bad)

The bottomÂ line

Running two AI assistants simultaneously is like conducting an orchestra where half the musicians are jazz improvisers and the other half are classical purists. It shouldnâ€™t work, but somehow it does.

The markdown problem remains unsolved. But we learned something more valuable: how to orchestrate multiple AI tools effectively, when to trust human intuition over AI analysis, and that sometimes the best solution is admitting you need to try a different approach.

Also, that Claude Code should consider a side career in motivational speaking.

The Demo That Needed Documentation

â€œThe Lost Weekendâ€ Part 2 of 4, when â€œit works on my machineâ€ isnâ€™t enough

May 30, later that day

What I do remember: six documents in one marathon session. After taking the project to Gemini, I told it to just go ahead and write me a set of specs and docs. From prototype toÂ demo

The hardest part wasnâ€™t the writingâ€Šâ€”â€Šit was the thinking. Stepping outside the builder mindset to see the system through other eyes.

Weâ€™ve already written about â€œThe Demo That Killed The Prototypeâ€ so we know where that story is going but this is before the demo, when we were still trying to figure out what the what was.

Chasing Rabbits (A Debugging Story)

The Lost Weekend, Part 3 of 4, or debugging with Gemini a prototype that Claude threw together:

May 31, early

What did it mean?

AssertionError: None

Six hours later, I finally understood what that error was trying to tell me: Stop.

The mystery that made noÂ sense

PyGithub was throwing assertion errors on GitHub issue creation. The debugging logs showed everything was valid:

  • Labels array: ['feature', 'enhancement', 'prototype', 'priority'] - only 4 items, well under the 100 limit
  • Repository access: confirmed working
  • Authentication: valid token with proper permissions
  • Input parameters: all properly formatted

Yet somehow: assert len(labels) <= 100 was failing with AssertionError: None.

Seven bugs on the way toÂ nowhere

Hereâ€™s the thing about chasing mysterious bugsâ€Šâ€”â€Šyou find other bugs along the way. Saturdayâ€™s rabbit hunt netted:

  1. âœ… Milestone assertion fix
  2. âœ… Repository configuration correction
  3. âœ… Knowledge base context retrieval optimization
  4. âœ… Dependency version alignment
  5. âœ… JSON parsing robustness improvements
  6. âœ… Error message user-friendliness
  7. âœ… GitHub API method corrections

All real improvements. All valuable fixes. All distractions from the one bug that refused to make sense. Do you know how frustrating it is to fix bug after bug after bug only to find you still havenâ€™t gotten to the root of the problem.

This was when I started wondering why the code was so sloppy from the get-go.

The moment ofÂ clarity

Six hours in, debugging fatigue set in. Thatâ€™s when the real insight hit:

I wasnâ€™t debugging a bug anymore. I was debugging my debugging.

The AssertionError wasnâ€™t a technical problemâ€Šâ€”â€Šit was a process problem. I was grinding when I should have been stepping back.

Strategic retreat

Sometimes the most productive debugging action is knowing when to stop debugging.

The seven bugs Iâ€™d fixed were real value. The mystery bug was a rabbit hole that could consume infinite time without guaranteed resolution.

Strategic decision: revert to the last working version. Start fresh with lessons learned.

To be honest. This felt like giving up. I was reluctant to back down after investing hours on fixing this one issue. Thatâ€™s called the â€œsunk-cost fallacy,â€ kids!

The wisdom of walkingÂ away

Hereâ€™s what every debugger learns eventually: not every problem needs to be solved right now. Some problems need fresh eyes, clean environments, or just time to reveal their true nature.

The mysterious PyGithub error? Probably environmental. Possibly a library version edge case. Maybe even a cosmic ray flipping a bit somewhere.

But definitely not worth another six hours on a Saturday.

The realÂ bug

The real bug wasnâ€™t in PyGithubâ€Šâ€”â€Šit was in my process. Six hours of grinding when twenty minutes of fresh perspective might have solved everything.

Good debugging isnâ€™t about persistence. Itâ€™s about knowing when persistence becomes counterproductive.

The best debuggers know when to stop debugging.

When Your AI Writes 500 Lines of Boilerplate (And Why Thatâ€™s ActuallyÂ Useful)

Part 4 of of the reconstructed â€œLost Weekendâ€ at the beginning of this project, as best as we can determine!

May 30, later in the day

What AI-generated code teachesÂ us

When to generate vs.Â craft

âœ… Good for: Boilerplate, integration patterns, standard implementations

b7c3ef25cbdc.title: From 2% to 87%: The Great Test Suite Recovery
b7c3ef25cbdc.subtitle: July 13
b7c3ef25cbdc.content:
From 2% to 87%: The Great Test SuiteÂ Recovery

July 13

Thereâ€™s a special kind of despair that comes with seeing your test suite report 144 failures and 19 errors out of 204 total tests. A 2% pass rate isnâ€™t just brokenâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s catastrophically broken. Itâ€™s the kind of number that makes you question whether you should just delete everything and start over.

The day I wrote this, we climbed out of that hole, ending the day at 87% pass rate (177/204 tests passing). The journey from software disaster to mostly-working system taught me more about test infrastructure than three years of â€œtesting best practicesâ€ blog posts.

The foundation: pre-commit hooks

The recovery actually started three days earlier with something mundane: setting up pre-commit hooks. I had been griping about needing to remember to update documentation every time we changed the code and my colleague at Kind, lead engineer Grace Xu, told me about the concept of pre-commit hooks.

Yes, I have worked in technology all my life and am still learning quotidian programming concepts daily.

I asked Claude to set some up and it configured black, flake8, isort, and other code quality tools to run automatically on every commit. It also reminds us to update documentation based on which files we changed.

This seemed like procrastination at the timeâ€Šâ€”â€Šwhy format code when core functionality is broken? But it turned out to be essential. When youâ€™re fixing 144 test failures, you need every bit of consistency and clarity you can get. Code formatting issues become cognitive overhead you canâ€™t afford.

(At least thatâ€™s what I told myself. It is also possible I was being a digital magpie and just grabbing and absorbing every shiny new idea into my process.)

The pre-commit setup also revealed something important: we had 318 files that needed formatting fixes. Thatâ€™s not a small projectâ€Šâ€”â€Šthatâ€™s a sign of technical debt accumulation that was making everything harder to understand and debug.

The horror of 144Â failures

Sunday morning, July 13. Fresh coffee, good intentions, and a test command that delivered soul-crushing results:

======================== 144 failed, 37 passed, 21 skipped, 19 errors ========================

Two percent. The kind of failure rate that suggests fundamental infrastructure problems, not minor bugs.

The failures fell into categories that told a story:

  • AsyncSession leaksâ€Šâ€”â€ŠDatabase sessions not being closed properly
  • Missing pytest-asyncio configurationâ€Šâ€”â€ŠAsync tests failing because pytest couldnâ€™t run them
  • Fixture driftâ€Šâ€”â€ŠTests expecting fixtures that no longer existed
  • Contract violationsâ€Šâ€”â€ŠComponents expecting interfaces that had changed
  • Float precision errorsâ€Šâ€”â€ŠTests comparing floats with exact equality

Each category represented weeks of accumulated technical debt coming due all at once.

The systematic triageÂ approach

Rather than randomly fixing tests, we took a systematic approach:

Phase 1: Infrastructure fixes (the foundation)

The async session leak discovery: The most critical issue was database sessions not being closed properly in the query intent handler. This was causing cascading failures as tests shared database state.

The fix was surprisingly simpleâ€Šâ€”â€Šadd proper session management to main.py:

python

# Before: session leaked across requests

# After: proper async session lifecycle management

pytest-asyncio configuration: Half the test failures were because pytest couldnâ€™t run async tests. Adding pytest-asyncio to requirements and configuring it properly eliminated 20+ failures immediately.

Where have I heard this one before? Ay-sink-ee-oooooh!

Phase 2: Fixture rehabilitation

Missing db_session fixture: Nine tests were failing because they expected an async database session fixture that didnâ€™t exist. Creating the fixture in conftest.py unblocked an entire category of repository tests. I still donâ€™t understand why my bots write tests and either donâ€™t create the fixtures for the tests (and then act surprised when they fail) or create them and then â€œclean them up,â€ like some overclocked housekeeper.

Orchestration engine test refactoring: Tests were using mock domain models instead of real ones, causing contract mismatches. Updating them to use actual domain objects fixed another cluster of failures. Beware of test mocks! They are needed when you are testing workflows that are not fully built yet, but if they linger beyond when they are needed, they will trip you up.

Phase 3: Contract alignment

Enum case drift: Intent classification tests were failing because they expected different enum cases than the implementation was using. The kind of drift that happens when youâ€™re moving fast and not running tests regularly. (It also seems to happen a lot because either these bots get sloppy or they are mixing up knowledge from programming languages with different conventions.)

Repository interface changes: Some tests expected connection pools while others expected sessions. The infrastructure changes weâ€™d made for better async support had shifted interfaces without updating tests.

The psychological challenge

The hardest part wasnâ€™t the technical fixesâ€Šâ€”â€Šit was maintaining the belief that the situation was recoverable. When you see 144 failures, the rational response is panic. When you fix 10 and still have 134 remaining, itâ€™s easy to conclude youâ€™re making no progress.

The breakthrough came when we started categorizing failures instead of just counting them. Once we could see that most failures were infrastructure issues rather than logic problems, the path forward became clearer.

The momentumÂ shift

Around hour 4 of the recovery session, something shifted. The fixes started cascading. Resolving the async session leak eliminated 15 failures. Configuring pytest-asyncio properly fixed another 20. Adding the missing fixture unblocked 9 more.

Suddenly we werenâ€™t fighting individual test failuresâ€Šâ€”â€Šwe were addressing systemic issues that affected multiple test categories. The pass rate went from 2% to 30% to 60% to 87% as each infrastructure fix unlocked multiple working tests.

What was still broken (and why that wasÂ OK)

The remaining 13% of test failures fall into categories that represent real work, not just infrastructure debt:

FileRepository pool vs session architecture: Tests expect connection pools but the implementation now uses sessions. This represents an architectural decision that needs to be resolved, not just a bug to fix.

API integration contract drift: Some query service tests are failing because the interfaces have evolved during development. These failures are telling us about API design decisions we need to make.

Logic assertion mismatches: Tests expecting specific float values or exact string matches that need to be updated for current implementation behavior.

These arenâ€™t blocking failuresâ€Šâ€”â€Štheyâ€™re indicators of technical decisions that need conscious resolution.

The infrastructure lessons

The recovery taught us several important principles about test infrastructure:

Async testing requires specific setup. pytest-asyncio isnâ€™t optional when youâ€™re building async systemsâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s foundational infrastructure that needs to be configured correctly from the start.

Database session management is critical. Session leaks donâ€™t just affect performanceâ€Šâ€”â€Šthey make tests unpredictable and unreliable. Proper session lifecycle management is essential for test stability.

Formatting consistency reduces cognitive load. When youâ€™re debugging complex failures, code formatting issues become mental overhead you canâ€™t afford. Automated formatting is productivity infrastructure.

Systematic triage beats random fixing. Categorizing failures by root cause reveals the high-leverage fixes that unblock multiple tests at once.

The AI assistance reality

Cursor Assistant was invaluable for systematic analysis and fixture creation. But the recovery process highlighted something important: AI is excellent at executing solutions but human judgment is essential for prioritization.

When facing 144 failures, AI wants to fix them all in parallel. This can lead to a monomaniacal bug hunt based on guesswork that easily ends up down infinite rabbit holes.

Human insight recognizes that fixing async session management will eliminate 20 failures, while fixing individual assertion errors will eliminate one failure each.

The most effective pattern: human diagnoses systemic issues, AI executes systematic fixes.

The unexpected benefit

The test suite recovery revealed something we hadnâ€™t appreciated: our architecture is actually quite solid. The failures were mostly infrastructure and configuration issues, not fundamental design problems.

The domain models are working correctly. The repository pattern is sound. The orchestration engine is reliable. The intent classification is accurate. The components we built with careful design are holding up under scrutiny.

Thatâ€™sâ€¦ actually pretty encouraging.

Looking forward

87% pass rate isnâ€™t perfect, but itâ€™s functional. (Spoiler: It will get better.)

The remaining failures represent conscious decisions to make rather than accumulated debt to fix. The test infrastructure is now solid enough to support ongoing development without constant firefighting.

More importantly, weâ€™ve established a pattern for handling technical debt systematically rather than reactively. When the next batch of tests starts failing (and they will), we have a process for recovery that doesnâ€™t involve panic and random fixes.

The great test suite recovery is complete. Now we can get back to building features instead of fighting infrastructure.

From Broken Tests to Perfect Architecture: The GreatÂ Cleanup

July 14

What started as â€œletâ€™s fix these 9 failing FileRepository testsâ€ became â€œletâ€™s eliminate three yearsâ€“worth of accumulated technical debt and achieve 100% architectural pattern compliance.â€ Sometimes the best debugging sessions are the ones that refuse to stay in their lane.

(How we accumulated that much tech debt in less than three weeks is another testament to the power of AI.)

Eventually, we discovered that our test failures werenâ€™t just broken testsâ€Šâ€”â€Šthey were symptoms of fundamental architectural inconsistencies that had been lurking beneath a mostly-working system. By the end of a 14-hour session, weâ€™d eliminated dual repository implementations, standardized on consistent patterns, and achieved something every architect dreams of: a codebase where everything follows the same rules.

The deceptively simple startingÂ point

Fresh off PM-011â€™s completion and the test suite recovery to 87% pass rate, I thought July 14 would be a cleanup day. Just 27 remaining test failures across a few categories:

  • 9 FileRepository tests (connection pool vs session mismatch)
  • 3 API query tests (session management issues)
  • 14 assertion drift tests (float precision, logic updates)
  • 1 miscellaneous test (dataclass issue)

The FileRepository failures looked straightforward: tests were providing AsyncSession objects, but the repository expected connection pools with anÂ .acquire() method. Classic interface mismatch. Should be a quick fix, right?

Famous last words.

The revealing architectural audit

Instead of band-aiding the FileRepository issue, I asked Claude Code to investigate our database patterns more systematically. What came back was a comprehensive architectural compliance audit that revealed uncomfortable truths about our codebase.

Repository Compliance: 71% (5/7 repositories)

The audit identified seven repositories across the system:

  • âœ… 5 repositories fully compliant with our documented Pattern #1
  • âŒ 1 repository using legacy raw SQL + connection pools
  • âš ï¸ 1 repository in the wrong architectural layer

But the real shock was the footnote: â€œDual WorkflowRepository implementation detected.â€

We had two completely different WorkflowRepository classes in the codebase. Not variations on a themeâ€Šâ€”â€Šcompletely different implementations using different patterns, serving different parts of the system. (I was getting dÃ©jÃ  vu again. Why did we keep â€œdiscoveringâ€ that weâ€™d built parallel solutions in the past?)

The detective workÂ begins

The FileRepository investigation led to a broader question: how much legacy code were we carrying from before we established architectural patterns?

Claude Codeâ€™s analysis revealed the scope:

Legacy Pattern (Raw SQL + Connection Pools):

class FileRepository:
    def __init__(self, db_pool):
        self.db_pool = db_pool
    async def get_file_by_id(self, file_id: str):
        async with self.db_pool.acquire() as conn:
            row = await conn.fetchrow("SELECT * FROM uploaded_files WHERE id = $1", file_id)

Modern Pattern (SQLAlchemy + Sessions):

python

class FileRepository(BaseRepository):
    def __init__(self, session: AsyncSession):
        super().__init__(session, UploadedFileDB)
    async def get_file_by_id(self, file_id: str) -> Optional[UploadedFile]:
        result = await self.session.execute(
            select(UploadedFileDB).where(UploadedFileDB.id == file_id)
        )

The FileRepository was essentially prototype code that had never been migrated to our documented patterns. It worked, but it violated every architectural principle weâ€™d established.

Suddenly, I was having nightmares again about the legacy spaghetti that powered AOL Instant Messenger in its final days.

The dual WorkflowRepository mystery

The WorkflowRepository situation was more complex. We had two implementations:

Legacy version (services/repositories/workflow_repository.py):

  • Raw SQL with connection pools
  • Used by API endpoints for read operations
  • Methods: find_by_id(), save()

Modern version (services/database/repositories.py):

  • Inherits from BaseRepository
  • Used by orchestration engine for write operations
  • Methods: create_from_domain(), update_status()

The interfaces didnâ€™t even overlap! They were serving completely different use cases, with no obvious conflicts. This explained why the duplication had persistedâ€Šâ€”â€Šeach implementation worked perfectly for its specific purpose.

But Claude Codeâ€™s investigation revealed the truth: â€œThis is technical debt from an incomplete migration, not an architectural design choice.â€

The evidence was clear:

  • The orchestration engine had been fully migrated to the RepositoryFactory pattern
  • API endpoints had never been migrated from direct imports
  • The two repositories existed because the migration was never completed

The systematic cleanupÂ begins

Rather than patch around the inconsistencies, we decided to complete the architectural migration properly. The approach: Test-Driven Development for every change, ensuring we didnâ€™t break anything that was working.

Phase 1: FileRepository migration

Claude Code created a comprehensive TDD test suite, then implemented the migration:

  • Migrated from raw SQL to SQLAlchemy ORM
  • Changed from connection pools to AsyncSession
  • Maintained the same public interface (returns domain models)
  • Followed Pattern #1 from our architecture documentation

The migration was clean. The repository now inherited from BaseRepository, used standard patterns, and integrated seamlessly with our test infrastructure.

Phase 2: WorkflowRepository consolidation

This was trickier because we needed to preserve functionality for both use cases:

Step 1: Add missing methods to the modern repository

python

async def find_by_id(self, workflow_id: str) -> Optional[Workflow]:
    """Add legacy method for API compatibility"""
    db_workflow = await self.get_by_id(workflow_id)
    return db_workflow.to_domain() if db_workflow else None

Step 2: Migrate API endpoints to use RepositoryFactory

# Before: Direct import and connection pool
from services.repositories.workflow_repository import WorkflowRepository
repo = WorkflowRepository(pool)

# After: Factory pattern with session management
repos = await RepositoryFactory.get_repositories()
db_workflow = await repos["workflows"].find_by_id(workflow_id)

Step 3: Remove the legacy implementation entirely

The migration was surgical. API functionality remained identical, but now everything used the same underlying patterns and session management.

The async session investigation

With the repository patterns unified, we still had those mysterious â€œoperation in progressâ€ errors in the FileRepository tests. This led to a deep investigation of async session management that revealed important patterns.

The error looked like a concurrency issue:

sqlalchemy.exc.InterfaceError: cannot perform operation: another operation is in progress

But systematic testing revealed the infrastructure was sound. We could run 20 sequential operations without issues. The problem was specific test anti-patterns that were reusing sessions inappropriately.

The solution was a session factory pattern for tests:

# Anti-pattern: Reusing session in loops
repo = FileRepository(db_session)
for item in items:
    await repo.save_file_metadata(item)  # Session reused!

# Better pattern: Fresh session per operation
async with await db_session_factory() as session:
    repo = FileRepository(session)
    await repo.save_file_metadata(item)

This investigation taught us important principles about async database testing and session lifecycle management that will prevent similar issues in the future.

The moment of architectural victory

By evening, the audit results were transformed:

Repository Compliance: 100% (7/7 repositories)

  • âœ… All repositories inherit from BaseRepository
  • âœ… All repositories use AsyncSession pattern
  • âœ… All repositories follow documented patterns
  • âœ… No legacy implementations remaining
  • âœ… Consistent architectural layers

Weâ€™d achieved something rare in software development: complete pattern compliance across the entire system. Every repository now follows the same rules, uses the same base classes, and integrates with the same infrastructure.

The meta-lessons about technical debt

The July 14 cleanup taught us several important principles:

Legacy code compounds. What started as one non-compliant repository revealed systematic architectural inconsistencies. Technical debt doesnâ€™t stay isolatedâ€Šâ€”â€Šit spreads and creates maintenance burden across the system.

Good architecture makes debugging easier. Once we had consistent patterns, new issues became obvious. When everything follows the same rules, violations stand out immediately.

Test failures can be architectural feedback. The FileRepository test failures werenâ€™t just broken testsâ€Šâ€”â€Šthey were the system telling us about pattern violations we hadnâ€™t noticed.

AI agents excel at systematic audits. Having Claude Code comprehensively audit all repository implementations revealed technical debt we might have missed for months. Different AI agents working in parallel (Cursor on session management, Claude Code on pattern compliance) accelerated the cleanup significantly.

The collaborative debugging pattern

The session demonstrated an effective pattern for complex architectural work:

Strategic AI (Opus) provides oversight and ensures architectural consistency

Investigative AI (Claude Code) conducts systematic audits and discovers technical debt

Implementation AI (Cursor) executes migrations with TDD discipline

Human (thatâ€™s me!) makes architectural decisions and coordinates the work

This multi-agent approach let us work on different aspects of the same problem simultaneously without conflicts. While Cursor was fixing async session patterns, Claude Code was migrating repository implementations. The parallel work streams accelerated progress significantly.

What this enables goingÂ forward

Achieving 100% pattern compliance isnâ€™t just aesthetic satisfactionâ€Šâ€”â€Šit has practical benefits:

Onboarding new developers becomes easier when everything follows the same patterns. No need to learn multiple ways of doing database access.

Adding new repositories is straightforwardâ€Šâ€”â€Šinherit from BaseRepository, follow the established pattern, integrate with RepositoryFactory.

Test infrastructure works consistently across all components. No special cases or interface mismatches.

Debugging database issues has clear troubleshooting patterns. When everything uses the same session management, problems are easier to isolate.

Architectural reviews can focus on new patterns rather than cleaning up old inconsistencies.

The honest assessment

Was the system perfect now? Not even close. We still had test assertion drift, float precision issues, and various edge cases to handle. But the foundational patterns were now solid and consistent.

Sometimes architectural work feels like â€œyak shavingâ€â€Šâ€”â€Šendlessly preparing to do the real work. But July 14 proved that systematic cleanup creates compound benefits. Every repository that follows consistent patterns is one less maintenance burden. Every eliminated legacy implementation is cognitive overhead removed.

The unexpected satisfaction

Thereâ€™s something deeply satisfying about achieving pattern compliance across a complex system. Itâ€™s the difference between a codebase that grew organically (with all the inconsistencies that implies) and one that follows coherent principles.

The FileRepository now looks like every other repository. The WorkflowRepository duplication is eliminated. The test infrastructure works consistently. When you open any database-related file, you know exactly what patterns to expect.

That consistency pays dividends every time you need to debug, extend, or modify the system.

9fbbf6932838.title: The Action Humanizer: Teaching AI to Speak Human
9fbbf6932838.subtitle: July 13, later that day
9fbbf6932838.content:
The Action Humanizer: Teaching AI to SpeakÂ Human

July 13, later that day

Thereâ€™s something deeply unsatisfying about building an AI assistant that talks to users like a developer. When your system responds with â€œI understand you want to investigate_crash,â€ it sounds like a robot thatâ€™s trying to be helpful but doesnâ€™t quite understand how humans communicate. (Which, well, it kind of is?)

Yesterday we fixed this with the Action Humanizerâ€Šâ€”â€Ša smart caching system that converts technical action strings into natural language. Now the system says â€œI understand you want to investigate a crash,â€ which feels like talking to a colleague instead of debugging a program.

Small change, big difference.

The problem that bothered me forÂ weeks

This issue had been nagging at me since we implemented the intent classification system. The AI was correctly understanding user requests and classifying them into structured actions like investigate_crash, create_github_issue, or analyze_performance. Technically perfect, humanly awful.

Every user message would get responses like:

  • â€œIâ€™ve started a workflow to handle your investigate_crash requestâ€
  • â€œI understand you want to create_github_issueâ€
  • â€œLet me help you with analyze_performanceâ€

Functionally correct, emotionally jarring. Like having a conversation with someone who learned English from technical specifications or getting one of those personalized emails addressed to Dear $FIRSTNAME.

The architecture insight

The solution couldnâ€™t be simple find-and-replace. Different actions need different treatments:

  • investigate_crash â†’ "investigate a crash"
  • create_github_issue â†’ "create a GitHub issue"
  • analyze_performance â†’ "analyze performance"
  • list_projects â†’ "list projects" (plural, no article)

The patterns are consistent enough for rules but nuanced enough to need intelligence. Perfect candidate for a hybrid approach: rule-based conversion for common patterns, LLM fallback for complex cases, smart caching to avoid repeated processing.

Building the smart cachingÂ system

We designed the Action Humanizer as a proper service with three layers:

Layer 1: DatabaseÂ caching

Every technical action gets cached with its human-readable equivalent. Once weâ€™ve figured out that investigate_crash becomes "investigate a crash," we never need to compute it again.

The database schema captures not just the mapping, but metadata:

  • Usage count (how often this action appears)
  • Last used timestamp (for cache maintenance)
  • Category context (analysis vs execution actions might be treated differently)

Layer 2: Rule-based conversion

For common patterns, we built explicit rules:

# verb_noun patterns get articles
if verb in ['create', 'investigate', 'analyze', 'review']:
    return f"{verb} a {noun}"

# list/count patterns get pluralization  
elif verb in ['list', 'count']:
    return f"{verb} {noun}s"

This handles 80% of cases instantly and consistently.

Layer 3: LLMÂ fallback

For complex actions that donâ€™t match rules, we fall back to the LLM with a carefully crafted prompt:

Convert this technical action identifier to natural conversational English.
Technical action: update_user_story_acceptance_criteria
Examples:
- investigate_crash â†’ investigate a crash
- create_github_issue â†’ create a GitHub issue
Natural language version:

The LLM is surprisingly good at this task. It understands context (github â†’ GitHub), articles (when to use â€œaâ€ vs no article), and maintains the action verb structure.

The implementation sprint

This was a perfect test of our multi-AI development approach. We broke the work into clear phases and executed with Test-Driven Development:

Phase 1: Database and domain models (Cursor Assistant)

  • Alembic migration for the cache table
  • Domain model for ActionHumanization
  • SQLAlchemy mapping and repository pattern

Phase 2: Service implementation (Cursor Assistant)

  • ActionHumanizer service with the three-layer architecture
  • Rule-based conversion logic
  • Integration points with the LLM client

Phase 3: Template integration (Collaborative)

  • TemplateRenderer to handle placeholder replacement
  • Integration with existing message templates
  • Testing across different workflow types

Phase 4: Testing and validation (All hands)

  • Unit tests for rule-based conversion
  • Integration tests for the full pipeline
  • Manual testing through the UI

The TDD approach kept us focused. Write a test for â€œinvestigate_crashâ€ â†’ â€œinvestigate a crashâ€, implement just enough to pass, refactor if needed. Repeat for the next pattern.

The satisfying results

The system now handles natural language conversion seamlessly:

Technical actions â†’ Human language

  • investigate_crash â†’ "investigate a crash"
  • create_github_issue â†’ "create a GitHub issue"
  • analyze_performance â†’ "analyze performance"
  • review_pull_request â†’ "review a pull request"
  • update_user_story â†’ "update a user story"
  • list_projects â†’ "list projects"

The UI responses now feel natural:

  • â€œI understand you want to investigate a crash. Iâ€™ve started a workflow to handle this.â€
  • â€œIâ€™ll help you create a GitHub issue with the details youâ€™ve provided.â€
  • â€œLet me analyze performance patterns for you.â€

Small change, but it fundamentally improves the user experience. The system feels less like a developer tool and more like a collaborative assistant.

The performance characteristics

The caching system delivers the performance we need:

  • Cache hits: Instant response for known actions
  • Rule-based misses: Sub-millisecond conversion for common patterns
  • LLM fallbacks: ~200ms for complex actions (only happens once per action)

In practice, 95% of requests hit the cache or rules. The LLM fallback is rarely needed after the initial seeding period.

The meta-lesson about AIÂ UX

Building the Action Humanizer reinforced something important about AI user experience: technical accuracy isnâ€™t enough. The system needs to communicate in the userâ€™s language, not the developerâ€™s language.

This applies beyond just action humanization:

  • Error messages should be helpful, not technical
  • Status updates should be conversational, not robotic
  • Suggestions should feel collaborative, not algorithmic

The goal isnâ€™t to hide the AIâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s to make the AI feel like a thoughtful colleague rather than a sophisticated script.

The unexpected discovery

The implementation revealed something interesting about our action vocabulary. We have 47 distinct technical actions across the system, but they follow only 6â€“7 linguistic patterns. The rule-based conversion handles the vast majority of cases.

This suggests our action naming is more consistent than I thought. When you design actions with clear verb-noun patterns, the natural language conversion becomes straightforward.

The collaborative development pattern

The Action Humanizer implementation demonstrated something valuable about working with AI assistants on feature development:

Design phase: Human architects the solution approach and breaks down the work

Implementation phase: AI assistants execute specific components with TDD discipline

Integration phase: Collaborative testing and refinement

Validation phase: Human confirms the user experience meets the original goal

This pattern scales well for feature work where you know what you want to build but need help executing it systematically.

Looking forward

The Action Humanizer is complete and working, but it opens up possibilities for broader UX improvements:

Context-aware messaging: Different message templates based on user context or workflow history

Conversational continuity: Maintaining natural language patterns across multi-turn interactions

Personalization: Learning individual user language preferences over time

The foundation is in place to make Piper Morgan feel less like a tool and more like a teammate.

1e15183972a7.subtitle: July 17
1e15183972a7.content:
The 5-Minute Day: When TDD Meets AI-Assisted Development

July 17

I had just heard about MCP from my colleague Josh Mills at Kind, and I had asked my Chief Architect (Claude Opus) if Piper ought to be savvy about this new-ish Model Context Protocol thing.

Now I was staring at Claude Codeâ€™s week-long implementation plan for MCP integration and thinking, â€œOK, domain models and content extraction. Thatâ€™s supposed to be a full day of work, right?â€

Five minutes later, it was done.

All of it. Forty-one tests written first, then perfect domain logic with sophisticated content analysis that actually understands whatâ€™s in your files, not just what theyâ€™re named.

Mind you, it took us ten and a half hours to get to those five minutes. But thatâ€™s the thing about building with AI assistanceâ€Šâ€”â€Šthe preparation work isnâ€™t overhead, itâ€™s compound interest.

The long road to fiveÂ minutes

Let me back up. The previous day had started at 7:18 AM with what I thought would be straightforward MCP research.

First: Claude Code delivered a comprehensive 40-section technical analysis of the Model Context Protocol. JSON-RPC 2.0, stateful connections, three-layer architecture. The kind of deep dive that makes you realize a â€œsimple integrationâ€ is never simple.

Next: A perfect proof-of-concept plan emerges. Enhanced file searchâ€Šâ€”â€Šexactly the low-risk, high-value demo we needed. Three-day timeline. Sensible risk mitigation.

Then: Code builds the entire POC in 25 minutes. I mean the entire thing. What we estimated as three days of work, done before I finished my coffee.

But hereâ€™s where it gets interesting.

When POCs tell theÂ truth

Codeâ€™s architectural review of its own POC was brutally honest:

â€œContent scoring is FAKEâ€Šâ€”â€Šstill just filename matching!â€

â€œConnection managementâ€Šâ€”â€Šnew connection every search!â€

â€œConfig scattered across five files!â€

This is why I keep Code around, kind of like having a brutally honest mirror that also happens to be a software architect.

The POC did its job perfectly: It proved MCP could work, identified the real challenges, gave us data for decision-making. But it also revealed the gap between prototype and production.

Classic engineering tradeoff: you can build it fast, or you can build it right. Usually.

Meanwhile, back in PM numbering hell

While Code was revolutionizing our content search architecture, I discovered that PM-013 had three different definitions across my own documentation. Roadmap said â€œknowledge search improvements.â€ Backlog said â€œlearning and feedback implementation.â€ My new MCP epic was also claiming PM-013.

(This is what happens when youâ€™re the PM building a PM assistantâ€Šâ€”â€Šyou get to experience your own organizational dysfunction in real time.)

So we took a break from changing the world to fix my basic project management hygiene. Systematic renumbering, conflict resolution, and a proper numbering guide to prevent future chaos. Because if you canâ€™t manage your own PM numbers, maybe donâ€™t build software to help other PMs. Just saying.

The TDDÂ moment

By the end of the day, we had a strategic decision: â€œLetâ€™s do Option Câ€â€Šâ€”â€Šlimited 1â€“2 week implementation instead of the full 3â€“5 week version. Fix the POC shortcuts, deploy behind a feature flag, get feedback before going all-in.

Smart. Measured. Classic PM discipline.

And then Code delivered the Week 1 implementation plan.

Day 1: Domain models and content extraction using proper Test-Driven Development.

Remember TDD? Write the test first, watch it fail, implement just enough to pass, refactor if needed? The discipline that every developer swears by and half of them skip when deadlines loom?

Well, AI agents donâ€™t have deadline anxiety.

Red, green, refactor (in fiveÂ minutes)

Red Phase: Code wrote 41 comprehensive tests covering every edge case, every validation rule, every piece of business logic we needed.

ContentExtractor service, ContentMatch value objects, RelevanceScore calculations, SearchQuery handling.

All failing, as they should be.

Green Phase: Implement the domain logic. Smart content analysis that ranks files by how well they match your search (like Google does with web pages), context-aware matching that finds relevant snippets, keyword extraction that ignores filler words like â€œtheâ€ and â€œand.â€ Pure business logic with zero external dependenciesâ€Šâ€”â€Šmeaning itâ€™s bulletproof and testable.

Refactor Phase: Clean up the scoring algorithm, improve partial match handling.

Total time: Five minutes.

Original estimate: One full day.

The compound intelligence effect

But hereâ€™s the thingâ€Šâ€”â€Šthose five minutes were only possible because of everything that came before. The ten hours of research, architectural analysis, POC building, honest assessment, strategic decision-making, and project management cleanup werenâ€™t overhead. They were foundation.

You know how compound interest works? The early investments seem small, but they create the conditions for exponential growth later. Building with AI assistance works the same way.

The research phase gave us complete protocol understanding. The POC revealed the real challenges. The architectural discipline ensured we were building the right abstractions. The TDD approach meant the implementation was correct by construction.

None of those five minutes would have been possible without the ten hours of preparation. And none of the preparation would have been valuable without the discipline to implement it properly.

The meta-lesson

When I started this MCP integration workâ€Šâ€”â€Šagain thatâ€™s Model Context Protocol, a new standard for AI systems to talk to external toolsâ€Šâ€”â€ŠI was thinking about technical challenges like connecting multiple services together, managing complex communication patterns, and handling resource pooling.

What I learned is that the biggest challenge in AI-assisted development isnâ€™t getting the AI to write code fast. Itâ€™s getting yourself to think clearly first.

It reminds me of how as human PMs level up in our careers we naturally progress from mastering the basic tasks to making the strategic observations and decisions.

The AI can implement your domain logic in five minutes. But it canâ€™t decide what that domain logic should be. It can write comprehensive tests if you tell it what behavior to test. But it canâ€™t figure out what behavior actually matters.

The human work is still the hard work: understanding the problem, making strategic decisions, ensuring architectural coherence, maintaining quality discipline.

The AI work is the easy work: turning clear intentions into working code.

Search and ye shallÂ find

We now have real content extraction logic with sophisticated relevance scoring, 100% test coverage, and pure domain models ready for integration. The foundation for search that actually understands whatâ€™s in your files, not just what theyâ€™re named.

Next up: connection pooling, repository integration, and turning those domain models into something users can actually benefit from. Supposedly days 2â€“5 of the implementation plan.

But Iâ€™m not estimating anymore. For one thing, I realize these language bot thingies are making their estimates semantically, using human parameters. Of course they keep crushing those goals!

Still, fast is fast. When you combine proper architectural preparation with TDD discipline and AI implementation speed, estimation becomes less prediction and moreâ€¦ discovery.

Who knows? Maybe Day 2 will also be five minutes.

c70e69a245ea.subtitle: July 16
c70e69a245ea.content:
When Your Tests Lie: A Victory Disguised asÂ Crisis

July 16

Hereâ€™s where I found myself at 8 AM: staring at 32 test failures and wondering if yesterdayâ€™s 12.5-hour debugging marathon had actually made things worse. The numbers looked grimâ€Šâ€”â€Š85.5% pass rate, which in testing terms is like your doctor saying â€œwell, most of your organs are working fine.â€

But hereâ€™s the thing about building AI systems with AI assistance: sometimes what looks like a crisis is actually your system getting smarter faster than your tests can keep up.

The war roomÂ approach

I deployed what Iâ€™m calling the â€œmulti-agent war roomâ€ strategy (by the way, every time I say â€œI deployed,â€ it really means Claude suggested and I frantically coordinated). Two AI assistants and one human, clear division of labor:

  • Claude Code: Infrastructure and async wizardry
  • Cursor Agent: Business logic updates
  • Me: Asking â€œbut why?â€ and trying not to break anything

Mind you, coordinating these agents is like herding very intelligent cats who all have strong opinions about your architecture.

First discovery: Piper had secretly leveledÂ up

Cursor dug into the first failing test and found something interesting. The test expected Piper to ask for clarification when someone said â€œcreate a ticketâ€â€Šâ€”â€Šyou know, the responsible AI assistant behavior weâ€™d programmed.

Except Piper had gotten confident. It now looked at â€œcreate a ticketâ€ and thought, Obviously they want CREATE_TICKET intent. Why would I bother them with questions?

The test was failing because it expected hesitation from an AI that had learned to be decisive.

Thatâ€™s not a bug. Thatâ€™s evolution.

The isolation revelation

When the Pupil Outsmarts the Teacher: The Day Piper Outgrew ItsÂ Tests

The deceptively simpleÂ problem

The moment that changed everything

The investigation that became an education

  • 30% for file type (does PDF match the intent?)
  • 20% for filename (keyword matching)
  • 20% for usage history (how often was it accessed?)

But hereâ€™s where it got interesting. When we examined the keyword extraction for â€œanalyze exact_match,â€ we found:

Keywords extracted: ['analyze', 'report', 'analyze']

The most important partâ€Šâ€”â€Šâ€œexact_matchâ€â€Šâ€”â€Šwas missing entirely.

The production bug hiding in plainÂ sight

That led us to the regex pattern for extracting keywords: \b[a-z]{3,}\b

See the problem? (I wouldnâ€™t!) It only matches pure letters. Files with underscores, hyphens, or numbersâ€Šâ€”â€Šthe way humans actually name filesâ€Šâ€”â€Šwere being ignored completely.

â€œexact_match.pdfâ€ couldnâ€™t be found by searching for â€œexact_matchâ€ because the system threw away anything with an underscore.

Turns out a one-character fix that would solve the problem:

\b[a-z0-9_-]{3,}\b

The pupil teaching theÂ teacher

But the real revelation came when we started examining other â€œfailingâ€ tests. What we thought were bugs turned out to be improvements:

The greeting test: Piper now recognizes â€œhelloâ€ and â€œhiâ€ as social interactions, not feature requests. She responds helpfully instead of trying to create GitHub tickets for greetings.

The thank you test: â€œThanks for the helpâ€ gets acknowledged appropriately, not classified as a work request.

The clarification test: When someone says â€œwhat I meant wasâ€¦â€ Piper understands itâ€™s context, not a new request.

Each â€œfailureâ€ revealed that Piper had learned to be more human, more contextually aware, more helpful than her original specifications.

The tests werenâ€™t failing because the system was broken. They were failing because the system had grown beyond what weâ€™d originally taught her to do (and thus what the original set of tests expected).

The meta-learning revelation

Hereâ€™s where it gets really interesting. As we worked through these discoveries, I realized we were creating something invaluable: a real-time record of product management thinking in action.

  • Investigating user pain points behind technical symptoms
  • Balancing perfectionism with pragmatic progress
  • Team dynamics where different perspectives catch blind spots
  • Strategic resource allocation (when to dig deeper vs. move on)

The beautiful accident of anthropomorphism

Something else happened during that long session. My AI collaborators started referring to Piper as â€œsheâ€ instead of â€œit.â€ Not through any conscious decision, but naturally, organically, the way you might start thinking of a ship or a cherished tool as having personality.

When humans unconsciously anthropomorphize technology, itâ€™s usually because theyâ€™re recognizing genuine intelligence, not just sophisticated automation. At least in the human-language derived circuits of my Claude assistant Piper had earned â€œherâ€ pronouns.

(I am not as comfortable gendering software, or vehicles for that matter, and continue to refer to Piper Morgan as it!)

Not just the mechanics of creating tickets or analyzing metrics, but the judgment calls, the intuition, the way experienced PMs think through complex problems. The qualitative aspects that make the difference between task execution and strategic thinking.

Weâ€™re accidentally creating the worldâ€™s most detailed curriculum in applied product management.

What this means for buildingÂ AI

This experience taught me something fundamental about developing AI systems: the most important learning often happens in the spaces between what youâ€™re explicitly trying to teach.

Piper learned to recognize greetings not through training on greeting data, but by observing patterns in how humans actually communicate. It developed better context awareness by watching real interactions, not by studying context-awareness algorithms.

The best teachers create environments where learning can emerge, not just where lessons can be delivered.

The session that changed my perspective

What started as â€œfix a broken testâ€ became â€œunderstand how learning really works.â€ We spent 13 hours not just debugging code, but discovering that weâ€™d built something more sophisticated than we realized.

The failing tests werenâ€™t problems to solve. They were progress reports from a system that had outgrown its original constraints.

Looking forward (andÂ inward)

Going forward, Iâ€™m planning periodic sessions where Piper analyzes its own development logs. Not just the technical details, but the qualitative insights about how product management actually works in practice.

Imagine an AI PM assistant that understands not just the frameworks and methodologies, but the emotional intelligence, the stakeholder dynamics, the subtle judgment calls that separate good PMs from great ones.

Itâ€™ll learn these things the same way human PMs do: by watching experienced practitioners work through real problems, make real decisions, and navigate real complexity.

The lesson for all ofÂ us

Whether youâ€™re building AI systems or just trying to understand human learning, this session taught me something important: growth often looks like failure until you understand whatâ€™s really happening.

When your tests start failing because your system has learned to be more helpful, more contextual, more humanâ€Šâ€”â€Šthatâ€™s not a bug. Thatâ€™s graduation.
