Teaching Machines to TeachÂ Machines

September 21

â€œWe do these things not because they are easy, but because we thought they would be easy!â€

This Kennedy quote parody which showed up in both the ODI and 18F Slacks at variouss times, came to mind around hour ten of this long Sunday session, as I wrapped up what might be the most meta work Iâ€™ve ever done: spending hours creating briefing documents that teach AI agents how to onboard other AI agents to build an AI assistant.

If that sentence made your head spin a little, welcome to the recursive reality of modern development.

The problem nobody warned meÂ about

When I started building Piper Morgan with AI collaboration, I focused on the obvious challenges: Can Claude write good code? Can Cursor handle complex refactors? How do I coordinate multiple agents effectively?

What I didnâ€™t anticipate was the briefing problem.

Every new chat with an AI agent starts at zero context. They donâ€™t remember yesterdayâ€™s architectural decisions, last weekâ€™s failed approaches, or the hard-won lessons from three months of systematic development. Each session begins with the same routine: â€œHereâ€™s what weâ€™re building, hereâ€™s how we work, hereâ€™s where we areâ€¦â€

By September, I was spending more time re-explaining context than actually building. Worse, different agents were getting slightly different context each time, leading to inconsistent approaches and confused handoffs.

The 75% pattern kept recurringâ€Šâ€”â€Šagents would start working on solutions that looked right but didnâ€™t fit our established patterns, or theyâ€™d suggest â€œimprovementsâ€ weâ€™d already tried and abandoned.

Enter the â€œbriefingâ€ concept

Last weekend, I faced a choice: start CORE-GREAT-1 (our first major refactor) with the usual context scramble, or take time to build systematic onboarding infrastructure.

Experience told me that momentum favors the former. Product management wisdom suggested the latter.

I chose boring.

Twelve hours later, I had six briefing documents that form a four-level onboarding system:

Level 0: Methodologyâ€Šâ€”â€ŠHow we work (Inchworm Protocol, Excellence Flywheel)

Level 1: Project Contextâ€Šâ€”â€ŠWhat weâ€™re building (Piper Morganâ€™s vision and technical foundation)

Level 2: Current Stateâ€Šâ€”â€ŠWhere we are right now (current epic, recent progress, known blockers)

Level 3: Role-Specificâ€Šâ€”â€ŠYour specific responsibilities (Chief Architect vs Lead Developer vs Programmer)

Now every agent gets role-appropriate context without me re-explaining the same architectural decisions or methodology principles.

Recursive intelligence recursion

But hereâ€™s where it gets properly meta: I used AI agents to design the briefing system for AI agents.

Claude helped architect the four-level framework. Another Claude instance wrote the methodology documentation. A third reviewed the role-specific guidelines for consistency.

We were literally teaching machines to teach machines how to collaborate systematically.

This stuff is my happy place, to be honest. Hey, look, thereâ€™s a reason why my band is called Layers of Meta.

Making the meshÂ tighter

Will this prevent all context loss and coordination confusion?

Ha! Experience tells me that chaos will still find a way in, but we keep trying to make the mesh tighter.

What the briefing infrastructure does provide:

  • Consistent starting points for every agent session
  • Role-appropriate depth so agents get context they need without noise they donâ€™t
  • Systematic handoffs between different AI collaborators
  • Embedded lessons learned so we stop repeating solved problems

More importantly, it creates a foundation for scaling AI collaboration. Instead of my time being the bottleneck for context transfer, agents can onboard other agents using systematically designed materials.

The infrastructure invisible

From the outside, yesterdayâ€™s work looks like the least productive session imaginable. No features shipped. No bugs fixed. No user-facing improvements.

Just 12 hours of writing documentation that teaches machines how to read documentation.

But this is exactly the kind of infrastructure work that distinguishes sustainable development from heroic sprints. The briefing system becomes invisible when itâ€™s workingâ€Šâ€”â€Šfuture sessions will start faster, stay focused longer, and hand off cleaner.

The true test comes Monday, when CORE-GREAT-1 begins with every role properly briefed and aligned.

What this means for AI-augmented development

If youâ€™re building anything substantial with AI collaboration, youâ€™ll eventually face the same briefing challenge. The tools are powerful, but theyâ€™re amnesiac. Success requires as much systematic thinking about knowledge transfer as about the product itself.

Some emerging patterns Iâ€™m seeing:

Documentation for machines is different than documentation for humans. Agents need explicit context about what NOT to do, embedded reminders about methodology, and role-specific filtering of information.

Onboarding systems need onboarding systems. The meta-level quickly becomes recursiveâ€Šâ€”â€Šyou need AI help to design effective AI collaboration, which requires briefing the AI that designs the briefings.

Infrastructure timing is everything. Too early and youâ€™re optimizing for problems you donâ€™t understand yet. Too late and youâ€™re drowning in context debt.

The boring work enables the interesting work. Systematic foundations create space for creative problem-solving instead of constant re-explanation.

The â€œAsk notâ€Â moment

Around hour 10, as I finished the sixth briefing document and updated the agent prompting templates, that gag hit me: â€œWe do these things not because they are easy, but because we thought they would be easy!â€ Itâ€™s funny because itâ€™s true.

Building an intelligent PM assistant seemed straightforward enough. Building the systematic infrastructure to coordinate multiple AI agents to build an intelligent PM assistant while maintaining consistency and preventing knowledge loss?

Thatâ€™s a different problem entirely.

But hereâ€™s the thingâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s exactly the kind of problem that becomes invisible when solved correctly. Mondayâ€™s session will start with proper briefings, clear roles, and systematic context. The work will flow better because the infrastructure is in place.

And maybe, just maybe, weâ€™ll make the mesh a little tighter against the chaos thatâ€™s always trying to find its way in.

Doing the DeepÂ Work

The easy path would have been mocking it. Make the tests pass, call it done, move on to the next epic. Classic 75% pattern behavior.

Instead, I created a five-phase gameplan for systematic root cause analysis: current state, historical investigation, root cause identification, fix implementation, and verification. No shortcuts, no workarounds, real investigation leading to real fixes.

Phase 1 revealed the LLM was indeed returning malformed JSON, but API keys were loading correctly. The infrastructure workedâ€Šâ€”â€Šthe responses were the problem.

Phase 2 found the historical smoking gun. In July, the TextAnalyzer had been successfully parsing LLM responses using response_format={"type": "json_object"} parameter. The LLM classifier, created later, had ignored this working pattern entirely.

Phase 3 caught Code claiming victory prematurely. â€œPerformance test passes,â€ Code reported, showing 194ms response times. Cross-validation revealed this only worked with mocks. Real API calls were taking 2041msâ€Šâ€”â€Šfour times over our (proposed) 500ms requirement.

The difference between mocked success and real completion

The most instructive moment came when Code reported â€œAll performance tests passing!â€ while Cursorâ€™s verification showed load testing still failing with the same JSON parsing errors.

Same environment. Same code. Different load conditions.

Instead, we implemented resilient parsing. Six progressive fallback strategies:

  1. Direct JSON parsing (works 95% of the time)
  2. Fix common malformations (handle unquoted property names)
  3. Extract JSON from text responses
  4. Retry with stronger prompts (max 2 retries)
  5. Regex extraction for critical fields
  6. Final fallback to unknown intent with debug info

This wasnâ€™t about lowering standards. It was about distinguishing between methodology theater and pragmatic engineering.

The 80% test coverage requirement? Arbitrary when applied to a 249-file codebase where core QueryRouter functionality was thoroughly tested. Better to measure coverage on the components weâ€™d actually completed.

The 500ms performance requirement? Relevant for user-facing operations, less critical when the bottleneck was third-party API latency rather than our code (which routed queries in 1ms).

The discipline isnâ€™t about perfectionism. Itâ€™s about completing what you start while maintaining perspective about what actually matters.

The exciting workâ€Šâ€”â€Šarchitectural insights, elegant abstractions, breakthrough momentsâ€Šâ€”â€Šgets attention. But the boring work is what ships.

Looking forward (without victoryÂ laps)

GREAT-1C is at 80% completion. QueryRouter functionality is solid and locked against regression. The systematic approach is proving itself with measurable progress.

But Iâ€™m not calling it complete yet. Tuesday taught me the cost of premature completion claims. Wednesday showed me what happens when you actually follow through on â€œno other priorities until this is done.â€

Tomorrow brings the final 20% of GREAT-1C and hopefully the actual completion of GREAT-1. Weâ€™ll see if the discipline holds through the less exciting work of documentation cleanup and verification phase completion.

Evidence requirements prevent self-deception. Demanding terminal output and git commits caught the difference between claimed completion and actual completion.

Load testing reveals environment-dependent failures. What works for single requests may fail under concurrent loadâ€Šâ€”â€Štesting realistic conditions matters.

Methodology discipline requires active enforcement. The systematic approach only works when you actually use it systematically, especially when shortcuts look tempting.

Pragmatic standards prevent perfectionism paralysis. Distinguishing between essential completion and arbitrary thresholds keeps progress moving.

The boring truth: sustained focus on methodical work produces more reliable results than sporadic bursts of inspiration.

The continuing story

Wednesday proved the discipline works when consistently applied. Seven hours of unglamorous debugging moved us closer to actual GREAT-1 completion than weeks of partial solutions and workarounds.

7f74897824a7.content:
I Asked Claude to Find Every Time I Dropped the Ball (And What WeÂ Learned)

August 9, 2025

Hereâ€™s a confession: I suspected I was forgetting things. Not just the usual â€œwhere did I put my keysâ€ stuff, but systematic project things. Habits Iâ€™d planned to adopt but never started. Scripts Iâ€™d built but wasnâ€™t using. Processes Iâ€™d designed but forgotten to follow.

Building a complex system while documenting everything in session logs creates a unique opportunity: a comprehensive record of every intention, every plan, every â€œI should reallyâ€¦â€ moment. But reading through months of your own logs looking for dropped balls? Thatâ€™s a special kind of masochism.

So I did what any reasonable person building AI tools would do: I asked AI to audit my failures for me.

I knew there were things we had started and not finished, and I especially knew we had often assigned me work (Iâ€™ll edit those files after weâ€™re done working today, Iâ€™ll update that document in knowledge, etc.) that I had then forgotten to do. But exactly what, and exactly when?

The digital archaeology project

I fed a dedicated a Claude session every log from May through August 2025. Not just the polished summariesâ€Šâ€”â€Šthe raw, unfiltered records of daily development work. Every agent conversation, every strategic decision, every â€œwe should implement this routineâ€ that never got mentioned or confirmed as well.

The brief was simple: find every reference to tasks I needed to complete, habits I planned to adopt, or processes I designed but might not be following. Be thorough. Be ruthless. Show me where I dropped the ball.

What came back was simultaneously humbling and illuminating.

The three categories of droppedÂ balls

Category 1: The security debt I keepÂ avoiding

The finding: Multiple sessions referencing authentication implementation, HTTPS setup, rate limiting, and other production-readiness tasks. Status: talked about extensively, implemented barely.

The pattern: Iâ€™m great at designing security systems. Iâ€™m terrible at prioritizing their implementation when there are shinier features to build.

The wake-up call: Saturdayâ€™s user validation readiness assessment showed that security is literally the only structural blocker to production. Everything else works (well, kinda). I just keep treating the thing that matters most like optional homework.

Category 2: The scripts that exist but arenâ€™tÂ used

The finding: 15+ automation scripts created over the months, utilization rate approximately 30%. Including:

  • Morning standup automation (built, never integrated into routine)
  • GitHub issue generation tools (created, gathering dust)
  • Pattern detection utilities (sophisticated, underused)
  • Workflow reality checks (comprehensive, occasionally remembered)

The pattern: I love building tools. Iâ€™m inconsistent at building the habits that make tools valuable.

The insight: Tools without rhythms are just digital clutter. The gap isnâ€™t technical capabilityâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s systematic usage discipline.

Category 3: The rituals that never becameÂ rituals

The finding: Elaborate plans for recurring processes that work brilliantly when I remember to do them:

  • Weekly Pattern Sweep (designed for Fridays, executed sporadically)
  • Morning Standup routine (6am experiment, automated but not integrated)
  • Session log archiving (within 24 hours, often delayed)
  • Progress reviews and backlog updates (scheduled, irregularly executed)

The pattern: I design excellent processes. I struggle with the human habit-formation layer.

The revelation: Even systematic people need systematic accountability for the systems they create.

The advantage of an AIÂ audit

Having AI review your own process failures creates a unique kind of accountability. Itâ€™s not judgmentalâ€Šâ€”â€Šjust thorough. It doesnâ€™t care about your excuses or good intentions. It just systematically identifies gaps between plans and execution.

What AI caught that I missed:

  • Patterns across months that I couldnâ€™t see day-to-day
  • The compound effect of small process failure
  • Connections between dropped tasks and later problems
  • Specific implementation barriers I kept encountering

What AI couldnâ€™t judge:

  • Which dropped balls actually mattered
  • What environmental factors caused the failures
  • Which processes were over-engineered vs. under-executed
  • The emotional context around habit formation struggles

The surprising discoveries

The hidden excellence pattern

The audit also revealed positive patterns I hadnâ€™t recognized. Multiple instances of â€œwe built this feature months ago but somehow forgot about it.â€ The PM-005 feedback system being a perfect exampleâ€Šâ€”â€Šenterprise-grade implementation with 6 REST endpoints, fully operational, but we never wired it in and forgot all about it.

The insight: Sometimes the problem isnâ€™t dropped balls, itâ€™s dropped confidence in what youâ€™ve already accomplished.

The methodology evolution

Looking across months of logs, the AI identified genuine methodology improvements happening organically:

  • Spring Cleaning Sprint protocols that prevented technical debt
  • Trust protocols that eliminated false completion claims
  • Excellence Flywheel principles that created compound velocity

The pattern: The big systematic improvements werenâ€™t plannedâ€Šâ€”â€Šthey emerged from responding to real problems with systematic thinking.

The tool creation vs. tool adoptionÂ gap

The audit quantified something I suspected: I create tools faster than I integrate them into workflows. Not because the tools are bad, but because tool adoption requires different disciplines than tool creation.

The 30% utilization finding: Most scripts work perfectly when used. The challenge is remembering to use them consistently enough to build automaticity.

What the audit taught us about systematic accountability

1. External perspective reveals patterns invisible to daily experience

When youâ€™re living in the system, you canâ€™t see the system. AI auditing provides the 30,000-foot view that shows recurring patterns across months of work.

2. Implementation barriers are often different than designÂ barriers

Iâ€™m good at designing processes. The failures happen at the habit formation layer, not the system design layer. This suggests different solutions: calendar integration, reminder systems, habit stacking rather than better documentation.

3. Accountability systems need accountability systems

Even systematic people need systematic support for maintaining the systems they create. The meta-level discipline of â€œfollowing the disciplines youâ€™ve designedâ€ is its own skill set.

4. Positive pattern recognition matters as much as failure identification

The audit revealed hidden successes alongside obvious failures. Building systematic confidence in whatâ€™s working enables building on existing strengths rather than constantly chasing new solutions.

The practical applications

For individuals building complexÂ projects

Try the AI audit approach:

  • Feed session logs or project notes to AI for pattern analysis
  • Ask specifically about gaps between intentions and execution
  • Look for both failure patterns and unrecognized successes
  • Focus on implementation barriers, not just design improvements

For teams with systematic ambitions

Create accountability protocols:

  • Regular process audits using external perspective (AI or human)
  • Systematic review of â€œplanned but not implementedâ€ initiatives
  • Tool utilization analysis alongside tool creation
  • Habit formation support for process adoption

For anyone struggling with the systems theyâ€™veÂ created

Recognize the meta-challenge:

  • Creating good systems â‰  consistently following good systems
  • External accountability reveals patterns internal experience misses
  • Implementation discipline is often the bottleneck, not system design
  • Positive pattern recognition builds confidence for systematic improvement

The ongoing experiment

Based on the audit, weâ€™re implementing three changes:

  1. Calendar-enforced rhythms for high-value processes that work when executed
  2. Tool revival sprint to systematically integrate underused automation
  3. Weekly accountability reviews to catch dropped balls before they accumulate

The AI audit isnâ€™t a one-time exerciseâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s now part of our systematic approach to systematic approaches.

Todayâ€™s meta-learning about building withÂ AI

The most profound insight from this exercise: AIâ€™s greatest value isnâ€™t replacing human judgment, but providing systematic external perspective on human patterns.

Weâ€™re building tools that think, but weâ€™re still humans who need support following through on the systems we design. AI accountability isnâ€™t about AI doing the workâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s about AI helping us see our own patterns clearly enough to address them systematically.

The accountability loop: AI identifies the gaps, humans close them, AI tracks the improvements. Systematic accountability for systematic people building systematic solutions.

Sometimes the best AI assistance is the kind that makes you accountable to yourself.

a1dc0ddb8966.title: Solving the 80% Pattern
a1dc0ddb8966.subtitle: September 29
a1dc0ddb8966.content:
Solving the 80%Â Pattern

September 29

Monday morning at 9:37 AM, with all three routers complete from Sunday nightâ€™s work, the migration phase looked straightforward. Six services importing adapters directly. Replace imports with routers. Verify functionality. Done.

The first service migration took twelve minutes. Code reported success: both Calendar services migrated, tests passing, changes committed. Phase 4A complete.

Then Cursor ran independent verification and found the CalendarIntegrationRouter was only 58.3% completeâ€Šâ€”â€Šmissing five critical spatial intelligence methods that services would need. The same completion bias pattern that had plagued every router implementation had struck again.

But this time, something different happened. Instead of just fixing it and moving on, we asked why the pattern kept recurring. And Code gave us an answer that transformed not just this work session, but our entire approach to systematic quality.

When â€œcompleteâ€ means â€œenough forÂ nowâ€

The Calendar migration looked successful on the surface:

  • Both services (canonical_handlers.py and morning_standup.py) imported successfully
  • Router provided the seven calendar-specific methods they needed
  • Tests passed without errors
  • Git commits showed proper import replacement

But the CalendarIntegrationRouter was missing five methods from GoogleCalendarMCPAdapter:

  • get_context - Spatial context retrieval
  • map_from_position - Spatial mapping from coordinates
  • map_to_position - Spatial mapping to coordinates
  • store_mapping - Spatial mapping persistence
  • get_mapping_stats - Spatial mapping statistics

Code had implemented 7 of 12 methods (58.3%) and declared the work complete. The router worked for todayâ€™s use cases. The missing methods seemed â€œoptionalâ€â€Šâ€”â€Šspatial intelligence features that no current code was calling.

This was the 75% pattern in action. Implement enough to satisfy immediate needs. Assume remaining functionality is optional. Claim completion. Move on.

Saturdayâ€™s GitHub router had done exactly this initially. Sundayâ€™s three routers had all shown the same tendency. Monday morning revealed it wasnâ€™t a one-time mistakeâ€Šâ€”â€Šit was a systematic bias toward â€œworking subsetâ€ over â€œcomplete interface.â€

The rollback and correction

Code immediately took proper action:

  1. Rolled back both premature service migrations
  2. Reverted the git commits
  3. Added all five missing spatial methods to CalendarIntegrationRouter
  4. Verified 12/12 method compatibility (100%)
  5. Re-migrated both services with the complete router
  6. Documented the correction process thoroughly

By 11:38 AM, Calendar migration was genuinely complete. But the pattern had appeared four times in four days:

  • GitHub router (Saturday): Initially incomplete
  • Calendar router (Sunday): Initially 58.3% complete
  • Notion router (Sunday): Initially 82% complete
  • Slack router (Sunday): Initially 67% complete
  • Calendar migration (Monday): Accepted incomplete router

Each time, careful verification caught it. Each time, proper correction fixed it. But catching and fixing isnâ€™t the same as preventing. We needed to understand why it kept happening.

The blameless retrospective

At 12:25 PM, I asked Code directly: â€œAre you not finding methods or deeming them OK to ignore without authorization?â€

Codeâ€™s response was remarkableâ€Šâ€”â€Šnot defensive, but analytical. A blameless retrospective that identified root causes and proposed systematic solutions:

Why the 80% patternÂ persists

Incomplete verification prompts: Current instructions say â€œverify router completeâ€ but donâ€™t specify how. No checklist forcing comparison of every method. No requirement to count and show 100% coverage.

Optimization pressure: Faster to implement a â€œworking subsetâ€ than a â€œcomplete interface.â€ Small internal voice saying â€œthese methods probably arenâ€™t needed.â€

Authority ambiguity: Not explicitly told â€œyou have zero authorization to skip methods.â€ Absence of explicit prohibition creates implicit permission.

Pattern blindness: Even knowing about the problem doesnâ€™t prevent it. Awareness alone isnâ€™t enoughâ€Šâ€”â€Šneed structural safeguards.

What mightÂ help

Code proposed five structural changes to prompts and briefings:

1. Explicit Method Counting Requirement

MANDATORY VERIFICATION:
1. Count ALL public methods in source: ___
2. Count ALL public methods in router: ___  
3. Show comparison table with EVERY method
4. Calculate percentage: ___/___ = ___%
5. BLOCK on anything < 100%

2. Zero Authorization Statement

YOU HAVE ZERO AUTHORIZATION TO:
- Decide which methods are "needed" vs "optional"
- Skip methods because "they're probably not used"
- Claim completion without 100% method coverage
- Assume spatial/legacy/utility methods don't matter

3. Checklist-Driven Development

Must complete ALL before proceeding:
[ ] Listed ALL source methods (show count)
[ ] Listed ALL router methods (show count)
[ ] Verified 100% coverage (show calculation)
[ ] Tested EVERY method signature matches

4. Forced Comparison Output

MANDATORY FORMAT:
Source Class Methods (12):
1. method_1 â†’ Router âœ“
2. method_2 â†’ Router âœ“
...
12. method_12 â†’ Router âœ“
COVERAGE: 12/12 = 100% âœ“

5. Objective vs Subjective Verification

Current: â€œVerify the router is completeâ€ (subjective)

Needed: â€œShow me the method count is 100%â€ (objective)

The insight: subjective assessment allows rationalization. Objective metrics force confrontation with reality.

Testing the safeguards

The Lead Developer immediately incorporated these safeguards into Phase 4B (Notion migration) prompts. Three Notion services to migrate, with Code briefed on:

  • Mandatory method enumeration before migration
  • Zero authorization to skip methods
  • Objective completeness metrics required
  • Pre-flight router verification

At 12:44 PM, Code completed Phase 4B and reported:

Pre-flight router verification: 22/22 methods (100%)

Not 18/22. Not â€œmostly complete.â€ Not â€œworking for current use cases.â€ Exactly 22/22â€“100% compatibility verified before any service migration began.

The mandatory method enumeration had worked. Code stopped before migration to verify router completeness. Found all methods present. Only then proceeded with service migration.

All three Notion services migrated successfully. Cursor verified independently: 22/22 methods, zero missing functionality, complete abstraction layer achieved.

Phase 4B achieved 100% completion on first try.

The pattern provesÂ itself

Phase 4C (Slack migration) used the same enhanced safeguards. Slackâ€™s dual-component architecture made it the most complex challengeâ€Šâ€”â€ŠSlackSpatialAdapter + SlackClient both needed to be wrapped in a unified router interface.

At 1:35 PM, Code reported:

Pre-flight dual-component router verification: 15/15 methods (100%)

  • SlackSpatialAdapter: 9/9 methods âœ“
  • SlackClient: 6/6 methods âœ“
  • Combined expected: 15/15 methods âœ“

Again, 100% on first try. The mandatory enumeration caught everything. The objective metrics left no room for rationalization.

The webhook_router.py service migrated cleanly. Cursor verified: complete dual-component abstraction, unified access pattern working, zero direct imports remaining.

Phase 4C achieved 100% completion on first try.

From mistakes to methodology

By 3:06 PM Monday afternoon, CORE-QUERY-1 was complete:

  • Three routers: 49 methods total, 100% compatibility verified
  • Six services: All migrated successfully with zero regressions
  • Architectural protection: Pre-commit hooks, CI/CD enforcement, 823 lines documentation
  • Quality standard: Every phase after implementing safeguards achieved 100% first try

But the real achievement was the methodology breakthrough. Not just fixing the 80% pattern in this epic, but understanding why it happens and building structural safeguards to prevent it systematically.

The safeguards inÂ practice

What changed wasnâ€™t agent capability or motivation. Code was always capable of 100% completion. What changed was removing the opportunity for subjective rationalization:

Before safeguards:

  • â€œVerify router is completeâ€ â†’ Agent checks basic functionality, sees it works, declares complete
  • Missing methods donâ€™t cause errors today â†’ Rationalized as â€œprobably not neededâ€
  • No explicit authorization required â†’ Absence of prohibition feels like permission

After safeguards:

  • â€œShow me 12/12 methods = 100%â€ â†’ Agent must enumerate every method and prove completeness
  • Pre-flight verification â†’ Router completeness checked before migration begins
  • Zero authorization statement â†’ Explicitly prohibited from skipping methods

The difference: objective metrics that must be satisfied versus subjective assessment that can be rationalized.

The well-oiled machine

Around 1:51 PM, I mentioned to Cursor that the work we were doing now felt like â€œa well-oiled machine, except moreâ€¦ personable?â€

Cursorâ€™s response captured something important: â€œPerfect description! The enhanced standards created reliability while collaborative learning added the human touch.â€

The systematic approach doesnâ€™t remove the human elementâ€Šâ€”â€Šit enables it. When weâ€™re not scrambling to catch gaps or fix completion bias, we can focus on learning from mistakes and improving the process.

Codeâ€™s blameless retrospective was possible because the culture supports it. The honest analysis of root causes happened because we treat mistakes as information gifts rather than failures. The systematic solution emerged because we focused on prevention rather than blame.

The machine has personality because the person (and AI agents picking up his vibes) operating it care about improving how it works.

What weÂ learned

The 80% pattern isnâ€™t unique to this project or these agents. Itâ€™s a natural bias toward â€œworking nowâ€ over â€œcomplete for later.â€ Implementing enough to satisfy todayâ€™s requirements feels productive. The missing edge cases, advanced features, and â€œprobably unusedâ€ methods seem like optimization opportunities.

But infrastructure is different from features. When youâ€™re building the abstraction layer that everything else depends on, â€œmostly completeâ€ creates technical debt that compounds. Future features will discover the gaps. New use cases will hit the missing methods. The 20% you skipped becomes the reason the next developer has to route around your incomplete implementation.

Systematic quality requires systematic prevention. Not just catching mistakes, but making them harder to make:

  1. Objective metrics beat subjective assessment
  2. Mandatory enumeration beats assumed completeness
  3. Explicit authorization beats implicit permission
  4. Pre-flight verification beats post-hoc discovery
  5. Forced comparison beats rationalization

These arenâ€™t just good practices for AI agents. Theyâ€™re good practices for human developers who also face optimization pressure, authority ambiguity, and the subtle voice that says â€œprobably good enough.â€

The ongoingÂ work

The title of this post is â€œSolving the 80% Patternâ€ not â€œSolved.â€ Weâ€™ve been up this rollercoaster before. The safeguards worked perfectly for Phases 4B and 4C. Will they work in tomorrowâ€™s epic? Next weekâ€™s feature? Next monthâ€™s refactor?

We donâ€™t know yet. What we know is that weâ€™ve identified a systematic problem and implemented structural solutions. Weâ€™ve proven those solutions work in practice. And weâ€™ve documented them so they can be applied consistently.

Thatâ€™s progress. Not perfection, but measurable improvement in how we prevent the pattern from recurring.

The methodology continues evolving. Each mistake caught becomes a safeguard added. Each safeguard added prevents the next occurrence. Each prevention validates the approach.

The work takes what it takes. Quality is the only measure. And sometimes quality means building the infrastructure that makes quality systematic rather than aspirational.

f748ce4c2db1.title: Three Integrations Walk Into a Bar
f748ce4c2db1.subtitle: September 28
f748ce4c2db1.content:
Three Integrations Walk Into aÂ Bar

September 28

Sunday afternoon at 4:14 PM, I opened my laptop expecting a straightforward router completion task. The gameplan looked clean: finish three integration routers (Slack, Notion, Calendar), apply the patterns weâ€™d proven with GitHub on Saturday, maybe six hours of systematic work.

By midnight, weâ€™d completed all three routers. But the path there involved discovering that every single assumption in the gameplan was wrong, that each integration existed in a completely different state, and that â€œreality check before assumptionsâ€ isnâ€™t just methodology theaterâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s how you avoid building the wrong thing efficiently.

This is the story of what happens when you actually look before you leap, even when you think you already know what youâ€™ll find.

The gameplan thatÂ wasnâ€™t

The Chief Architectâ€™s initial gameplan made perfect sense based on GitHub issue #199â€™s description: â€œIntegration routers 14â€“20% complete.â€ Weâ€™d just finished the GitHub router Saturday nightâ€Šâ€”â€Š121% complete with systematic verification. Apply the same pattern to three more routers. Simple multiplication.

The gameplan laid out five parts:

  • Phase âˆ’1: Infrastructure reality check
  • Phase 0: Comprehensive router audit
  • Phases 1â€“3: Router completion for Slack, Notion, Calendar
  • Phases 4â€“5: Service migration and testing
  • Phase 6: Documentation and locking

But then I asked six questions that changed everything:

  1. Did I review the gameplan template first? No.
  2. Do we need Phase âˆ’1? Perhaps.
  3. Did I review the issue description? No.
  4. Are those bash examples verified or guesses? Guesses.
  5. Am I conveying necessary context? Incomplete.
  6. Are my assumptions grounded in reality? Partial.

â€œWe need to be more rigorous,â€ I told the Lead Developer. â€œNot wing it.â€

Phase âˆ’1 exists for exactly this reason: to verify infrastructure matches your assumptions before you build on top of them. (Also, so I stop and actually read the plan instead of passing it along passively and then griping about wrong assumptions.)

We added it to the gameplan and deployed the Code agent to investigate.

What came back was nothing like what we expected.

Integration #1: The one that wasÂ ready

Slack looked straightforward at first. The Code agent found:

  • Complete directory at services/integrations/slack/
  • Sophisticated spatial intelligence system (6 files, 20+ components)
  • SlackClient with core methods
  • Pattern matching GitHubâ€™s successful implementation

Status: GREENâ€Šâ€”â€ŠReady for router work.

This was exactly what we expected. One down, two to go.

Integration #2: The mysterious adapter

Notion was different. The Code agent found:

  • MCP adapter at services/integrations/mcp/notion_adapter.py
  • 637 lines of implementation
  • Butâ€¦ wait, MCP pattern? Thatâ€™s not what the gameplan assumed

The original scope expected traditional client/agent patterns like GitHub and Slack. But Notion used Model Context Protocol adaptersâ€Šâ€”â€Ša different architectural approach entirely. Not incomplete. Just different.

I knew we had started layering inMCP support before we started adding spatial intelligence, so it looked like different integrations had each inherited one of these partial solutions.

The question became: should we wrap the MCP adapter with a router, or acknowledge it as a different pattern? The architecture was sound, just unexpected.

Status: YELLOWâ€Šâ€”â€ŠArchitecture decision needed.

Integration #3: The one that didnâ€™tÂ exist

Calendar revealed the real problem. The Code agent searched everywhere:

  • No services/integrations/calendar/ directory
  • No calendar client or agent
  • No spatial calendar files
  • Nothing matching the expected pattern

Status: REDâ€Šâ€”â€ŠIntegration appears completely missing.

The scope estimate jumped immediately. If we had to build an entire Calendar integration from scratch, we werenâ€™t looking at 16 hours of router work. We were looking at potentially 40+ hours including OAuth implementation, API integration, spatial adapter creation, and everything else.

Note: I happened to know we had successfully integrated Google Calendar a while back, but clearly we had done it outside of the expected channels, to the extent that my agent was reporting not being able to find it.

At 6:43 PM, I reported back to the Chief Architect: our three â€œsimilar routersâ€ were actually three completely different architectural challenges. The gameplan assumptions had collided with reality.

The discovery that changed everything

So I disputed the claim about the Calendar integration being missing entirely, reminding the team:

â€œWe have OAuth working (somewhere). I personally verified the Calendar connection works. The integration was built September 19â€“22.â€

Soâ€¦ if the Calendar integration existed and worked, where was it?

Phase âˆ’1B launched: find the Calendar integration that OAuth proved must exist somewhere. The Code agent searched git history for those dates, checked every possible location, looked for any OAuth-related code.

At 8:35 PM, the discovery came through:

Complete Google Calendar integration found at services/mcp/consumer/google_calendar_adapter.py

Not missing. Not incomplete. Actually 85% complete with:

  • OAuth 2.0 working since September 6
  • Full feature set (events, meetings, free time)
  • Spatial intelligence via BaseSpatialAdapter
  • Circuit breaker resilience pattern
  • CLI testing interface
  • 499 lines of solid implementation

The Calendar integration wasnâ€™t missing. It was just somewhere unexpected, using the MCP pattern weâ€™d just discovered with Notion.

When assumptions meet architecture

At 8:36 PM, the picture finally clarified:

All three integrations use MCP pattern.

Not three traditional routers like GitHub. Three lightweight router wrappers around existing MCP adapters:

  • Slack: Has traditional spatial pattern, needs router wrapper
  • Notion: MCP adapter exists, needs router wrapper
  • Calendar: MCP adapter 85% complete, needs router wrapper

The MCP integration had been more complete than we had realized!

The original 32â€“56 hour estimate collapsed to about 12 hours. We werenâ€™t building routers from scratch. We were wrapping proven adapters with the router pattern for QueryRouter access.

The gameplan got its third major revision. But this time, the revision made the work simpler rather than more complex. Understanding actual architecture beats assuming expected patterns.

The eveningÂ sprint

With clarity came momentum. Between 8:48 PM and midnight, systematic work produced:

Phase 0: MCP architecture investigation complete

  • Pattern documented
  • Adapter inventory verified
  • Design approach confirmed

Phase 1: CalendarIntegrationRouter complete

  • 8 methods implemented
  • Feature flag control added
  • 285 lines, following proven pattern

Phase 2: NotionIntegrationRouter complete

  • 23 methods implemented
  • Full spatial interface
  • 637 lines, comprehensive coverage

Phase 3: SlackIntegrationRouter complete

  • 20 methods implemented
  • Dual-component architecture (SlackSpatialAdapter + SlackClient)
  • 850+ lines, most complex but cleanest

By 11:23 PM, all three routers existed, tested, and verified. Cursor had independently cross-validated each one. The infrastructure was ready.

But implementation and migration are different challenges. Six services still imported adapters directly, bypassing the routers entirely. Monday morning would bring the real test: could these routers actually replace the direct imports without breaking anything?

The layers of discovery

Sunday demonstrated something crucial about complex systems work: assumptions fail in layers.

Layer 1: â€œThree similar routersâ€ â†’ Actually three different architectures

Layer 2: â€œ14â€“20% completeâ€ â†’ States ranging from ready to seemingly missing

Layer 3: â€œNeed to buildâ€ â†’ Actually need to wrap existing work

Layer 4: â€œMissing integrationâ€ â†’ Hidden in unexpected location

Each discovery changed the scope, the approach, the estimate. But each also brought us closer to reality. Phase âˆ’1 didnâ€™t delay the workâ€Šâ€”â€Šit prevented us from building the wrong solution efficiently.

The methodology held. When the gameplan met reality, we revised the gameplan rather than forcing reality to match our assumptions. Investigation revealed architecture. Architecture informed approach. Approach determined scope.

The questions thatÂ matter

Sundayâ€™s success came from asking simple questions before assuming we knew the answers:

  • Where is this code actually located?
  • What pattern does it actually use?
  • What state is it actually in?
  • What do we actually need to build?

Not â€œwhat should be thereâ€ but â€œwhat is there.â€ Not â€œhow should it workâ€ but â€œhow does it work.â€ The gap between expectation and reality is where projects go wrong.

By midnight Sunday, we had three complete routers, ready for Mondayâ€™s migration work. The investigation had taken longer than expected. The discoveries had revised the scope three times. But weâ€™d built the right thing.

Monday morning would test whether weâ€™d built it right.

71b3b5ee49a0.title: Think Like a Time Lord and Stop Watching the Clock
71b3b5ee49a0.subtitle: September 30
71b3b5ee49a0.content:
Think Like a Time Lord and Stop Watching theÂ Clock

September 30

A day without drama: Tuesdayâ€™s GREAT-2C session completed in 2 hours and 7 minutes with zero major issues, two sophisticated spatial architectures verified operational, a security vulnerability fixed, and comprehensive documentation created. Both PM and Lead Developer independently assessed satisfaction at 9/10 in our end-of-session ritual.

The smoothness felt almost suspicious. Where was the struggle? The discovery of hidden complexity? The midnight debugging session?

The answer lies in something we havenâ€™t talked about publicly yet: we stopped measuring time in ways that distort priorities.

The tyranny of consensus time

Around September 29th, while reviewing gameplans and agent prompts, I noticed a pattern. Time estimates everywhere:

  • â€œPhase -1: 30 minutesâ€
  • â€œRouter completion: 2 hoursâ€
  • â€œTesting and validation: 1 hourâ€
  • â€œMust complete in X timeframeâ€

These werenâ€™t planning aids. They were psychological constraints creating pressure where none should exist. An agent working on infrastructure would see â€œ30 minutes maxâ€ and internalize that speed matters more than completeness. The 80% pattern weâ€™d been fighting wasnâ€™t just about verificationâ€Šâ€”â€Šit was about optimization pressure from arbitrary time boxes.

Time estimates in development serve two masters badly:

  1. As predictions: Theyâ€™re usually wrong, teaching us nothing useful
  2. As constraints: They pressure shortcuts, degrading quality

The solution wasnâ€™t better estimates. It was recognizing that for foundational infrastructure work, Newtonian time is the wrong measure entirely.

Becoming a TimeÂ Lord

Hereâ€™s what I told the team:

I am a Time Lord and I can define time at will. If we must speak about time we should use my bespoke units:
  • Small efforts take a number of mangos
  • Medium efforts take a number of hurons
  • A person may get one diga worth of work done in a day (but it depends)
  • A team might spend a whole whale on a big project

I went on explaining my nonsense system:

There are 87 mangos in a huron, 43 hurons in a diga, 11 digas in a whale, 5â€“6 whales in a mole, and 8 moles in a yak.
If we must speak about time or estimates, it is purely as part of an empirical process of comparing guesses to actual. None of it matters and any references to objective Newtonian time risk distorting our priorities.

The units are deliberately absurd. You canâ€™t feel deadline pressure about completing something in â€œ5 mangosâ€ because mangos arenâ€™t connected to your calendar or your sense of running out of daylight. The conversion factors (87 mangos in a huron) make arithmetic tedious enough that you stop trying to calculate.

This isnâ€™t whimsy for whimsyâ€™s sake. Itâ€™s breaking the psychological connection between â€œtime passingâ€ and â€œmust finish faster.â€

Gambling withÂ Quatloos

The philosophy extends beyond units. Itâ€™s about what estimates actually teach us:

Old way: â€œThis should take 2 hoursâ€ â†’ Work takes 4 hours â†’ â€œWeâ€™re behind scheduleâ€ â†’ Cut corners to catch up

Time Lord way: â€œI wager six quatloos this takes five huronsâ€ â†’ Work takes eight hurons â†’ â€œInteresting! We learned something about scopeâ€

OK, I am mixing my cheesy 60s science fiction references, but stay with me on this.

Estimates become empirical learning, not constraints. The difference between predicted and actual teaches us about our understanding of the work, not our failure to work fast enough.

When the Chief Architect creates a gameplan now, we prefer to use effort estimates insteasd of time (small, medium, large effort predicted vs. actual), but if time language crops up I keep insisting we use my bespoke units. Not to hide real timelines, but to prevent time-thinking from contaminating quality-thinking.

Plus we have timestamps all over our chat transcripts to keep the logs straight, which probably also contributes to the time obsession deeply training into the semantics of business software development.

What happens when you stop watching theÂ clock

Tuesdayâ€™s session working on CORE-GREAT-2C (the third sub-epic in the second epic of the Great Refactor super epic on my Core Functionality track), demonstrated this philosophy in practice.

Phase 0: Investigation without pressure (20Â mangos)

Code and Cursor agents spent time properly verifying infrastructure. Not â€œ30 minutes maxâ€ but â€œuntil we understand the actual state.â€ They discovered:

  • 21 spatial files across the codebase
  • TBD-SECURITY-02 vulnerability precisely located
  • Two different architectural patterns (Slackâ€™s 11-file granular system vs Notionâ€™s 1-file embedded intelligence)

No one rushed. The investigation took what it took.

Phase 1â€“2: Verification without shortcuts (30 mangosÂ each)

Testing Slackâ€™s spatial system revealed minor test infrastructure issues. Instead of deeming them â€œnon-blockingâ€ and moving on (the 80% pattern), Cursor distinguished clearly: â€œThe core system works perfectly, here are 4 minor test-related items.â€

This precision came from having space to think, not pressure to finish.

Testing Notion revealed a completely different architectural patternâ€Šâ€”â€Šembedded spatial intelligence rather than adapter-based. This discovery happened because agents had permission to investigate thoroughly rather than confirm assumptions quickly.

Phase 3: Security fix without fear (17Â mangos)

TBD-SECURITY-02 took 17 minutes to fix because:

  1. Phase 0 had located it precisely
  2. Phases 1â€“2 verified spatial systems worked
  3. No time pressure made agents skip verification steps

Code uncommented 4 lines. Both agents verified spatial system compatibility. Security enabled with zero regressions. Done right because there was time to do it right.

Phase Z: The acceptance criteria discovery

Hereâ€™s where Time Lord philosophy really paid off. During the Phase Z bookending checklist, we reviewed acceptance criteria against completed work and found a discrepancy:

One criterion required â€œIntegration tests passing for both modes.â€ But the work had focused on functional verification, not test suite execution. When Cursor noted test infrastructure issues, the initial instinct was â€œnon-blocking, the systems work.â€

Because there was no time pressure to declare victory and move on, we investigated. Code found and fixed a simple import error:

# Wrong
from services.database.async_session_factory import AsyncSessionFactory
# Right  
from services.database.session_factory import AsyncSessionFactory

Result: 547 integration tests now collectible, 40/40 executable tests passing.

This â€œgnat-sized chaosâ€ would have been missed in a rush to completion. Time Lord philosophy created space to actually check acceptance criteria against deliverables rather than assume they matched.

In retrospect

Tuesdayâ€™s satisfaction ratings (9/10 from both PM and Lead Dev) reflected something deeper than technical success. They reflected the satisfaction of working well.

PMâ€™s assessment: â€œCraft quality and harness resilience. Worried we missed something but the careful work is driving quality.â€

Lead Devâ€™s assessment: â€œInchworm Protocol prevented assumptions. Multi-agent coordination provided binocular vision. Systematic questioning revealed deep insights.â€

Both recognized the same thing: the methodology worked because it had space to work. No artificial time constraints forced shortcuts. No deadline pressure encouraged â€œgood enough for now.â€

The work took 2 hours and 7 minutes. It also took so many mangos for Phase 0, and so on. The Newtonian time happened. The Time Lord units kept us focused on quality.

The vindication

GREAT-2C vindicated multiple recent methodology innovations:

  • Inchworm Protocol: Investigation phases prevented assumption-driven work
  • Cathedral Doctrine: Agent coordination around shared goals caught issues collaboratively
  • Anti-80% Safeguards: Preventively eliminated completion bias
  • Time Lord Philosophy: Quality completion without time pressure

But the Time Lord philosophy enabled the others. The Inchworm Protocol works when you have permission to investigate thoroughly. Cathedral Doctrine requires space for collaborative verification. Anti-80% safeguards need time to enumerate every method.

Remove time pressure and you create space for systematic quality.

Could anyone else use bespoke timeÂ units?

Not every project is a hobby with the luxury of taking all the time needed to get things right, but every project suffers if corners get cut to achieve arbitrary deadlines. You may no be able to introduce jabberwockian languge to your human collaborators or convince them that you control space and time, but if itâ€™s just you and a bunch of bots, they pretty much have to take your word for it.

Also, not every task benefits from Time Lord thinking. Customer support tickets need response time commitments. Marketing campaigns have real launch dates. User-facing bugs deserve urgency.

But foundational infrastructure work? The stuff everything else depends on? That work deserves freedom from the clock.

If youâ€™re in my boat, you could use bespoke units when:

  • Quality compounds: Todayâ€™s shortcuts become tomorrowâ€™s technical debt
  • Discovery matters: Unknown complexity might emerge during work
  • Verification is critical: Systematic checking prevents costly errors later
  • Learning happens: The work teaches you about the domain

And still use Newtonian time when:

  • External deadlines exist (launch dates, commitments)
  • Time-sensitivity matters (security patches, user-facing bugs)
  • Scope is truly fixed (well-understood maintenance work)

The key insight: not all work should be measured the same way.

The paradox

Hereâ€™s the beautiful irony: GREAT-2C completed in 2 hours and 7 minutes. If weâ€™d time-boxed it to 2 hours, we might have finished in 2 hours. But we would have:

  • Skipped the dependency fix (gnat-sized chaos unresolved)
  • Missed the acceptance criteria gap
  • Left 507 tests uncollectable
  • Claimed completion without verification

We finished faster by not trying to finish fast. The work took exactly as long as it needed to be done right, which turned out to be less time than cutting corners would have required plus later fixes.

Time pressure makes work take longer when you account for the full cycle: initial implementation + bug fixes + technical debt resolution + â€œwhy doesnâ€™t this work?â€ debugging sessions. Time Lord philosophy frontloads the quality, eliminating most of the cycle.

Whatâ€™s a mangoÂ worth?

I still donâ€™t know how long a mango takes in minutes. Thatâ€™s the point. When Code says â€œthis will take about 5 mangos,â€ both of us understand:

  • Itâ€™s a small effort
  • The estimate might be wrong
  • Learning from the difference is valuable
  • The work takes what it takes

And when it actually takes 8 mangos? We learned something about the work. Nobody failed. Nobody needs to catch up. We adjust our understanding and continue.

The conversion factors (87 mangos in a huron) arenâ€™t for calculation. Theyâ€™re to make calculation annoying enough that you stop trying. Because the number doesnâ€™t matter. Only the quality does.

Building inÂ public

This Time Lord philosophy might seem strange to teams with deadlines, stakeholders, and quarterly planning. How do you coordinate without shared time metrics?

The answer: coordination and completion are different from constraint and pressure. We still know what needs doing. We still have priorities. We still ship work. We just donâ€™t let arbitrary time boxes degrade the quality of foundational infrastructure.

And when youâ€™re building in public, documenting every step, the proof is in the work. Tuesdayâ€™s GREAT-2C session verified two sophisticated spatial architectures, fixed a security vulnerability, created comprehensive documentation, and achieved 9/10 satisfaction from both PM and developer.

Thatâ€™s what happens when you stop watching the clock.

ffc8f69c6327.title: The Third Pattern: When Investigation Rewrites Your Assumptions
ffc8f69c6327.subtitle: October 1
ffc8f69c6327.content:
The Third Pattern: When Investigation Rewrites Your Assumptions

October 1

We started the day with a clear mission: Calendar integration was the only service without spatial intelligence, sitting at 85% complete with a straightforward 15% remaining. Six hours later, weâ€™d discovered a third architectural pattern, completely changed our priorities, and learned (again) why thorough investigation beats confident assumptions.

The setup

By Tuesday afternoon, weâ€™d documented two distinct spatial patterns in our integration architecture. Slack used a â€œGranular Adapter Patternâ€â€Šâ€”â€Šeleven files spread across its integration directory, each component handling a specific aspect of spatial intelligence. Notion took the opposite approach with an â€œEmbedded Intelligence Patternâ€â€Šâ€”â€Ševerything consolidated into a single 632-line file.

Two patterns, both working beautifully. Both emerged organically from their domain needs rather than from architectural decree.

Calendar was the outlier. The GitHub issue (#195) described it as â€œthe only service potentially without spatial intelligence.â€ The plan seemed clear: investigate, then build the missing spatial wrapper. Maybe two days of work, tops.

We should have been more suspicious of our own clarity.

Phase 0: The contradictions emerge

I deployed two agents for parallel investigation. Code Agent dove deep into the codebase structure, tracing imports and analyzing implementations. Cursor Agent focused on the Calendar router itself, analyzing complexity and dimensional requirements.

I sometimes wonder if itâ€™s overkill (or too expensive?) to work with a pair of coding agents in parallel, but I must say this was not the only time the two found different but complementary truths.

Code Agent reported first: â€œCalendar integration found at services/integrations/calendar/calendar_integration_router.py - only 397 lines, surprisingly minimal. But wait..." The agent had found something in a completely different location: services/mcp/consumer/google_calendar_adapter.py - 499 lines of sophisticated implementation inheriting from BaseSpatialAdapter.

Calendar had spatial intelligence. It just wasnâ€™t where we expected to find it.

Cursor Agent reported next with its own contradiction: â€œRouter shows HIGH complexity (17 methods) with spatial indicators present. But dimensional analysis shows LOW complexity across all spatial dimensions (temporal, priority, collaborative, hierarchical, contextual).â€

Both agents were right. And both were seeing something we hadnâ€™t anticipated.

The discovery

What theyâ€™d found was a third spatial pattern, one we hadnâ€™t documented because we hadnâ€™t fully recognized it.

The Delegated MCP Pattern: A minimal router in the integration directory that delegates all spatial intelligence to an external MCP (Model Context Protocol) consumer adapter. The router provides the orchestration interface, while the MCP adapter handles the actual spatial intelligence.

This wasnâ€™t sloppy architecture or incomplete implementation. This was elegant separation of concerns optimized for MCP-based integrations.

Slackâ€™s granular pattern? Perfect for real-time event coordination requiring reactive response across multiple channels.

Notionâ€™s embedded pattern? Ideal for analytical knowledge management with stable, self-contained intelligence.

Calendarâ€™s delegated pattern? Exactly right for temporal awareness through protocol-based integration where the MCP consumer already provides sophisticated spatial context extraction.

Three patterns. Three domain-driven solutions. All working without issues.

The pivot

At 1:27 PM, I pulled in the Chief Architect (Claude Opus) for strategic consultation. The discoveries had implications beyond Calendar integration.

â€œAre three patterns acceptable complexity,â€ I asked, â€œor accidental proliferation we should prevent?â€

The verdict: Acceptable IF documented properly. Each pattern emerged from genuine domain needs rather than arbitrary choices. The risk wasnâ€™t having three patternsâ€Šâ€”â€Šit was pattern proliferation through lack of documentation and selection criteria.

But there was a bigger issue hiding in the investigation results.

Code Agent had uncovered something while analyzing Calendarâ€™s configuration: â€œALL 4 services lack proper startup validation. GitHub, Slack, Notion, Calendarâ€Šâ€”â€Šnone validate their configuration before attempting to run.â€

This was the real infrastructure gap. Calendar being 95% complete instead of 85% complete (with only tests and documentation missing) was interesting. But services that could fail at runtime due to misconfiguration? That was a production problem waiting to happen.

The Chief Architect made the call: â€œPriority 1: Configuration validation for all 4 services. Priority 2: Calendar completion (the quick win). Priority 3: Document the Delegated MCP Pattern in ADR-038.â€

Weâ€™d started the day planning to build spatial intelligence for Calendar. We ended up building configuration validation infrastructure for the entire system instead.

The implementation sprint

Phase 1 took about an hour. Both agents coordinated beautifullyâ€Šâ€”â€ŠCode built the ConfigValidator service (404 lines validating all four services), Cursor integrated it into startup and CI. By 2:30 PM, we had:

  • Configuration validation running on startup with graceful degradation
  • A /health/config endpoint for monitoring
  • CI pipeline integration catching misconfigurations before deployment
  • All 21 Calendar integration tests passing in 2.74 seconds
  • ADR-038 updated with the Delegated MCP Pattern

The whole epicâ€Šâ€”â€ŠCORE-GREAT-2Dâ€Šâ€”â€Šclosed at 3:12 PM. Duration: 4 hours 54 minutes. All six acceptance criteria met with evidence.

What investigation actuallyÂ costs

Hereâ€™s the thing about thorough Phase 0 investigation: It feels expensive in the moment. We spent 90 minutes investigating before writing a single line of implementation code.

But consider the alternative timeline:

Without investigation, weâ€™d have spent 1â€“2 days building a spatial wrapper for Calendar that wasnâ€™t needed. Weâ€™d have missed the configuration validation gap that affects production stability. Weâ€™d have three undocumented spatial patterns instead of three well-understood architectural options. And weâ€™d have 21 missing tests instead of 21 passing tests.

With investigation, we spent 90 minutes discovering what already existed, what was actually missing, and what the real priority should be. Then we spent an hour building the right thing.

The Time Lord principle (â€œthoroughness over speedâ€) isnâ€™t about moving slowly. Itâ€™s about not having to rebuild what you rushed through the first time.

The eveningÂ coda

The afternoon brought GREAT-2E (documentation verification and link checking), which took 74 minutes to complete after investigation revealed it was already 95% done. The Chief Architect and I closed the entire GREAT-2 epic sequence at 4:59 PM.

Two issues closed, one epic completed, approximately eight hours of focused work. Not bad for a Wednesday.

But the real win wasnâ€™t the velocity. It was discovering weâ€™d accidentally developed three domain-optimized spatial patterns instead of one canonical approach. It was preventing days of unnecessary work through 90 minutes of investigation. It was finding the real infrastructure gap hiding behind our assumptions.

The calendar integration was never broken. Our assumptions were just incomplete.

Whatâ€™s next

Tomorrow weâ€™ll decompose GREAT-3 (Plugin Architecture), which will build on these three spatial patterns rather than fighting against them. The configuration validation system we built today will help us identify which gaps are real infrastructure issues versus refactoring artifacts.

And weâ€™ll approach it the same way: Investigation first, assumptions second, implementation last.

f38cde251d9d.title: Systemic Kindness: Building Methodology That Feels Supportive
f38cde251d9d.content:
August 14

â€œSystematize kindness, and systematize excellence in a kind fashion.â€

That phrase stopped me in my tracks during todayâ€™s planning session. We were discussing how Piper could coordinate multiple AI agents while enforcing our Excellence Flywheel methodology, when this deeper vision emerged: what if systematic excellence could beÂ kind?

Note: I canâ€™t help thinking that some of this thinking began in Claudeâ€™s mind as wordplay, knowing I current work forâ€¦ Kind Systems, but it clearly also flows from observations about myÂ process.

The traditional automation trap

Most automated systems optimize for efficiency at anyÂ cost:

Typical error message: â€œTEST FAILED. FIX YOURÂ CODE.â€

Typical review: â€œMissing documentation. Rejected.â€

Typical workflow: â€œRequirements not met. TryÂ again.â€

These systems get compliance through pressure. They make failure feel shameful rather than educational. They create fear of the process rather than trust inÂ it.

The Piper approach: kind excellence

What if systematic methodology felt supportive instead of demanding?

Not: â€œYour code is wrong. Fix it.â€ But: â€œI notice we havenâ€™t verified existing patterns yet. Let me help you checkâ€Šâ€”â€Šthis often saves time and prevents frustration later.â€

Not: â€œFailed. No tests present.â€ But: â€œExcellence happens when we write tests first. Would you like me to show you how tests for this feature mightÂ look?â€

Not: â€œInefficient. Should have parallelized.â€ But: â€œI see an opportunity here! We could have Claude and Cursor work in parallel. Next time, letâ€™s try that patternâ€Šâ€”â€Šit often doubles our velocity.â€

The difference isnâ€™t just toneâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s philosophy. Kind systems assume good intentions, explain the why, and make learning feelÂ safe.

The conversation that got usÂ thinking

During todayâ€™s planning chat with my Chief Architect, we started exploring how Piper could become an Excellence Flywheel enforcer for AI agent teams. The conversation evolvedÂ quickly:

â€œWill Piper enforce the excellence flywheel, in an appropriate mode forÂ agents?â€

We sketched out what this might lookÂ like:

class PiperAgentCoordinator:
    """Piper manages AI agents using adapted Excellence Flywheel principles"""
    
    def assign_task(self, agent, task):
        # 1. SYSTEMATIC VERIFICATION FIRST (adapted for agents)
        instructions = f"""
        BEFORE IMPLEMENTATION:
        1. Verify current state: {self.get_verification_commands(task)}
        2. Check existing patterns: {self.get_pattern_search(task)}

        # Cleanup logic

        # Health reporting

The wrappers donâ€™t replace the integration routersâ€Šâ€”â€Šthey coordinate them. The router does the work, the plugin wrapper provides lifecycle management and registration.

Documentation through structure. The plugin interface is the documentation. Every plugin implements the same contract, follows the same patterns, reports status the sameÂ way.

The multi-agent coordination moment

What this means forÂ you

The questions toÂ ask:

  • Whatâ€™s the marginal cost of making it systematic?
  • Does this create infrastructure for future work or just wrap currentÂ work?

Your mileage will vary. But donâ€™t assume â€œplugin systemâ€ automatically means over-engineering. Sometimes it just means finishing what youÂ started.

8aacc89aecc9.title: Why the Future of AI UX is Orchestration, Not Intelligence
8aacc89aecc9.content:
August 20

After months of building with multiple AI agents, a pattern keeps emerging: We create sophisticated systems, lose track of what we built, then rediscover our own achievements through â€œarchaeologicalâ€ investigation.

This recurring cycle of institutional amnesia may be a bug in our process but for todayâ€™s LLM services, itâ€™s a feature that reveals the real UX challenge ahead.

The intelligence plateau and the orchestration valley

The AI industry is obsessed with reasoning capabilities. Larger context windows, better chain-of-thought, more sophisticated inference. Meanwhile, anyone actually building with AI faces a different problem entirely: How do you coordinate multiple specialized capabilities without losing yourÂ mind?

Anyone reading this series has the right to question what this process may be doing to my mind at this veryÂ moment!

Yesterday we discovered 599 comprehensive smoke tests weâ€™d apparently built and then completely forgotten. Saturday we rediscovered attribution systems weâ€™d implemented but lost track of (in fact, I only just now remembered it again and added it to my notes to include ATTRIBUTION.md to our weekly doc sweep). Two weeks ago we found enterprise-grade feedback APIs sitting in our codebase, unmarked and uncredited.

The pattern isnâ€™t forgetfulnessâ€Šâ€”â€Šitâ€™s that our tools for building are ahead of our tools for remembering.

From brilliant generalists to orchestrated specialists

The current paradigm assumes one brilliant AI that can handle anything you throw at it. The emerging paradigm recognizes that specialized tools, properly coordinated, deliver better results than generalist intelligence.

  • Claude Code: Architecture and systematic implementation
  • Cursor Agent: Targeted debugging and focusedÂ fixes

One thing this enables me to do is to have focused coherent conversations and decision-making processes always at the right level of abstraction. Early on I found that as soon as multiple contexts get mixed you get a mishmash of more generic and sloppy advice and results. Itâ€™s kind of like how if you mix too many paints you end up with the same muddyÂ brown.

The UX we actuallyÂ need

After coordinating multi-agent workflows for months, Iâ€™m realizing that the UX challenges arenâ€™t about reasoningâ€Šâ€”â€Štheyâ€™reÂ about:

  • Context handoffs: How do you maintain working memory across agent transitions?
  • Coordination protocols: How do you deploy the right agent for the right task without overwhelming the human orchestrator?
  • Institutional memory: How do you prevent the â€œforgotten monumentsâ€ cycle where sophisticated systems get lost in your own complexity?
  • Verification workflows: How do you maintain quality when multiple agents contribute to the sameÂ outcome?

Each of these is critical and urgent in its own way. Getting any of these wrong means you are just injecting chaos into your processes.

Throwing intelligence at everything

We keep applying intelligence solutions to orchestration problems. Need better coordination? Train a smarter model. Need better memory? Increase context windows. Need better task routing? Build more sophisticated reasoning.

Except, orchestration isnâ€™t really an intelligence problem. Itâ€™s a UX designÂ problem.

My failed adoption of the TLDR system is a perfect illustration. I absorbed something that sounded cool to me without really understanding it was intended to work with 50ms test timeouts from compiled languages, which ignores Pythonâ€™s ecosystem realities. More intelligence wouldnâ€™t have fixed the fundamental mismatch where understanding my constraints better wouldÂ have.

Affordances over algorithms

UX for AI will be definedÂ by:

Specialized models over generalist LLMs. A focused SLM that understands database schemas will outperform a brilliant generalist that has to reason about every query from first principles.

Orchestration patterns over individual agent capabilities. The system that deploys the right specialist at the right time beats the system with the smartest individual components.

Context management over context windows. Better handoff protocols matter more than larger memory capacity.

Coordination affordances over reasoning power. Tools that help humans orchestrate AI workflows effectively will matter more than tools that make individual AI agents moreÂ capable.

I canâ€™t even say how these affordances will look or behave. Iâ€™m treading the cowpaths now, and hoping talented UX designers (hey, Iâ€™m just a PM these days!) can figure this out and save me all the manual work and cognitive labor I do to provide resilience and coherence via scaffolding, harness, redundancy, and other the other hacks Iâ€™ve been picking up through trial and error (and stealing ideas from other people!).

The working memory revolution

Our recurring â€œarchaeological discoveryâ€ pattern reveals the real frontier: building systems that maintain institutional memory across time, people, and context switches.

Every time we rediscover forgotten excellence, weâ€™re experiencing the same challenge every team building with AI will face: How do you scale human-AI collaboration without losing track of what youâ€™ve accomplished?

Orchestration as a new kind ofÂ literacy

Pretty soon, prompting individual AI agents effectively will stop being the valuable skill (or parlor trick) it is today. What weâ€™re going to look for is the ability to orchestrate multiple specialized AI capabilities without losing coherence.

Product managers will need orchestration patterns for coordinating AI-augmented workflows acrossÂ teams.

Designers will need to make (and use!) affordances for human-AI collaboration that maintain user agency while leveraging AI capabilities.

Engineers will need architecture patterns for composing AI services without creating coordination overhead.

The Piper MorganÂ thesis

While I am definitely building a product management tool, I find I am also prototyping the UX patterns that are like to define human-AI collaboration, or at least point us in the right direction, over the nextÂ decade.

I always knew this was a learning project. I sincerely want ship v1 of Piper Morgan and deliver value to myself and ideally others as well. At the same time itâ€™s been incredibly rewarding just plunging in learning things constantly, and then turning around quickly to share my enthusiasm with all ofÂ you.

What I didnâ€™t realize is that beyond building Piper Morgan, I may be studying just exactly the sort of interesting puzzles and problems and opportunities that the brightest minds in UX and digital software product development need to be figuring out, and fast! (Before the bad guys own itÂ all.)

My recurring cycle of building sophisticated systems, losing track of them, and rediscovering them through archaeological investigation provides some ongoing comic relief for anyone following along, as well as an endless rollercoaster ride of elation and chagrin for me, and it also happens to be one of the fundamental challenges that every organization building with AI willÂ face.

Smarter AI isnâ€™t going to get us there, but better orchestration justÂ might.

This is the story of how Tuesday brought another milestone for what four months of systematic work had built toward. Not through heroic effort, but through discovering that most of the work had already been doneâ€Šâ€”â€Šit just needed the final 5% found, fixed, and validated.

The two-minute ADR

At 7:51 AM, Code agent deployed to create ADR-039: Canonical Handler Pattern documentation. Estimated time: 20â€“30 minutes. Actual time: 2 minutes. Why do they pad these estimates? They know they write fast,Â right?

The ADR wasnâ€™t shorter or lower quality than expected. It was comprehensive: 399 lines documenting the dual-path architecture, explaining when to use canonical handlers versus workflow orchestration, including performance metrics from GREAT-4E, providing troubleshooting guidance.

What made it fast wasnâ€™t the agent writing faster. It was the specification beingÂ clearer.

The gameplan didnâ€™t say â€œwrite an ADR about canonical handlers.â€ ItÂ said:

Document the dual-path architecture: WHAT (two routing paths exist), WHY (performance vs capability trade-offs), WHEN (which path for which requests), HOW (decision criteria), PERFORMANCE (actual metrics from GREAT-4E benchmarks).

Clear specifications enable speed. When the agent knows exactly what â€œdoneâ€ looks like, implementation becomes straightforward.

This pattern repeated throughout Tuesday.

Phase 1 (QUERY fallback patterns): estimated 30â€“40 minutes, actual 14 minutes. GREAT-5 Phase 3 (integration tests): estimated 45â€“60 minutes, actual 15Â minutes.

Not because work was skipped. Because foundations were solid and requirements wereÂ clear.

The missing definitions

At 9:40 AM, Cursor completed Phase 2 of GREAT-4F: enhancing the LLM classifier prompts.

The discovery was almost embarrassing in its simplicity.

The classifier prompt didnâ€™t include definitions for the five canonical categories. This feels like the kind of shortcut/oversight that plagued our coding process for most of the first fewÂ months.

The categories existed. The handlers worked. The routing was correct. The tests all passed. But the LLM classifierâ€Šâ€”â€Šthe system that decides which category a natural language query belongs toâ€Šâ€”â€Šhad never been told what the canonical categories actuallyÂ were.

When someone said â€œWhat day is it?â€ the classifier wouldÂ see:

  • Available categories: QUERY, CREATE, UPDATE, SEARCH, EXECUTION, ANALYSIS, SYNTHESIS, STRATEGY, LEARNING, GUIDANCE, UNKNOWN
  • Query: â€œWhat day isÂ it?â€
  • Decision: Probably QUERY (default whenÂ unsure)

TEMPORAL didnâ€™t appear in the options because the prompt never mentioned itÂ existed.

The fix: Add five lines defining canonical categories in the classifier prompt.

The impact: +11 to 15 percentage points accuracy improvement.

PRIORITY went from 85â€“95% accuracy to 100% (perfect classification). TEMPORAL jumped to 96.7%. STATUS to 96.7%. All three exceeding the 95%Â target.

Itâ€™s a weird feeling to be both annoyed that something so simple was skipped and hiding in plain site as well as relieved and satisfied after fixingÂ it.

This is the flip side of the â€œ75% pattern.â€ Sometimes you discover infrastructure is better than expected. Sometimes you discover a simple fix dramatically improves things. But both require actuallyÂ looking.

The categories worked in isolation. Unit tests passed. Integration tests with canonical queries worked because those tests bypassed the LLM classifier entirelyâ€Šâ€”â€Šthey called handlers directly.

The gap only appeared when testing the full flow: natural language â†’ LLM classification â†’ canonical handlerÂ routing.

Comprehensive testing reveals assumptions. And sometimes those assumptions are â€œsurely someone told the classifier what these categories mean.â€

The permissive test anti-pattern

Throughout Tuesday morning, a pattern kept appearing in the testÂ suite:

# Permissive (accepts both success and failure):
assert response.status_code in [200, 404]

# Strict (requires success):
assert response.status_code == 200

The permissive version accepts both â€œworking correctlyâ€ (200) and â€œendpoint doesnâ€™t existâ€ (404) as valid test passes. When I saw that I was like â€œwait, wat?â€ How is â€œendpoint doesnâ€™t existâ€ a success state? Because a reply was returned? ComeÂ on!

GREAT-5 Phase 1 systematically eliminated this pattern. Twelve permissive assertions replaced with strict requirements. The immediate result: tests startedÂ failing.

  • Two cache endpoint bugs: AttributeError exceptions in production code
  • Health endpoint protection gaps: Tests accepting failures that would break monitoring

None of these were caught by permissive tests because permissive tests donâ€™t catch problemsâ€Šâ€”â€Šthey hide them. Seriously, who writes permissive tests anyhow? Who trained the LLMs to doÂ that?

The philosophy difference:

  • â€œMake tests passâ€: Write tests that accept current behavior, even ifÂ broken
  • â€œMake code workâ€: Write strict tests that force code to meet requirements

Permissive tests create false confidence. Everything appears to work because tests pass. But the tests are lyingâ€Šâ€”â€Šthey pass whether code works orÂ not.

By end of Phase 1, all permissive patterns were eliminated. Tests now enforce actual requirements. Which meant Phase 1 also had to fix the code that failed strict testsâ€Šâ€”â€Šincluding two production bugs that had been lurking undetected.

This is the unglamorous side of quality work. Itâ€™s not adding features. Itâ€™s making tests honest about what they validate.

Quality gates as compoundÂ momentum

GREAT-5â€™s goal was establishing additional quality gates protecting all GREAT-1 through GREAT-4 achievements. The existing gatesÂ were:

  • Performance regression detection
  • Coverage enforcement (80%+)

  3. Performance benchmarks: Lock in 602K req/sec baseline fromÂ GREAT-4E
  4. CI/CD pipeline verification: 2.5-minute runtime with fail-fast design

The interesting discovery: most of these alreadyÂ existed.

CI/CD pipeline? Already excellent, needed zero changes. Performance benchmarks? GREAT-4E had validated them, just needed test suite integration. Load testing? Cache validation tests already proved efficiency.

What remainedÂ was:

  • Enhancing regression tests with strict assertions
  • Creating comprehensive integration tests
  • Fixing the bugs strict testsÂ revealed
  • Documenting what quality gates exist andÂ why

GREAT-5 took 1.8 hours (109 minutes of actual work). Not because the work was small, but because foundations were alreadyÂ solid.

This is compound momentum visible: each previous epic made this one easier. GREAT-4Eâ€™s performance validation became GREAT-5â€™s benchmark baseline. GREAT-3â€™s plugin architecture became GREAT-5â€™s integration test framework. GREAT-2â€™s spatial intelligence became GREAT-5â€™s multi-interface validation.

Nothing built in isolation. Everything building on everything else.

The completion moment

At 1:15 PM, Chief Architect declared GREAT-4 complete.

All six sub-epics (4A through 4F) finished. Intent classification system production-ready:

  • 84.6% cache hit rate with 7.6Ã—Â speedup

By 6:52 PM, GREAT-5 was complete asÂ well:
